title: Forrest v. A.S. Price Mechanical
description: We affirm the circuit court's order affirming the Workers' Compensation Commission's computation of claimant's compensation, the finding that claimant has reached maximum medical improvement, and the admission of claimant's vocational expert's report.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Cally R. Forrest, Jr., Respondent,
v.
A.S. Price Mechanical and Oâ€™Steen Adjusting Services,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4227
Heard March 6, 2007 â€“ Filed April 2, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Duke K. McCall, Jr., Rebecca H. Zabel and Zandra Johnson, all of Greenville, for Appellants.
Belinda Ellison, of Lexington and James B. Richardson, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation case, Cally R. Forrest, Jr. sustained injuries from a work-related accident while employed by Appellant A.S. Price Mechanical.[1]Â  Appellant concedes that Forrest is entitled to lifetime medical and workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  Appellant assigns error to the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s computation of Forrestâ€™s compensation, the finding that Forrest has reached maximum medical improvement (MMI), and the admission of Forrestâ€™s vocational expertâ€™s report.Â  We affirm.
I.
With the exception of four semesters spent at Clemson University, Forrest was employed full-time since graduating from high school in 1995, usually working multiple jobs.[2]Â  As a high school student, Forrest worked regularly, including seasonal, full-time work with Monetta Peach Packers.Â  He continued seasonal employment with Monetta Peach Packers until his injury on May 26, 2001.Â  During the remaining months of the year, Forrest worked for several employers, including Appellant A.S. Price Mechanical, Priceâ€™s Metal Shop, Gibson Construction Company, and J.E. Oswalt & Sons (â€œOswaltâ€).Â  
After leaving Clemson in December of 1998, Forrest began working full-time for Larry Price at Priceâ€™s Metal Shop.[3]Â  Forrest also worked for Appellant on the weekends.Â  In the fall of 1999, Forrestâ€™s job with Appellant changed from part-time to full-time, and he began working for Larry Price only part-time.Â  When work with Appellant was slow, Forrest would work for Gibson Construction Company.Â  Eventually, his job with Gibson Construction Company became full-time, and he worked for Appellant only part-time.Â  By the start of the 2000 peach season, the specific construction Forrest was working on was completed with Gibson Construction Company, and Forrest once again began his seasonal work with Monetta Peach Packers.Â  
At the end of the peach season in 2000, Forrest began working full-time for Oswalt and part-time with Appellant.Â  When the peach season began in 2001, he left his job at Oswalt and went back to Monetta Peach Packers.Â  Forrest testified he intended to go back to work for Oswalt at the end of the 2001 peach season.Â  He further noted that the owner of Oswalt and one of the owners of Monetta Peach Packers were friends and knew of his intentions.Â Â  
Forrest was injured during the 2001 peach season when he fell from a roof while working part-time for Appellant.Â  Forrest was twenty-four years old at the time of the accident.Â  The injuries rendered him a paraplegic.
Appellant agreed to pay Forrest workersâ€™ compensation at a rate of $490.00.Â  This amount reflected Forrestâ€™s combined wages from Appellant and Monetta Peach Packers.Â Â  
The single commissioner subsequently adjusted the compensation rate to $532.72.Â  This compensation rate represented Forrestâ€™s average weekly wage from January 1, 2001 to May 26, 2001, while working for Appellant, Monetta Peach Packers, and Oswalt.Â  The Commission adopted the order of the single commissioner.Â  The circuit court held the Commissionâ€™s findings were supported by substantial evidence and affirmed.
II.
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  â€œIn workersâ€™ compensation cases, the Full Commission is the ultimate fact finder.â€Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  This court reviews facts based on the substantial evidence standard.Â  Thompson v. S.C. Steel Erectors, 369 S.C. 606, 612, 632 S.E.2d 874, 877 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Under the substantial evidence standard, the appellate court may not substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2006).Â  The appellate court may reverse or modify the Commissionâ€™s decision only if the claimantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced because the decision is affected by an error of law or is clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Id.Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed from one side, but such evidence, when the whole record is considered, as would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the Full Commission reached.â€Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.
III.
Appellant argues the circuit court erred in affirming the Commissionâ€™s computation of Forrestâ€™s average weekly wage of $532.72.Â  First, Appellant asserts that the doctrines of estoppel and laches preclude Forrest from asserting a different wage than the parties agreed upon.Â  Next, Appellant objects to the inclusion of Oswalt as an employer in the rate computation, and maintains that Forrest was not employed with Oswalt at the time of his injury.Â  Appellant contends any wages earned as a result of his previous employment with Oswalt are irrelevant per section 42-1-40 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006).Â  Finally, Appellant argues there are no exceptional circumstances justifying an adjustment or computation of Forrestâ€™s average weekly wage in a method other than that employed originally.
At the outset we hold that the doctrines of estoppel and laches do not preclude the Commission from adjusting the average weekly wage prior to the administrative bodyâ€™s final determination.Â  Appellantâ€™s argument stems from the fact that Forrestâ€™s initial compensation rate was $300 per week until he requested that this rate be increased to include wages earned from Monetta Peach Packers.Â  Appellant states it agreed to the new calculation ($490 per week) and filed a new Form 15 with the Commission in exchange for Forrest agreeing to withdraw his request for a hearing.Â  Forrest filed a new Form 19 with the Commission confirming his acceptance of the rate, and Appellant maintains it relied to its detriment on Forrestâ€™s promise of acceptance.Â  
The circuit court correctly held that neither a Form 15 nor a Form 19 is a final judgment.Â  Section 42-17-10 of the South Carolina Code (1985) allows the Commission to adjust a claimantâ€™s compensation rate after the filing of the claim, even when the parties agree to the preliminary compensation rate.Â  Section 42-17-10 provides: â€œAll such agreements [between the claimant and employer as to rate of compensation] shall be subject to adjustment and correction as to the compensable rate if subsequent to filing with the Commission it is determined that such rate does not reflect the correct average weekly wage of the claimant.â€Â  Moreover, Appellant has failed to establish any detrimental reliance. 
On the merits, we disagree with Appellantâ€™s contention that the Commission erred in including Oswalt as an employer in Forrestâ€™s average weekly wage computation. Section 42-1-40 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) defines â€œaverage weekly wageâ€ for the purposes of computing compensation and sets forth four different methods of calculation.[4]Â  The methods for calculating average weekly wage explained in section 42-1-40 have been interpreted by our courts to implement the â€œusualâ€ job situation with one employer.Â  See Foreman v. Jackson Minit Markets, Inc.
  265 S.C. 164, 167, 217 S.E.2d 214, 215 (1975) (summarizing the four different methods of calculating average weekly wage in the predecessor to section 42-1-40).Â  However, section 42-1-40 further provides that when exceptional reasons make one of the standard approaches unfair to either the employer or employee, â€œsuch other method of computing average weekly wages may be resorted to as will most nearly approximate the amount which the injured employee would be earning were it not for the injury.â€Â  We note that exceptional circumstances have been found where an employee has multiple employers at the same time.Â  See, e.g. Brunson v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 344 S.C. 107, 111, 542 S.E.2d 732, 734 (Ct. App. 2001) (listing several cases where multiple employment has been sufficient to justify exceptional circumstances).
Appellant argues section 42-1-40 requires that the wage being earned at the time of the injury be the wage that controls the compensation rate.Â  On the date of the injury, Appellant correctly points out that Forrest only worked for Appellant and Monetta Peach Packers.Â Â Â  
The Commission found that the following â€œexceptional circumstancesâ€ justified deviation from the usual statutory method of average weekly wage computation: (1) Forrestâ€™s young age of twenty-four years at the time of injury;[5] (2) Forrestâ€™s demonstration of the interest, aptitude, ability, work ethic, and work history to be both a welder or maintenance worker and an employee who had worked year-round with multiple employers; (3) the fact that Forrest worked for Monetta Peach Packers during the peach season for several months each year since he was fifteen and had worked for two or three additional employers to complete his annual earnings and year-round employment; (4) the severity of Forrestâ€™s injury; and (5) the fact that Appellant knew that Forrest regularly worked full-time and part-time for multiple employers.Â  
The circuit court did not err in affirming the Commission.[6]Â  The Commission acted within its broad discretion in determining that exceptional circumstances existed.Â  In finding exceptional circumstances in other cases, this court has reasoned that â€œ[section 42-1-40] provides an elasticity or flexibility with a view toward always achieving the ultimate objective of reflecting fairly a claimantâ€™s probable future earning loss.â€Â  Sellers v. Pinedale Residential Ctr., 350 S.C. 183, 191, 564 S.E.2d 694, 698 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œMoreover, it is well established that the objective of wage calculation is to arrive at a fair approximation of the claimantâ€™s probable future earning capacity.â€Â  Elliott v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 362 S.C. 234, 238, 607 S.E.2d 90, 92 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œDisability reaches into the future, not the past; loss as a result of the injury must be thought of in terms of its impact on probable future earnings.â€Â  Id. (citing Bennett v. Gary Smith Builders, 271 S.C. 94, 98-99, 245 S.E.2d 129, 131 (1978)).Â  
Forrestâ€™s work history demonstrates a laudable, strong work ethic.Â  There is no reason to second-guess the Commissionâ€™s finding that, were it not for his injury and subsequent paraplegia, Forrest would be working full-time and part-time, year-round for several different employers because of his commitment to seasonal employment with Monetta Peach Packers.Â  To arrive at a fair average weekly wage in this case, it was reasonable for the Commission to examine Forrestâ€™s actual work history.Â  The Commission looked to the period from January 1, 2001 until the date of Forrestâ€™s injury on May 26, 2001â€”a twenty-one-week period.Â  This time period reflected Forrestâ€™s true earnings and thus a fair estimation of his future earning capacity.Â  The rate of compensation determined by the Commission is consonant with the statutory scheme, as well as a fair rate to both Forrest and Appellant.Â  
Appellant attempts to distinguish this case from Sellers v. Pinedale Residential Ctr., 350 S.C. 183, 564 S.E.2d 694 (Ct. App. 2002), a case relied upon by the Commission.Â  This case is not distinguishable in any meaningful way that Appellant urges.Â  In Sellers, a case where exceptional circumstances were found to exist, a sixteen-year-old became a paraplegic as a result of a job injury.Â  350 S.C. at 186, 564 S.E.2d at 696.Â  The Commission noted the similarity between the two claimants (Sellers and Forrest) in that they were both of a young age and regularly worked three jobs.Â  Appellant contends in Sellers the claimant demonstrated that he planned to become a master electrician, which warranted the Commission increasing his compensation rate to that of an electrician.Â  Unlike the claimant in Sellers, Appellant argues Forrest has made no such showing.Â  Appellant contends Forrest â€œhas voluntarily assumed a pattern of work that is somewhat unconventional[.]â€Â  By conceding Forrestâ€™s â€œpattern of work,â€ Appellant in effect lends support to the Commissionâ€™s reliance on Forrestâ€™s true work history.Â  This reliance on Forrestâ€™s demonstrated work history supports the Commissionâ€™s finding of exceptional circumstances.Â  If anything, Forrest presents a stronger case for a finding of exceptional circumstances than Sellers did.
As for the argument that Forrestâ€™s testimony about intending to return to work for Oswalt is too speculative to determine future earnings, we find substantial evidence supports the Commissionâ€™s findings.Â  Forrestâ€™s future work plans, interrupted by his injury, may be reasonably gauged by his work history. 
Perhaps Forrestâ€™s strong work ethic is â€œunconventional,â€ but that is no reason to discount his actual work history and earnings.Â  The law mandates the Commission evaluate each case (including a claimantâ€™s average weekly wage) in accordance with its particular facts.Â  The quest here is one for truth in light of the particular case, not by resort to an employerâ€™s idea of what is â€œconventionalâ€ that can be advanced when an employer is up against a claimant with a solid work ethic and a demonstrable pattern of consistent work and earnings.Â  Substantial evidence supports the Commissionâ€™s determination of Forrestâ€™s average weekly wage.Â  
IV.
As for Appellantâ€™s remaining assignments of error, we affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities: Gadson v. Mikasa Corp., 368 S.C. 214, 224, 628 S.E.2d 262, 268 (Ct. App. 2006) (noting that MMI is a factual determination left to the discretion of the Commission); Dodge v. Bruccoli, Clark, Layman, Inc., 334 S.C. 574, 580-81, 514 S.E.2d 593, 596 (Ct. App. 1999) (finding MMI â€œindicate[s] that a person has reached such a plateau that in the physicianâ€™s opinion there is no further medical care or treatment which will lessen the degree of impairment[,]â€ while disability is the â€œincapacity because of an injury to earn the wages which the employee was receiving at the time of injury in the same or any other employmentâ€); Fields v. Regâ€™l Med. Ctr. Orangeburg, 363 S.C. 19, 25, 609 S.E.2d 506, 509 (2005) (noting the qualification of an expert witness and the admissibility of the expertâ€™s testimony are matters within the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion); Peterson v. Natâ€™l R.R. Passenger Corp., 365 S.C. 391, 399, 618 S.E.2d 903, 907 (2005) (â€œDefects in an expert witnessâ€™ education and experience go to the weight, not the admissibility, of the expertâ€™s testimony.â€); Gadson, 368 S.C. at 229, 628 S.E.2d at 270 (finding that the Commission acted within its discretion in allowing a certified rehabilitation counselor with a masterâ€™s degree to render an opinion on employability).Â  
V.
For the reasons stated above, the order of the circuit court is
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]  The employerâ€™s carrier, Oâ€™Steen Adjusting Services, is also an appellant.Â  
[2]  Forrest testified that although he received a scholarship to attend Clemson, he left after two years because he wanted to work full-time and get married.Â  
[3]  Larry Price is Forrestâ€™s father-in-law and Allen Priceâ€™s uncle.Â  Allen Price is the owner of Appellant A.S. Price Mechanical.
[4]  Section 42-1-40 provides as follows:

â€œAverage weekly wagesâ€ means the earnings of the injured employee in the employment in which he was working at the time of the injury during the period of fifty-two weeks immediately preceding the date of the injury . . . .Â  â€œAverage weekly wageâ€ must be calculated by taking the total wages paid for the last four quarters immediately preceding the quarter in which the injury occurred . . . divided by fifty-two or by the actual number of weeks for which wages were paid, whichever is less.Â  When the employment, prior to the injury, extended over a period of less than fifty-two weeks, the method of dividing the earnings during that period by the number of weeks and parts thereof during which the employee earned wages shall be followed, as long as results fair and just to both parties will be obtained.Â  Where, by reason of a shortness of time during which the employee has been in the employment of his employer or the casual nature or terms of his employment, it is impracticable to compute the average weekly wages as defined in this section, regard is to be had to the average weekly amount which during the fifty-two weeks previous to the injury was being earned by a person of the same grade and character employed in the same class of employment in the same locality or community.Â  

(Emphasis added.)Â  
[5]  The Commissionâ€™s order states Forrest was twenty-three at the time of injury.Â  Forrestâ€™s testimony and birth date (May 22, 1977) show, however, that Forrest turned twenty-four four days prior to his accident.
[6]  We recognize the difficulty with the factor concerning the severity of a claimantâ€™s injury and the implication of a sliding scale relationship between injury and determination of average weekly wage.Â  But see Sellers v. Pinedale Residential Ctr., 350 S.C. 183, 191, 564 S.E.2d 694, 699 (Ct. App. 2002) (finding the extent of Sellersâ€™ injury was a factor warranting a ruling of exceptional circumstances).

title: Abercrombie v. Abercrombie
description: In this domestic action, Husband appeals the family court's (1) valuation and equitable division of marital property, (2) award of aliony to Wife, and (3) decision to retain a portion of the equitable distribution awarded to Husband to clean hazardous waste materials he left on the marital property.  We affirm.
text:
Abercrombie v. Abercrombie


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Sherrie Lynn Abercrombie, Respondent,
v.
Keith Abercrombie, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Laurens County
Â John M. Rucker, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4228
Heard March 7, 2007 â€“ Filed April 2, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Rodney M. Brown, of Fountain Inn, for Appellant.
Jim S. Brooks, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  In this domestic action, Keith Abercrombie (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s (1) valuation and equitable division of marital property, (2) award of alimony to Sherrie Lynn Abercrombie (Wife), and (3) decision to retain a portion of the equitable distribution awarded to Husband to clean hazardous waste materials he left on the marital property.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Husband and Wife married in December 1974.Â  The parties separated in 2003, and Wife sought a divorce based on Husbandâ€™s adultery.Â  The family court granted Wife the divorce based on Husbandâ€™s infidelity, granted Wife custody of the children, awarded Wife child support, made a fifty-fifty equitable distribution of the marital estate, awarded Wife alimony, and retained a portion of Husbandâ€™s equitable distribution to clean hazardous waste from the marital property.[1]Â  
After the hearing, the family court found the marital property of the parties consisted of the marital home, a small rental property, a mobile home, forty-six acres of property, a daycare business and accompanying real estate, and the proceeds of a sale of additional rental property.Â  The family court valued the assets as follows: the marital home, mobile home, and forty-six acres at $300,000; the rental property at $20,000; the daycare business and property at $200,000; and the proceeds from the sale of rental property at $31,965.39.Â  The real estate of the parties was found to be encumbered by a mortgage of $418,000.Â  Thus, the total value of the marital estate was found to be $133,965.39.Â  The family court then divided the marital property equally between Husband and Wife with each receiving a distribution equaling $66,982.70.[2]Â  
Wife received the marital real estate and daycare business, along with the $418,000 mortgage.Â  The family court, however, reduced Husbandâ€™s share of the marital property by $48,453.47, which accounted for an $18,000 child support arrearage and $30,453.47 in delinquent taxes Husband owed Greenville County.Â  After these offsets, Husbandâ€™s equitable distribution was reduced to $18,529.23, which the family court ordered be placed in escrow to be used for the removal of hazardous waste left on the property by Husband.Â  No post trial motions were filed.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, the appellate court has the authority to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 532, 615 S.E.2d 98 (2005).Â  In spite of this broad scope of review, we remain mindful that the family court judge saw and heard the witnesses and generally is in a better position to determine credibility.Â  Id. Â Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Husband argues the family court erred in valuing the marital property.Â  Specifically, he argues section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) applies to valuation of marital property, and because the family court did not use the fifteen factors to value the property, the court erred in valuing the marital home, forty-six acres, and the daycare.Â  We disagree.Â  

Section 20-7-472 provides in part:
  
In a proceeding for divorce a vinculo matrimonii or separate support and maintenance . . . and in other marital litigation between the parties, the court shall make a final equitable apportionment between the parties of the partiesâ€™ marital property upon request by either party in the pleadings.Â  In making apportionment, the court must give weight in such proportion as it finds appropriate to all of the following factors . . . .
  

(emphasis added).Â  It is evident from the language of section 20-7-472 itself that the factors apply to the apportionment of marital property not the valuation of the property.Â  Furthermore, in Husbandâ€™s brief he does not cite any authority for his proposition that this section applies to valuation of marital property.
In making an equitable distribution of marital property, the family court must identify real and personal
marital property and determine the propertyâ€™s fair market value. Â Cannon v. Cannon, 321 S.C. 44, 48, 467 S.E.2d 132, 134 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œIn the absence of contrary evidence, the court should accept the
value the parties assign to a marital asset.â€Â  Id.Â  Moreover, in South Carolina, a property owner is competent to offer testimony as to the value of his property.Â  Cooper v. Cooper, 289 S.C. 377, 379, 346 S.E.2d 326, 327 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  â€œA family court may accept the valuation of one party over another, and the courtâ€™s valuation of
marital property will be affirmed if it is within the range of evidence presented.â€ Â Woodward v. Woodward, 294 S.C. 210, 215, 363 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 1987).
In this matter, Wife specifically testified, as she was qualified to do as owner of the property, that the marital home and forty-six acres had a value of $300,000, and the daycare had a value of $200,000.Â  While Husband provided other values for the business, the value accepted by the family court was within the range presented at trial.Â  Accordingly, the family court did not err in valuing the marital property.
Husband next argues the family court erred in effecting the equitable distribution.[3]Â  He claims his portion of the award should have totaled â€œat the minimum a distribution in kind or proceeds after a sale of $400,000.â€Â  Specifically, he contends the family court erred in the division because it improperly valued the marital assets and offset his equitable distribution share by the $18,000 outstanding child support, the $31,965.39 in unpaid taxes, and the $18,529.23 to remove the hazardous waste from the property.Â  However, we note that Husband never raised the issue of the offset of child support, unpaid taxes, or the cleaning fee to the family court by way of a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion.Â  Therefore, the issue is not preserved for our review.Â  See Washington v. Washington, 308 S.C. 549, 551, 419 S.E.2d 779, 781 (1992) (holding when an appellant neither raises an issue at trial nor through a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion, the issue is not preserved for appellate review.)Â  Â Â Â 
Lastly, Husband argues the family court erred in awarding Wife alimony.Â  Husband essentially argues there was no factual basis to support an award of alimony.Â  We disagree.
An award of alimony rests within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion. Â Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 282, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002).Â  â€œIt is the duty of the family court to make an alimony award that is fit, equitable, and just if the claim is well founded.â€ Â Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 184, 554 S.E.2d 421, 424 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The family court is required to consider all relevant factors in determining alimony. Â Patel v. Patel, 347 S.C. 281, 290, 555 S.E.2d 386, 391 (2001); Epperly v. Epperly, 312 S.C. 411, 415, 440 S.E.2d 884, 886 (Ct. App. 1994).
The record reflects that the family court considered the relevant statutory factors in awarding alimony to Wife.Â  In making the award of alimony to Wife, the family court properly considered the income levels of the parties, the duration of the marriage, the fault of Husband, the standard of living established during the marriage, and the financial ability of Husband to pay support.Â  At the hearing, Wife specifically testified to Husbandâ€™s income, his marital misconduct, the length of the marriage, and the standard of living the parties enjoyed during the marriage.[4]Â  Therefore, the family court did not abuse its discretion in awarding alimony to Wife.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the order of the family court is hereby
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] Â The parties had three children, only one of which was a minor at the time of the divorce.Â  Neither custody nor child support is at issue in this appeal.
[2] Â Husband was not present at the hearing but was represented by counsel.Â  
[3] Â Husband agrees the fifty-fifty split is proper.Â  He merely challenges the impact the offsets had on his portion of the distribution.
[4] Â Husband presented no evidence to counter Wifeâ€™s testimony regarding these issues.Â  In fact, Husband failed to even file a financial declaration with the family court as required by the family court rules.Â  Therefore, he cannot now complain that the family court improperly relied on Wifeâ€™s testimony in awarding alimony.Â  See, e.g., Hough v. Hough, 312 S.C. 344, 347, 440 S.E.2d 387, 390 (Ct. App. 1994) (stating the appellant has the burden â€œto show the family court committed reversible error and a
party cannot sit back at trial without offering proof, then come to the appellate court complaining of the insufficiency of
evidence to support the family courtâ€™s findingsâ€). Â Â

title: State v. Jamison
description: Torrey L. Jamison appeals his convictions for trafficking cocaine, trafficking crack cocaine, resisting arrest, failure to stop for a blue light, and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.  He argues the trial court abused its discretion by allowing the State to present expert testimony about the dollar value of cocaine and crack cocaine.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Torrey L. Jamison, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â D. Garrison Hill, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4229
Submitted March 1, 2007 â€“ Filed April 2, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.: Â Torrey L. Jamison appeals his convictions for trafficking cocaine, trafficking crack cocaine, resisting arrest, failure to stop for a blue light, and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On the night of January 6, 2004, the Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s Office dispatched Deputy Andrew Wall to investigate a suspicious vehicle parked in the middle of a dead-end road located in a cul-de-sac.Â  He found the vehicle, a Chevrolet pickup truck, parked without any lights on. Â Wall shone his patrol vehicleâ€™s exterior spotlight into the truck as he was driving by, did not see anyone inside, and believed the truck was abandoned.Â  He positioned his patrol car behind the truck and called in the truckâ€™s license plate to his dispatcher.
While waiting for the dispatcher to respond, Wall saw an individual, later identified as Jamison, suddenly sit up in the driverâ€™s seat of the truck.Â  Jamison immediately put the truck into motion and began driving away.Â  Wall turned on his blue lights and pursued the truck.Â  The truck stopped several times during the chase, but never long enough for Wall to approach the truck on foot.Â  Wall radioed for backup; Deputy John Little and Deputy Tasha Cox quickly joined the pursuit.
Once the truck stopped long enough for the deputies to approach, Wall and Cox advanced toward the vehicle on foot.Â  Wall ordered Jamison to exit the vehicle and he slowly complied.Â  The deputies searched Jamison and placed him into one of the patrol vehicles.Â  Upon searching Jamisonâ€™s truck, the deputies discovered a loaded .45 caliber pistol and a bag from a fast-food restaurant containing four, clear plastic bags with drugs inside.Â  Two of the four bags contained cocaine and the other two contained crack cocaine.Â  Altogether the bags contained 54.77 grams of cocaine and 19.21 grams of crack cocaine.
The Greenville County Grand Jury indicted Jamison for trafficking cocaine, trafficking crack cocaine, resisting arrest, failure to stop for a blue light, and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  A jury found Jamison guilty on all charges and the trial court sentenced him to concurrent terms of confinement totaling ten years plus three years probation.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Jamison argues the trial court abused its discretion by allowing the State to present expert testimony about the dollar value of cocaine and crack cocaine.Â  We disagree.
The qualification of a witness as an expert and the admissibility of his or her testimony are matters left to the sound discretion of the trial judge, whose decision will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion and prejudice to the opposing party.Â  Nelson v. Taylor, 347 S.C. 210, 214, 553 S.E.2d 488, 490 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the conclusions of the trial court either lack evidentiary support or are controlled by an error of law.Â  State v. Wise, 359 S.C. 14, 21, 596 S.E.2d 475, 478 (2004).
During Jamisonâ€™s trial, the State sought to call Investigator Keith Grounsell of the Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s Office as an expert on the street value of cocaine and crack cocaine.Â  Jamison objected, arguing testimony about the value of cocaine and crack cocaine was irrelevant and prejudicial because there was no evidence he committed or attempted a drug transaction.Â  The trial court allowed Grounsell to testify as an expert, but limited his testimony to the â€œwholesaleâ€ and â€œretailâ€ values of cocaine and crack cocaine for the general area.
The trial court allowed Grounsellâ€™s testimony based on several cases from the United States Court of Appeals,
Fourth Circuit.Â  The trial court reasoned that jurors typically do not have knowledge about the illegal drug industry.[2]Â  Grounsell testified that the drugs found in Jamisonâ€™s truck had a street value of between $2,750.00 and $9,319.00, depending on the quantities sold.
In his defense, Jamison claimed the drugs belonged to someone else, possibly one of his employees who also had access to the truck.
We agree with the trial court that jurors typically do not know the current street prices of illegal drugs.Â  Grounsellâ€™s valuation of the drugs, based on his years of law enforcement experience, allowed the jury to better determine whether a person would reasonably leave expensive narcotics unguarded and disguised as trash in a truck allegedly used by numerous people.
If the jury did not believe Jamisonâ€™s assertion that an unknown individual left thousands of dollars worth of drugs disguised as garbage in an area where other people had access to the drugs and might even throw them away, it reinforced the Stateâ€™s case that Jamison was knowingly in actual or constructive possession of the drugs at the time of his arrest, a key element of the trafficking charges.Â  We therefore hold the trial court did not err by allowing Grounsell to testify about the street value of the drugs found in Jamisonâ€™s truck.[3]

    AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and STILWELL, J., concur.

[1] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  See, e.g., U.S. v. Gastiaburo, 16 F.3d 582, 589 (4th Cir. 1994) (noting the court has â€œrepeatedly upheld the admission of law enforcement officersâ€™ expert opinion testimony in drug trafficking cases.â€); U.S. v. Johnson, 54 F.3d 1150, 1156-57 (4th Cir. 1995) (holding the district court did not err in qualifying a detective as an expert and allowing the detective to testify about the current street price of illegal drugs).
[3]Â  See State v. Matthews, 720 So. 2d 153 (La. Ct. App. 1998) (holding an agent from the Drug Enforcement Agency could testify regarding the street value of cocaine where the agent was testifying regarding matters within his personal knowledge and experience as a narcotics officer); State v. McCoy, 414 S.E.2d 392, 395 (N.C. Ct. App. 1992) (ruling a law enforcement officerâ€™s testimony on the street value of cocaine was properly admitted in defendantâ€™s trial for trafficking cocaine because the testimony was both helpful and relevant in showing the defendantâ€™s intent); Martin v. State, 823 S.W.2d 726, 728 (Tex. Crim. App. 1992) (ruling a sheriffâ€™s testimony on the price of marijuana was admissible and relevant because it allowed the jury to comprehend the quantity of illegal drugs recovered in terms that are easily understood); cf. State v. Lawrence, 264 S.C. 3, 16, 212 S.E.2d 52, 58 (1975) (ruling that testimony as to the black market resale value of prescription drugs when sold without a prescription was relevant to prove motive for the charge of conspiracy).

description: William White Rutledge appeals his conviction for simple possession of marijuana, first offense, arguing the trial court erred in ruling that a search warrant was sufficient to establish probable cause,  and in determining that the affidavit in support of the warrant was valid.  We affirm.
text:
State v. Rutledge


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
State of South Carolina, Respondent,
v.
William White Rutledge, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from York County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge 

Opinion No. 4230
Heard March 6, 2007 â€“ Filed April 9, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Daniel D. Dâ€™Agostino, of York, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliot, Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Thomas E. Pope, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  William White Rutledge appeals his conviction for simple possession of marijuana, first offense, arguing the trial court erred in ruling that the search warrant was sufficient to establish probable cause, and in determining that the affidavit in support of the warrant was valid.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
This case began when narcotics officers from the Rock Hill Police Department assigned to the York County Multi-Jurisdictional Drug Enforcement Unit received an anonymous tip through Crime Stoppers regarding drug activity at 162 Bailey Avenue in Rock Hill.Â  The anonymous informant stated that Rutledge and two other men were selling marijuana at that address.Â  Based on the tip, the officers checked the electric company records and determined that the electricity at that address was registered in Rutledgeâ€™s name.Â  The officers also checked Rutledgeâ€™s criminal history and discovered he had two prior convictions for simple possession of marijuana in 1990 and 1991.Â  The officers conducted surveillance for several days at the address, but did not see any activity at the residence.Â  The officers then conducted a â€œtrash pullâ€ at the address.Â  The trash can was located at the curb in front of 162 Bailey Avenue, but not on the property itself.Â  The officers found marijuana seeds and stalks inside, about midway down the trash can.Â  
Based on this information the officers went to the magistrate seeking a search warrant for the residence.Â  The affidavit supporting the search warrant stated, in pertinent part:Â  

The affiant, who is a certified Law Enforcement officer assigned to the York County Multi-Jurisdictional Drug Enforcement Unit and has several years law enforcement experience, to include narcotics investigations, states the following facts to support probable cause to search the premises within the curtilage of the property listed within:
The affiant has received information that William Rutledge and two other subjects only known as Steve and Richie are selling marijuana from 162 Bailey Ave., Rock Hill, South Carolina.
Within the past 72 hours officers of the YCMDEU conducted a narcotics investigation focused on 162 Bailey Ave., Rock Hill, SC.Â  As a result of this investigation, officers recovered marijuana, marijuana seeds and marijuana stalks from 162 Bailey Ave.Â  A Criminal Records check of William Rutledge found that Rutledge has prior convictions for marijuana.Â  Officers of the YCMDEU confirmed through Rock Hill Utilities that William Rutledge is drawing power at 162 Bailey Ave.
Based on the affiantâ€™s training and experience in narcotics investigations, it is believed that drug dealers keep contraband, proceeds of drug sales and records of drug transactions that may include written records, photographs, video tapes, audio tapes, computer hard drives and disks within secure locations of their residences and out buildings within the curtilage of their property.Â  See oral testimony.

In addition, the following oral testimony was provided with the affidavit:

On July 21, 2005 Officer Cantey of the York County Multi Jurisdictional Drug Enforcement Unit conducted a narcotics investigation focused on the illegal drug activities occurring at 162 Bailey Ave., Rock Hill, County of York, South Carolina.Â  During the investigation the trash from the residence was located in front of the residence.Â  The trash was located off the property and sat out for normal pick-up.Â  This date is the regularly scheduled day for the garbage collection from the residence.Â  During the investigation, marijuana was recovered from the trash of the residence.

Based on this information, the magistrate issued the search warrant.Â  
When they executed the search warrant, officers found marijuana on the kitchen counter.Â  Rutledge acknowledged to the officers that the marijuana was his, and told the officers that there was also a marijuana plant in the house that belonged to him.Â  The officers found the plant inside what the officer described as â€œa hydroponics marijuana growerâ€ in Rutledgeâ€™s bedroom.Â  
After a bench trial, Rutledge was convicted of simple possession of marijuana, first offense, and sentenced to thirty days incarceration or to pay a fine of $100 plus court costs and assessments, for a total of $432.50.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An appellate court reviewing the decision to issue a search warrant should decide whether the magistrate had a substantial basis for concluding that probable cause existed.Â  State v. Philpot, 317 S.C. 458, 461, 454 S.E.2d 905, 907 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  A reviewing court should give great deference to a magistrateâ€™s determination of probable cause.Â  State v. Davis, 354 S.C. 348, 355, 580 S.E.2d 778, 782 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW / ANALYSIS
Rutledge argues the circuit court erred in determining that the affidavit was sufficient to demonstrate probable cause, and in failing to determine that the search warrant was misleading and therefore invalid. Â We disagree.Â  
A search warrant may issue only upon a finding of probable cause.Â  State v. Bellamy, 336 S.C. 140, 143, 519 S.E.2d 347, 348 (1999).Â  Search warrants may be issued â€œonly upon affidavit sworn before the magistrate . . . establishing the grounds for the warrant.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-13-140 (1985).Â  Oral testimony may be used to supplement search warrant affidavits.Â  State v. Jones, 342 S.C. 121, 128, 536 S.E.2d 675, 678-79 (2000).Â  The magistrateâ€™s task in determiningÂ  whether to issue the search warrant is to make a practical, common-sense decision whether, given all the circumstances set forth in the affidavit before him, there is a fair probability that contraband or evidence of a crime will be found in a particular place.Â  State v. Dunbar, 361 S.C. 240, 246, 603 S.E.2d 615, 618 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
I.  Insufficiency Argument
Rutledge first argues that the affidavit was insufficient to demonstrate probable cause. Specifically, he argues that the affidavit fails to detail the â€œinvestigationâ€ referred to, to mention that the trash can where the marijuana was found was in the public domain and not on the property of the residence, and because the confidential informantâ€™s reliability was not established. We disagree.
The affidavit stated that the officers had â€œreceived information that William Rutledge and two other subjects only known as Steve and Richie are selling marijuana from 162 Bailey Ave., Rock Hill, South Carolina.â€Â  This tip provided the specific crime being committed, the names of the people involved in the crime, and the specific location where the activity was occurring. See Bellamy, 336 S.C. at 144, 519 S.E.2d at 349 (noting that specificity of information provided by a confidential informant indicates greater reliability).Â  Because an anonymous informant is correct about some facts, that informant is more likely correct about other facts, including illegal activity.Â 
Illinois v. Gates, 462 U.S. 213, 244 (1983).
Rutledge cites State v. Coin Operated Video Games Machines, 338 S.C. 176, 525 S.E.2d 872 (2000), to attack the reliability of the confidential informantâ€™s tip.Â  This case holds that a warrant based solely on information provided by a confidential informant must contain information supporting the credibility of the informant and the basis of his knowledge.Â  Id.Â  However, the warrant in this case was not based solely on the tip from the confidential informant.Â  The marijuana the officers found in the trash can in front of the residence, and Rutledgeâ€™s prior convictions for marijuana serve as additional evidence of a crime, while along with the electric bill registered in Rutledgeâ€™s name, also substantiating the credibility of the informant and the veracity of his statements.Â  See Bellamy, 336 S.C. at 144-45, 519 S.E.2d at 349 (finding confirmation of the reliability of an informantâ€™s information, which detailed the caliber and/or make of three guns, when the information correlated with 3 of 20 guns that had been stolen from a police station).
Given all the circumstances in the affidavit and the supporting oral testimony, including the informantâ€™s information, the electric bill in Rutledgeâ€™s name, Rutledgeâ€™s prior convictions, and the marijuana found in the trash can in front of the residence, we conclude that the magistrate had substantial basis for concluding that probable cause existed to issue a search warrant of the residence.Â  Accordingly, we find the affidavit was sufficient.
II.  Misleading Argument
Rutledge next argues that the affidavit was misleading, demonstrating a reckless disregard for the truth, because it overstates the evidence the officers had of any ongoing illegal activity.Â  Specifically, he argues that the affidavit should have disclosed the lack of independent evidence of ongoing illegal activities at the residence, should have indicated that the marijuana, seeds, and stalks were discovered in a trash can off the property, and that Rutledgeâ€™s prior convictions were in 1990 and 1991.Â  He thus requests that the alleged distorted facts in the affidavit be disregarded pursuant to Franks v. Delaware, 438 U.S. 154 (1978), in considering the affidavitâ€™s sufficiency to demonstrate probable cause.Â  We disagree.
There is a presumption of validity with respect to the affidavit supporting the search warrant. Â Id. at 171.Â  Rutledge contends first that the affidavit incorrectly informed the magistrate that illegal activities at the residence were ongoing.Â  However, the anonymous tip and the marijuana found in the trash can within seventy-two hours of the affidavitâ€™s submission support such a contention.Â  
Rutledge next contends the affidavit improperly implied that the officers recovered the marijuana, seeds, and stalks from the residence itself.Â  But, the affidavit merely states, â€œ[O]fficers recovered marijuana, marijuana seeds, and marijuana stalks from 162 Bailey Avenue.â€Â  Nowhere does the affidavit say it was found in the house.Â  Further, the affiantâ€™s oral testimony stated exactly how and where the officers found the trash can and the marijuana.Â  These statements do not constitute a reckless disregard for the truth.
Finally, Rutledge argues that the officers improperly left out the dates and severity of Rutledgeâ€™s marijuana convictions.Â  However, the exculpatory value of that information is dubious.Â  Rutledge contends that the omission of that information left the magistrate with the impression that Rutledge was involved with illegal narcotics.Â  But the inclusion of the specific date and type of conviction could still allow that impression.Â  Further, there is no Franks violation if the affidavit, including the omitted exculpatory information, still contains sufficient evidence to establish probable cause.Â  Id. Â Had the affidavit noted the dates of Rutledgeâ€™s prior marijuana convictions, the substantial basis for probable cause would not be diminished, because any doubt as to current illegal activities at the residence would be obviated by the recent informantâ€™s tip and discovery of marijuana outside the residence.Â  Therefore, we find nothing in the affidavit demonstrates a reckless disregard for the truth.
CONCLUSION Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Based on the foregoing, Rutledgeâ€™s conviction for simple possession of marijuana, first offense, is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.
