title: Stearns Bank National Association v. Glenwood Falls
description: We hold the master did not abuse his discretion in refusing to set aside a default judgment; appellant made a voluntary appearance, and the judgment was not procured through excusable neglect, as appellant's attorneys did not willfully abandon appellant.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Stearns Bank National Association, Plaintiff,
v.
Glenwood Falls, LP, a South Carolina limited partnership; DC Development, Inc.; McBride Building Supplies & Hardware, Inc.; First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Charleston; Charleston Affordable Housing, Inc.; and the Building Center, Inc.,
Defendants,
Of whom DC Development, Inc., is the Respondent,
v.
and Glenwood Falls, LP, a South Carolina limited partnership, is the
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from York County
Â S. Jackson Kimball, III, Master-in Equity

Opinion No. 4231
Heard March 6, 2007 â€“ Filed April 9, 2007Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael W. Tighe and Mary Dameron Milliken, of Columbia, for Appellant.
William E. Booth, III, of West Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  Glenwood Falls, LP, appeals the masterâ€™s order denying its motion to set aside a default judgment.Â  We affirm.Â  
I.
Glenwood Falls is a South Carolina limited partnership.Â  Glenwood Falls hired DC Development, a South Carolina corporation, to construct apartments on real property Glenwood Falls owned in York County.Â  To fund this project, Glenwood Falls obtained a $1.8 million mortgage from Stearns Bank. 
On January 30, 2004, Stearns Bank brought a foreclosure action against Glenwood Falls, DC Development, and Charleston Affordable Housing (â€œAffordable Housingâ€).Â  Affordable Housing, a South Carolina non-profit corporation, is one of Glenwood Fallsâ€™ general partners.Â  On March 15, 2004, DC Development answered and filed a cross-claim against Glenwood Falls, seeking to foreclose a mechanicâ€™s lien on the property and asserting causes of action for breach of contract, unjust enrichment, and quantum meruit.Â  DC Developmentâ€™s attorney, William Booth, mailed the cross-claim via certified mail to Glenwood Fallsâ€™ registered agent, Cathy Kleiman, but Kleiman did not sign the return receipt.Â  Instead, an unauthorized person signed it.Â  
Kleiman nevertheless received the cross-claim and, on May 13, 2004, forwarded it to Robert Nettles, an attorney she believed represented Glenwood Falls.Â  Over the next several months, Kleiman attempted to contact Nettles multiple times to ascertain the status of the cross-claim, but Nettles did not respond.Â  The record does not establish that Nettles was ever retained to represent Glenwood Falls in this matter.Â  
On June 17, 2004, the master issued a foreclosure order, but retained jurisdiction to hear the cross-claim.Â  On July 28, 2004, DC Developmentâ€™s attorney, Booth, purportedly received a phone message from Affordable Housingâ€™s attorney, Frank Cisa, regarding Cisaâ€™s representation of Glenwood Falls.Â  On November 8, 2004, Booth wrote Cisa the following:

I represent DC Development, Inc. and I believe you represent Glenwood Falls, LP and Charleston Affordable Housing, Inc.Â  I have scheduled the trial of a Cross-Claim of DC Development, Inc. against Glenwood Falls, LP.Â  The trial is scheduled for December 16, 2004, at 1:30 PM in the office of the Master in Equity for York County. 

Cisa replied the next day (â€œthe November 9 letterâ€).Â  He wrote:

I do represent Charleston Affordable Housing, Inc. and I am now taking over the representation of Glenwood Falls, LP.Â  What I gather from you[r] letter is that no Answer was filed on behalf of Glenwood Falls, LP to the Cross-Claim of DC Development, Inc.Â  If that is the case, it was caused by the failure of the original attorney for Glenwood Falls, LP to respond.Â  In any event, for DC Development, Inc. to recover any money in this action, my opinion is that Glenwood Falls, LP needs to assert a claim over and against the architects and engineers who designed this project.Â  Glenwood Falls, LP has no assets . . . .

On December 16, 2004, the master heard DC Developmentâ€™s cross-claim against Glenwood Falls, as Booth mentioned in his letter to Cisa.Â  Cisa, however, did not appear on Glenwood Fallsâ€™ behalf.Â  That same day, Booth filed an affidavit of default.Â  On January 5, 2005, the master entered a default judgment of $1.3 million against Glenwood Falls.Â  
In April 2005, Glenwood Falls moved to set aside the default judgment.Â  Glenwood Falls argued (1) the judgment was void because the court did not have personal jurisdiction over Glenwood Falls as a result of DC Developmentâ€™s failure to properly serve Glenwood Falls, and (2) the judgment was procured through excusable neglect.Â  The master denied Glenwood Fallsâ€™ motion.Â  The master found (1) the court had personal jurisdiction over Glenwood Falls, despite DC Developmentâ€™s failure to serve Glenwood Falls properly, because Glenwood Falls made a voluntary appearance, which waived its right to contest personal jurisdiction, and (2) the judgment was not procured through excusable neglect.Â  Glenwood Falls appeals. 
II.
The decision to grant or deny a motion for relief from judgment lies within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  BB&T v. Taylor, 369 S.C. 548, 551, 633 S.E.2d 501, 502-03 (2006).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion arises where the judge issuing the order was controlled by an error of law or where the order is based on factual conclusions that are without evidentiary support.â€Â  Id. at 551, 633 S.E.2d at 503.Â  
III.
Glenwood Falls argues the master erred in denying its motion to set aside a default judgment because (1) the judgment was void, as Glenwood Falls was not properly served and did not make a voluntary appearance, and (2) the judgment was procured through excusable neglect, as Glenwood Fallsâ€™ attorneys abandoned it.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the denial of Glenwood Fallsâ€™ motion for relief from default judgment.[1]  
A. Â Â Â Â  Voluntary Appearance 
Glenwood Falls contends the judgment was void as a result of DC Developmentâ€™s improper service, and the master erred in finding Glenwood Falls made a voluntary appearance.Â  We disagree. 
A court may set aside a default judgment in accordance with Rule 60(b), SCRCP.Â  See Rule 55(c), SCRCP.Â  Rule 60(b)(4) provides: â€œOn motion and upon such terms as are just, the court may relieve a
party or his legal representative from a final judgment . . . [if] the judgment is void . . . .â€Â  â€œA judgment is void if a court acts without personal jurisdiction.â€Â  BB&T v. Taylor, 369 S.C. 548, 551, 633 S.E.2d 501, 503 (2006). 
A court usually obtains personal jurisdiction by the service of the summons and complaint.Â  To serve a partnership, a copy of the summons and complaint must be delivered to â€œan officer, a managing or general agent, or to any other agent authorized by appointment or by law to receive service of process,â€ or sent by â€œregistered or certified mail, return receipt requested and delivery restricted to the addressee.â€Â  Rule 4(d)(3) & (8), SCRCP.Â  Although a court commonly obtains personal jurisdiction by the service of the summons and complaint, it may also obtain personal jurisdiction if the defendant makes a voluntary appearance.Â  Rule 4(d) (â€œVoluntary appearance by defendant is equivalent to personal service.â€).[2]Â Â  
As the master found, and neither party contests, DC Development did not properly serve Glenwood Falls under Rule 4(d)(8), because an unauthorized person signed the return receipt.Â  Normally, this would be a suitable ground to grant relief from judgment under Rule 60(b)(4).Â  See Rule 4(d)(8) (â€œAny such default or judgment by default shall be set aside pursuant to Rule 55(c) or Rule 60(b) if the defendant demonstrates to the court that the return receipt was signed by an unauthorized person.â€).Â  But the master did not set aside the default judgment under Rule 60(b)(4) because he found Glenwood Falls made a voluntary appearance, which under Rule 4(d) is â€œequivalent to personal service.â€Â  Thus, the master concluded the court had personal jurisdiction over Glenwood Falls.Â  
The critical issue, therefore, is whether the master erred in finding Glenwood Falls made a voluntary appearance.Â  â€œThe term â€˜appearanceâ€™ is used particularly to signify or designate the overt act by which one against whom suit has been commenced submits himself to the courtâ€™s jurisdiction.â€Â  4 Am. Jur. 2d Appearance Â§ 1 (1995).Â  â€œAn appearance may be expressly made by formal written or oral declaration, or record entry, or it may be implied from some act done with the intention of appearing and submitting to the courtâ€™s jurisdiction.â€Â  Id.Â  No specific act constitutes an appearance, as â€œa defendant may choose to come into court with trumpets, or quietly by the back door.â€Â  Stephens v. Ringling, 102 S.C. 333, 342, 86 S.E. 683, 685 (1915).Â  Accordingly, courts decide on a case by case basis whether a defendantâ€™s act demonstrates an intent to submit to the courtâ€™s jurisdiction.Â  
Here, the master found the November 9 letter from Glenwood Fallsâ€™ attorney, Cisa, to DC Developmentâ€™s attorney demonstrated an intent to submit to the courtâ€™s jurisdiction and, therefore, constituted a voluntary appearance.Â  The master cited Petty v. Weyerhaeuser Company, 272 S.C. 282, 251 S.E.2d 735 (1979), for the proposition that a letter from one attorney to another may constitute a voluntary appearance.Â  Glenwood Falls argues Petty is distinguishable from this case.Â  
In Petty, plaintiffâ€™s counsel sent the summons and complaint to defense counsel in Tacoma, Washington.Â  A few weeks later, defense counsel called plaintiffâ€™s counsel to request an extension of time to answer the complaint, which plaintiffâ€™s counsel granted.Â  Defense counsel memorialized this exchange in a letter to plaintiffâ€™s counsel, which read: â€œConfirming our telephone conversation of February 27, please consider this letter as an informal notice of appearance on behalf of [the defendant] in the suit you recently instituted . . . .â€Â  Id. at 284, 251 S.E.2d at 736.Â  The letter also stated the defendant would like to â€œexplore settlement possibilities prior to retaining counsel in South Carolina for formal appearance, answer and defense or settlement by local counsel.â€Â  Id.Â  When, after numerous attempts, plaintiffâ€™s counsel could not reach defense counsel to discuss settlement possibilities, plaintiffâ€™s counsel filed an affidavit of default, and an order of default was issued.Â  Defense counsel moved to set aside the order of default, arguing the court did not have personal jurisdiction over the defendant because the plaintiff improperly served it.Â  The trial court found service was proper and, even if service were improper, the defendant made a voluntary appearance.Â  Our supreme court found service was improper, but nevertheless held the defendant made a voluntary appearance.
Glenwood Falls asserts Petty is distinguishable from this case because (1) in Petty defense counsel acknowledged the summons and complaint, but in this case Cisa did not acknowledge the cross-claim; and (2) in Petty defense counsel expressly stated the letter should be considered an appearance, but in this case Cisa did not expressly state the November 9 letter should be considered an appearance.Â  
Glenwood Fallsâ€™ attempt to distinguish Petty is unpersuasive.Â  First, Cisa does acknowledge DC Developmentâ€™s cross-claim.Â  In the November 9 letter to Booth, Cisa writes, â€œWhat I gather from you[r] letter is that no Answer was filed on behalf of Glenwood Falls, LP to the Cross-Claim of DC Development, Inc.â€ (emphasis added).[3]Â  Clearly, then, Cisa recognized DC Developmentâ€™s cross-claim against Glenwood Falls.
Second, the mere fact that Cisa did not mention the word â€œappearanceâ€ in the November 9 letter does not mean Glenwood Falls failed to make an appearance.Â  Again, the inquiry is whether Glenwood Fallsâ€™ conduct demonstrated an intent to submit to the courtâ€™s jurisdiction.Â  The inquiry is not whether Glenwood Falls invoked the term â€œappearance.â€[4]Â  On many occasions our supreme court has found that a party can make a voluntary appearance without formally announcing it.Â  See, e.g., Triangle Auto Spring Co. v. Gromlovitz, 270 S.C. 386, 389-90 n.1, 242 S.E.2d 430, 431 n.1 (1978) (holding that consenting to a confession of judgment constitutes a voluntary appearance); Connell v. Connell, 249 S.C. 162, 167, 153 S.E.2d 396, 399 (1967) (holding that raising the defense of res judicata constitutes a voluntary appearance); Se. Equip. Co. v. One 1954 Autocar Diesel Tractor, 234 S.C. 213, 218, 107 S.E.2d 340, 342 (1959) (holding that filing a motion to set aside an attachment constitutes a voluntary appearance).Â  
As the master correctly held that a letter from one attorney to another may serve as a basis to find a voluntary appearance, we now examine whether the master erred in finding that Glenwood Falls made a voluntary appearance.Â  We believe the November 9 letter manifests Glenwood Fallsâ€™ intent to submit to the jurisdiction of the court.Â  In the November 9 letter, Cisa not only announces his representation of Glenwood Falls without reservation but also expresses an intent to reach the merits of the case, especially when he writes â€œfor DC Development, Inc., to recover any money in this action, my opinion is that Glenwood Falls, LP needs to assert a claim over and against the architects and engineers who designed this project.â€Â  See Jenkinson v. Murrow Bros. Seed Co., 272 S.C. 148, 154, 249 S.E.2d 780, 783 (1978) (Ness, J., concurring) (â€œIn order to establish waiver of the right to contest jurisdiction, it is only necessary that a party, by its conduct, evince an intent to proceed to the merits of the case.â€).Â  Moreover, the November 9 letter contains not the slightest hint of a desire to challenge service of process.Â  Based on the record before us, we hold the master did not err in finding the November 9 letter was a voluntary appearance by Glenwood Falls.[5]
B. Â Â Â Â  Excusable Neglect 
Glenwood Falls contends the master erred in finding the judgment was not procured through excusable neglect because Glenwood Fallsâ€™ attorneys willfully abandoned it.Â  We disagree. 
A default judgment may be set aside on the grounds of mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect.Â  Rule 60(b)(1), SCRCP.Â  Relief from judgment is available upon a showing of excusable neglect and a meritorious defense; case law also directs the trial court to consider the presence or absence of prejudice to the party opposing the motion.Â  Mictronics, Inc. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Revenue, 345 S.C. 506, 510-11, 548 S.E.2d 223, 226 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œIn determining whether to grant a motion under Rule 60(b), the trial judge should consider: (1) the promptness with which relief is sought, (2) the reasons for the failure to act promptly, (3) the existence of a meritorious defense, and (4) the prejudice to the other party.â€).
In the case before us, because of our ultimate disposition, we need only address Glenwood Fallsâ€™ excusable neglect claim arising from the assertion of willful abandonment by its counsel.Â  Concerning a claim of attorney neglect, the general rule is that â€œthe neglect of the attorney is attributable to the client.â€Â  Graham v. Town of Loris, 272 S.C. 442, 451, 248 S.E.2d 594, 598 (1978).Â  In discussing this general rule, the Graham court quoted approvingly from Simon v. Flowers, 231 S.C. 545, 551, 99 S.E.2d 391, 394 (1957):

Although a wide discretion is vested in courts to set aside or vacate judgments because of the neglect, misconduct or inadvertence of counsel employed in the case, the general rule undoubtedly is that the neglect of the attorney is the neglect of the client, and that no mistake, inadvertence or neglect attributable to the attorney can be successfully used as a ground for relief, unless it would have been excusable if attributable to the client.Â  The acts and omissions of the attorney in such case are those of the client. 

However, â€œ[t]he rule that an attorneyâ€™s negligence may be imputed to his client and prevent the latter from relying on that ground for opening or vacating a judgment does not necessarily prevail in the event of the attorneyâ€™s abandonment or withdrawal from the case.â€Â  Graham, 272 S.C. at 452, 248 S.E.2d at 599 (citing 46 Am. Jur. 2d Judgments Â§ 737 (1969)).Â  To overcome the general rule that the neglect of the attorney is attributable to the client, the client must establish that its former attorney willfully and unilaterally abandoned it.Â  Id. at 452, 248 S.E.2d at 599; Paul Davis Sys. Inc. v. Deepwater of Hilton Head, LLC, 362 S.C. 220, 226, 607 S.E.2d 358, 361 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œThis is not a case of willful and unilateral abandonment of the client by counsel in which we could refuse to apply the general rule that the neglect of the attorney is the neglect of the client.â€).
Our law thus instructs that an exception to the general rule applies when the attorneyâ€™s inaction was the consequence of willful abandonment or withdrawal from the case.Â  Where an attorney is merely neglectful, the general rule applies and relief from judgment is unavailable; where an attorneyâ€™s conduct transcends mere neglect and the party seeking relief establishes willful abandonment or withdrawal from the case, relief from judgment is available.Â  
The facts in Graham are instructive.Â  The Town of Loris was represented by its city attorney.Â  The day before a summary judgment hearing the Town of Loris received a letter from the city attorney announcing his immediate resignation.Â  The city attorney did not inform any town official of the impending summary judgment hearing.Â  When no one appeared at the hearing on behalf of the Town of Loris, summary judgment was entered against it.Â  The trial court ultimately granted the Town of Loris relief from judgment, holding that the Town of Loris had no notice of the summary judgment hearing and that its attorney had resigned.Â  The supreme court affirmed, noting that â€œunder the rare circumstances of this case,â€ the Town of Loris â€œshould not be charged with the abandonment of the case by its counsel.â€Â  Graham, 272 S.C. at 452, 248 S.E.2d at 599.
In Simon, 231 S.C. 545, 99 S.E.2d 391, defense counsel failed to answer a complaint because he was involved in a multi-day trial.Â  As a result of defense counselâ€™s failure to answer the complaint, the court entered a default judgment against defendant.Â  On appeal, our supreme court was sympathetic to defense counselâ€™s plight but nevertheless adhered to the general rule and imputed the neglect of counsel to his client.Â  The court explained:

[T]he default was the result of forgetfulness on [the attorneyâ€™s] part which in turn was due to pressure of his business in the trial of cases . . . .Â  In the crowded routine of a busy lawyerâ€™s life a mistake such as the record here discloses is understandable; but it entails the penalty of default under strict enforcement of the rule of procedure, and the trial courtâ€™s refusal to forgive it affords no basis for reversal.

Id.Â  at 550-51, 99 S.E.2d at 394.Â  
We now turn to Glenwood Fallsâ€™ claims of excusable neglect in connection with attorneys Nettles and
Cisa.
1.  Nettles
Glenwood Falls argues Nettles willfully abandoned it.Â  We initially observe that it is doubtful whether Nettles actually represented Glenwood Falls in this litigation. Â In fact, Nettles wrote Kleiman and Cisa on June 24, 2004, and disavowed any representation of Glenwood Falls.Â  This uncertainty about Nettlesâ€™ purported representation of Glenwood Falls, standing alone, is enough to sustain the masterâ€™s ruling.
Moreover, under no circumstance has Glenwood Falls shown that it was prejudiced by Nettles alleged representation.Â  As the November 9 letter illustrates, Glenwood Falls arranged for Cisa to take over the representation of Glenwood Falls before default was entered. Â Therefore, Glenwood Falls, through Cisa, had ample time following the November 9 letter to take appropriate action to protect itself from default.Â  Glenwood Falls failed to do so.Â  Now, Glenwood Falls attempts to resurrect its alleged problems with Nettles in May, June, and July of 2004 to extricate itself from its failure to act to protect its interests in November and December of 2004.Â  This it cannot do.Â  We find the master did not abuse his discretion in denying Glenwood Falls relief based on the purported representation by Nettles. 
2.  Cisa
Glenwood Falls argues Cisa willfully abandoned it.[6]Â  Cisa began representing Glenwood Falls on November 9, 2004, at the latest.Â  Even if we assume that Cisaâ€™s failure to act between the November 9 letter and the default judgment was neglectful, we may not assume that Cisaâ€™s failure to act transcends mere neglect and rises to the level of willful abandonment or withdrawal from the case.Â  Resolution of the appeal concerning Cisa turns on this critical difference.Â Â  Â 
As noted, mere neglect invokes the general rule of imputing the neglect of the attorney to the client, while willful abandonment triggers the exception to the general rule and allows relief to the client.Â  This distinction may be best illustrated by reiterating the critical factual distinction between Simon and Graham.Â  In Simon, the attorney simply forgot to answer the complaint against his client, and the supreme court upheld the trial courtâ€™s denial of relief of judgment because the attorneyâ€™s conduct did not transcend mere neglect.Â  Simon, 231 S.C. at 550-51, 99 S.E.2d at 394.Â  In Graham, the moving party established that its attorney affirmatively withdrew by resigning on the eve of a summary judgment hearing leaving the client unaware of the imminent and dispositive motion hearing.Â  Our supreme court upheld the trial courtâ€™s decision to grant relief from judgment based on the fact that the attorney willfully abandoned his representation by resigning right before the summary judgment hearing.Â  Graham, 272 S.C. at 453, 248 S.E.2d at 599.Â  
This case is controlled by Simon, for evidence of willful abandonment is missing.Â  Thus, even if we assume Cisaâ€™s failure to act following the November 9 letter constituted neglect, the scant record before us does not permit the additional finding of willful abandonment, partly due to Glenwood Fallsâ€™ generic and nonspecific Rule 60(b) motion.Â  We, of course, decline to speculate in a manner that favors Glenwood Falls.Â  Therefore, Glenwood Falls has not established that Cisa willfully abandoned or withdrew from the case.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the masterâ€™s refusal to find excusable neglect.Â  
Consequently, we find no error in the masterâ€™s denial of Glenwood Fallsâ€™ Rule 60(b)(1) motion to set aside a default judgment for excusable neglect with respect to attorneys Nettles and Cisa.
IV.
We hold the master did not abuse his discretion in refusing to set aside the default judgment obtained by DC Development against Glenwood Falls.Â  The November 9 letter constitutes a voluntary appearance by Glenwood Falls, and the judgment was not procured through excusable neglect.Â  The masterâ€™s order is
 AFFIRMED.
 SHORT, J., concurs.
ANDERSON, J., dissents in a separate opinion. 
Â ANDERSON, J. (dissenting in a separate opinion):Â  Â I disagree with the majorityâ€™s reasoning and analysis.Â  In my view, the trial court erred in failing to set aside the default judgment on the basis of mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect.Â  Specifically, Glenwood is entitled to relief because its attorneys abandoned it.Â  I VOTE to REVERSE.
ABANDONMENT
Juridical writing in South Carolina articulates the general rule that the acts and omissions of an attorney are attributable to the client.Â  Hillman v. Pinion, 347 S.C. 253, 257, 554 S.E.2d 427, 429 (Ct. App. 2001); Simon v. Flowers, 231 S.C. 545, 99 S.E.2d 391, 394 (1957).Â  The exception to this rule is recognized in the seminal case, Graham v. Town of Loris, 272 S.C. 442, 248 S.E.2d 594 (1978).Â  Graham inculcates: 

Although a wide discretion is vested in courts to set aside or vacate judgments because of the neglect, misconduct or inadvertence of counsel employed in the case, the general rule undoubtedly is that the neglect of the attorney is the neglect of the client, and that no mistake, inadvertence or neglect attributable to an attorney can be successfully used as a ground for relief, unless it would have been excusable if attributable to the client.Â  The acts and omissions of the attorney in such case are those of the client.
However, under the facts of the present case, we are not merely considering neglect, inadvertence, or mistake of counsel.Â  We are concerned with a wilful and unilateral abandonment of the client by counsel.Â  There is authority for the proposition that the general rule is not applied to such a factual situation.Â  This exception to the general rule is expressed at 46 Am. Jur. 2d, Judgments, s 737 (1969) in the following language:
The rule that an attorneyâ€™s negligence may be imputed to his client and prevent the latter from relying on that ground for opening or vacating a judgment does not necessarily prevail in the event of the attorneyâ€™s abandonment or withdrawal from the case.

272 S.C. 442, 451-52, 248 S.E.2d 594, 599; accord Paul Davis Systems, Inc. v. Deepwater of Hilton Head, LLC, 362 S.C. 220, 226, 607 S.E.2d 358, 361 (Ct. App. 2004) (recognizing an exception to the general rule when the attorneyâ€™s conduct constitutes willful abandonment).Â  
The rule that the acts and omissions of an attorney are attributable to the client is not a hard and fast rule.Â  Brown v. Butler, 347 S.C. 259, 265, 554 S.E.2d 431, 434 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œRather, it is one that is â€˜to be applied rationally, with a fair recognition that justice to the litigants is always the polestar.â€™ â€ Id. (citing Graham, 272 S.C. at 452, 248 S.E.2d at 599).Â  
In Graham, our Supreme Court held â€œthe attorneyâ€™s action in withdrawing from this case at a crucial stage without reasonable notice to his client is one of willful abandonment.â€Â  272 S.C. at 452, 248 S.E.2d at 599.Â  â€œAn attorney who undertakes the conduct of an action impliedly stipulates to carry it to its termination and is not at liberty to abandon it without reasonable cause and reasonable notice.â€Â  Graham, 272 S.C. at 452-53, 248 S.E.2d at 599 (citing Perkins v. Sykes, 233 N.C. 147, 152, 63 S.E.2d 133, 137 (1951)); Floyd v. Kosko, 285 S.C. 390, 393, 329 S.E.2d 459, 460 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  When counsel withdraws from a case at a crucial stage in litigation without reasonable notice to his client, the â€œ[client] should not be charged with the abandonment of the case by its counsel.â€Â  Graham, 272 S.C. at 452-53, 248 S.E.2d at 599 (â€œConscience requires this Court to charge the attorney alone with his gross dereliction of duty and not to visit its consequences upon an innocent client.â€). 
The majority enunciates the position that any failure of counsel must be based upon assumptions.Â  The French phrase â€œpas du toutâ€[7] is efficacious.Â  Not only does the failure in this case transcend mere neglect, it rises to the level of abandonment.Â  
Kleinman believed Nettles to be Glenwoodâ€™s attorney when she forwarded DC Developmentâ€™s cross-complaint to him on May 13, 2004.Â  She persisted in attempting to contact Nettles, but he did not respond, nor did he file an answer to the cross-claim.Â  On June 24, 2004, in a letter to Kleinman and Cisa, Nettles disavowed representation of Glenwood.Â  In addition, Cisaâ€™s November 9, 2004 letter to counsel for DC Development indicated he was taking over Glenwoodâ€™s representation.Â  Cisa explained the reason no answer to DC Developmentâ€™s cross-claim had been filed was due to â€œthe failure of the original attorney for Glenwood Falls, LP to respond.â€Â  
It is commonly understood that a client may assume a lawyer who has previously represented him will continue to serve in that capacity.Â  When the attorney becomes aware the client is operating under that assumption, it is incumbent upon the attorney to immediately and clearly resolve any doubt about whether the attorney-client relationship still exists.Â  Delay in clarifying whether the representation continues risks exposing the client to prejudice, should the client mistakenly believe the attorney is acting to protect the clientâ€™s interests.Â  Although Nettles had the cross-complaint in his possession and had received multiple contacts from Kleinman, he nevertheless delayed nearly six weeks before addressing the attorney-client relationship.Â  During that time the cross-complaint should have been answered to avoid admission of the allegations therein.Â  Glenwood needed the advice of counsel on how to protect its interests.Â  Glenwood was unquestionably prejudiced by Nettlesâ€™ conduct.Â  
The etiology of the default position of Glenwood arises from the failure and inaction of Nettles.Â  The default position of Glenwood is concatenated from Nettles through Cisa.Â  On November 8, 2004, Cisa received DC Developmentâ€™s letter informing him of the December 16, 2004 trial date.Â  In acknowledgement of that letter, Cisa confirmed he was taking over Glenwoodâ€™s representation and indicated he intended to proceed on the merits of the case.Â  Cisa represented Glenwood on November 9, 2004, at the latest.Â  The majority agrees his conduct thereafter was neglectful.Â  
Recognizing the dissimilitude of the facts in Graham v. Town of Loris as juxtaposed to this record, the annunciation of the principles and doctrines of law in Graham command the same result in this case.Â  The attorney representing the Town of Loris resigned the day before a summary judgment hearing without notifying the town of his resignation.Â  When no one appeared at the summary judgment hearing the court granted summary judgment against the Town of Loris.Â  In this case, Cisa acknowledged he represented Glenwood, had notice of the December 16 trial, yet simply failed to appear at the trial.Â  Entry of default and the subsequent default judgment against Glenwood resulted from Cisaâ€™s abandonment.Â  His failure to appear at this critical stage in litigation without any notice to Glenwood was tantamount to unilateral and willful abandonment.Â  The rationale in Graham is equally applicable in this case:Â  â€œConscience requires this Court to charge the attorney alone with his gross dereliction of duty and not to visit its consequences upon an innocent client.â€ 
CONCLUSION
The opinion of the majority is infected with expository difficulty when juxtaposed to the precedent extant in South Carolina law on abandonment.Â  I VOTE to REVERSE.  

[1] The amended Rule 60(b), SCRCP, motion that is the basis of this appeal is generic and unspecific, leaving us to speculate as to the precise basis of the motion.Â  Beyond this, the record on appeal does not contain the transcript from the motion hearing.Â  Although we could affirm on issue preservation grounds alone, we elect to treat the issue as preserved, for we can reasonably discern the basis of the motion in the masterâ€™s order denying the motion.
[2] Although Rule 5(b), SCRCP, generally provides less stringent standards for serving pleadings subsequent to the original summons and complaint, Rule 5(a), SCRCP, requires service pursuant to Rule 4 when a party makes new or additional claims against another party that has been held in default for failure to appear.
[3] Glenwood Falls emphasizes in its brief to this court that the November 9 letter does not even mention the cross-claim.Â  Glenwood Falls writes Cisa â€œsimply stated that he was â€˜now taking over the representation of Glenwood Falls, LPâ€™ without even mentioning the Cross-Claim.â€ (emphasis added).Â  Glenwood Fallsâ€™ claim is not accurate, for the November 9 letter clearly addresses the cross-claim. 
[4] Glenwood Falls argues that because the November 9 letter did not formally announce Glenwood Fallsâ€™ intent to make an appearance, Glenwood Falls did not waive its right to contest personal jurisdiction.Â  Glenwood Falls cites Boland v. South Carolina Public Service Authority, 281 S.C. 293, 315 S.E.2d 143 (Ct. App. 1984), for the proposition that a letter from defense counsel to plaintiffâ€™s counsel does not constitute a voluntary appearance if the letter does not expressly invoke the term â€œappearance.â€Â  Boland does not create such a bright-line rule.Â  In Boland, this court upheld the trial courtâ€™s finding that the communication from defense counsel to plaintiffâ€™s counsel did not constitute an appearance.Â  That the communication did not use the term appearance was only one fact, among many, that was considered in the decision.Â  Other relevant factors included, for example, the timing and level of communication between the attorneys, as well as the fact that the defendantâ€™s â€œnext move in [the] lawsuit following [defense counselâ€™s] letter was to make a special appearance . . . .â€Â  Id. at 297, 315 S.E.2d at 146.Â  It is thus incorrect to suggest that the holding in Boland turned merely on the absence of the term â€œappearanceâ€ in the letter.Â Â  
[5] In light of this holding, we need not address whether Cisaâ€™s actions on behalf of Affordable Housing also constituted a voluntary appearance for Glenwood Falls. 
[6] We question whether this issue was part of Glenwood Fallsâ€™ Rule 60(b) motion.Â  Glenwood Fallsâ€™ Rule 60(b) motion is conclusory and while it is clear from the masterâ€™s order that the Rule 60(b) motion involved attorney Nettles, we are left to speculate about Cisa.Â  The master, for example, in his order denying Rule 60(b) relief focused on Nettles and observed, â€œThe only substantial reason posed for [Glenwood Fallsâ€™] failure to act promptly in this matter is alleged â€˜abandonmentâ€™ by its original attorney.â€Â  The master further noted that â€œGlenwood [Falls] asserts that its first counsel in this matter abandoned it . . . .â€Â  Although there is no substantive discussion about Cisa in the masterâ€™s order, the order does contain indirect references to â€œeither counselâ€ of Glenwood Falls and the â€œattorneysâ€ of Glenwood Falls.Â  While a close question is presented, we treat the claim against Cisa as preserved.
[7] This phrase means â€œnot soâ€ or â€œnot at allâ€.

title: State v. Ladson
description: We reverse and remand for a new trial because the reconstructed record does not permit meaningful appellate review.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Travis Anthony Ladson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Â Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4232
Heard March 6, 2007 â€“ Filed April 9, 2007Â Â Â 

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor David M. Pascoe, Jr., of Summerville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  Travis Anthony Ladson was convicted of first-degree burglary following a three-day trial.Â  Ladson was sentenced on November 10, 2004, to prison for a non-parolable term of twenty-five years.Â  Ladson timely appealed his conviction and sentence.Â  In accordance with standard procedure, Ladson promptly requested the transcript of the trial from the court reporter.Â  Approximately ten months later, in August of 2005, the court reporter finally disclosed that there was no record of the trial court proceedings.
Because of the complete absence of a transcript, Ladson moved this court to reverse the convictions and sentences and for a new trial.Â  Based on the Stateâ€™s assurance that the record could be easily reconstructed, a judge of this court denied Ladsonâ€™s motion and remanded the matter to the trial court to reconstruct the record.Â  More than a year after the trial, the trial judge convened a hearing with trial counsel in an effort to reconstruct the record.
We now have before us what the State contends is a reconstructed record of the trial court proceedings sufficient to permit appellate review.Â  Ladson contends the conclusory and summary nature of the purported record on appeal does not permit meaningful appellate review.Â  Because we find the reconstructed record insufficient for meaningful review of direct appeal issues, we reverse and remand for a new trial.
I.
On January 5, 2006, pursuant to this courtâ€™s order, the trial judge held a hearing to reconstruct the record for appeal.[1]Â  It was clear from the outset of this hearing that reconstructing the record from scratch, after such a substantial delay, would be an uphill struggle.Â  The State presented two affidavits from witnesses and â€œsummarizedâ€ the testimony of the other witnesses.Â  
The information provided by the State was conclusory. The State usually prefaced its recall of witness testimony with statements like â€œhis testimony generally would be,â€ â€œhe testified generally to the following,â€ and â€œthe next witness . . . will be by summation.â€Â  Ladson took issue with the Stateâ€™s summary reconstruction of the record.Â  The trial judge, noting that he no longer had his handwritten notes from the trial, typically would conclude with respect to a particular witness that the State presented â€œan accurate summation of the testimony,â€ or the Stateâ€™s general description was â€œa correct summation of the testimony,â€ or â€œthe summation presented by the State . . . [was] a correct statement.â€Â  
When the State concluded its summary of the testimony of one witness, the trial court concurred with the summary as â€œan accurate reflection of her testimony,â€ and further held that the witness was â€œqualified as an expert in her field, and . . . the court found her testimony to be credible.â€Â  The trial court then remarked, â€œI do not believe there was any question, at any point in time, as to the chain of evidence regarding these particular fingerprints.â€Â  The State corrected the trial court and noted that the witness was not qualified as an expert and further that Ladsonâ€™s trial counsel had preliminarily objected to the chain of custody. Â The trial court promptly agreed and explained the confusion by referring to another witness.
The State, too, had difficulty recalling the witnesses and the testimony.Â  For example, the State had completely forgotten about one witness, whose identity was determined only by reference to Ladsonâ€™s trial counselâ€™s notes.Â  As the Solicitor acknowledged, â€œthe final witness that I have to admit I discovered from [Ladsonâ€™s trial counselâ€™s] notes.â€Â  
There is even a dispute as to whether Ladson testified in his own defense.Â  Ladson claims he did not testify.Â  The trial court found otherwise, noting the â€œcourtâ€™s remembrance and recollection that the Defendant was not credible, and did not help himself in his testimony before the jury.â€ 
The trial court appeared equally confident that the jury returned its verdict the same day it began its deliberations: â€œMy only recollection is that, after the court answered [a question from the jury], that the jury came out relatively soon after that with a verdict.â€Â  When confronted with a different recollection from Ladsonâ€™s counsel (claiming the jury was excused for the day and reached a verdict the following day), the trial court responded, â€œI usually require the jury to stay for as long as it takes [until it] come[s] back with a verdict.Â  I donâ€™t ever remember an occasion where I have allowed a jury to go home and come back.â€Â  The trial courtâ€™s recollection was proven faulty when the State called attention to the juror note dated November 9, 2004, and the juryâ€™s verdict dated the next day, November 10.Â Â  
The trial court and the State are confident that Ladson made timely objections at trial and moved for a directed verdict â€œbased upon the evidence.â€Â  Presumably, the State believes these concessions enlighten Ladson and us to the specific issues to address on appeal.Â  
On January 26, 2006, the trial court issued an â€œOrder for the Record on Appeal.â€Â  
II.
Ladson maintains the reconstructed record does not allow for meaningful review of his direct appeal.Â  The State disagrees and asserts this court should find the record adequate for appellate review of the claims Ladson raised at the reconstructed hearing.Â  
It is clear from the record before us that all parties made a diligent effort to reconstruct the record.Â  Despite these good faith efforts, the reconstructed record is largely conclusory, with testimony, objections, and the like recalled only in summary fashion.Â  Thus, we must first determine the analytical framework for assessing the sufficiency of a reconstructed record, followed by a determination if the law warrants a new trial under the record before us.Â  
South Carolina jurisprudence recognizes the trial courtâ€™s authority to set the record for appeal.Â  In China v. Parrot, 251 S.C. 329, 334, 162 S.E.2d 276, 278 (1968), our supreme court held that where a portion of the court reporterâ€™s notes were lost, the trial judge properly considered affidavits from counsel and the court reporter in reconstructing the record.Â  See also Koon v. State, 358 S.C. 359, 367, 595 S.E.2d 456, 460 (2004) (recognizing a courtâ€™s power to remand for a reconstruction hearing), overruled on other grounds by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 105, 610 S.E.2d 494, 501 (2005); Whitehead v. State, 352 S.C. 215, 221, 574 S.E.2d 200, 203 (2002) (finding that when a transcript has been lost or destroyed, an appellate court may remand to have the record reconstructed); Dolive v. J.E.E. Developers, Inc., 308 S.C. 380, 383, 418 S.E.2d 319, 321 (Ct. App. 1992) (holding trial court did not err in granting property ownerâ€™s request to reconstruct the record of zoning proceeding where portions of original tape of hearing were incapable of being transcribed).
The authority of the trial court in South Carolina to reconstruct the record for appellate purposes aligns our state with the majority of jurisdictions that hold â€œthe inability to prepare a complete verbatim transcript, in and of itself, does not necessarily present a sufficient ground for reversal.â€Â  Smith v. State, 433 A.2d 1143, 1148 (Md. 1981); e.g., Lewis v. State, 123 S.W.3d 891, 893 (Ark. 2003); Wilson v. State, 639 A.2d 696, 699 (Md. 1994); State v. Deschon, 85 P.3d 756, 760 (Mont. 2004); Lopez v. State, 769 P.2d 1276, 1280 (Nev. 1989); State v. Izaguirre, 639 A.2d 343, 346
  (N.J. Super. Ct. App. Div. 1994); People v. Shire, 803 N.Y.S.2d 309, 310 (N.Y. App. Div. 2005); State v. Quick, 634 S.E.2d 915, 918 (N.C. Ct. App. 2006); Dickerson v. Commonwealth, 548 S.E.2d 230, 232-33 (Va. Ct. App. 2001).Â  
Most jurisdictions require an appellant to demonstrate specific prejudice flowing from an incomplete or reconstructed record.Â  See, e.g., Lewis, 123 S.W.3d at 893 (â€œ[I]t is the appellantâ€™s duty to demonstrate that prejudice results from the state of the recordâ€); State v. Williams, 629 A.2d 402, 406 (Conn. 1993) (holding appellant must show â€œspecific prejudice that results from having to address his claims on appeal with the reconstructed recordâ€); Jones v. State, 923 So.2d 486, 489 (Fla. 2006) (noting appellant must point to prejudice resulting from missing portions of trial transcript); State v. Wright, 542 P.2d 63, 65 (Idaho 1975) (holding appellant must demonstrate â€œspecific prejudiceâ€ resulting from failure to reconstruct record); Simpson v. Commonwealth, 759 S.W.2d 224, 228 (Ky. 1988) (holding a showing of â€œprejudicial errorâ€ in having to proceed using substitute transcript is required); Smith, 433 A.2d at 1148 (noting â€œdefects must be of a prejudicial characterâ€); Commonwealth v. Chatman, 406 N.E.2d 1037, 1040 (Mass. App. Ct. 1980) (holding appellant must â€œcome forward with articulable claims [by] which the reconstruction may be judgedâ€); State v. Borden, 605 S.W.2d 88, 92 (Mont. 1980) (holding appellant must demonstrate prejudice); State v. Dupris, 373 N.W.2d 446, 449 (S.D. 1985) (holding appellant must show â€œspecific error or prejudiceâ€ resulting from failure to record entire proceedings of trial); State v. Neal, 304 S.E.2d 342, 345 (W. Va. 1983) (â€œGenerally, the failure to report some part of the proceeding will not alone constitute reversible error[;] [s]ome identifiable error or prejudice must be shown by the defendant.â€).Â  â€œ[B]efore a defendant can establish that he is entitled to a new trial on the basis of an inadequate reconstructed record, he must identify a specific appellate claim that this court would be unable to review effectively using the reconstructed record.â€Â  Harris v. Commâ€™r of Corr., 671 A.2d 359, 363 (Conn. App. Ct. 1996).Â  We believe our supreme court would follow a rule requiring the party challenging a reconstructed record on appeal to demonstrate prejudice flowing from an inadequate record.
We conclude from China and its progeny, combined with a review of the law of other jurisdictions, that our supreme court would require a reconstructed record on appeal to allow for â€œmeaningful appellate review.â€Â  A new trial is therefore appropriate if the appellant establishes that â€œthe incomplete nature of the transcript prevents the appellate court from conducting a â€˜meaningful appellate review.â€™â€Â  In re D.W., 615 S.E.2d 90, 94 (N.C. Ct. App. 2005); see also State v. Chanze, 565 S.E.2d 379, 382-83 (W. Va. 2002) (finding criminal defendant is entitled to meaningful appellate review of his lower court proceedings, and if this is not possible from reconstructed record, a new trial is appropriate).Â  For a host of reasons, we find Ladson has established prejudice and demonstrated that the reconstructed record before us does not allow for meaningful appellate review.Â  
We recognize that the excellent trial judge did the best he could to reconstruct this case under difficult circumstances.Â  Approximately ten months transpired after the appeal was filed before the court reporter notified the parties (for a reason that is unclear) that her recording equipment failed and no part of the trial was recorded.[2]Â  The court reporterâ€™s delay in disclosing the lack of a transcript made a bad situation worse, as the passage of time clearly dimmed the recall of the participants.Â  We, too, must accept our share of the blame, for the remand order of this court required the trial court to reconstruct the record, with no option given to simply conclude that the record could not be reconstructed with the specificity to support meaningful appellate review.Â  Cf. Koon, 358 S.C. at 367, 595 S.E.2d at 460 (denying request to remand for reconstruction of a post-conviction hearing after appellant failed to allege specifics regarding his assignments of error); and Whitehead, 352 S.C. at 221, 574 S.E.2d at 203 (remanding matter to circuit court for reconstruction hearing and instructing, â€œIf the circuit court judge determines that reconstruction is not possible, he shall notify this Court . . . .â€). Â 
The hearing to reconstruct the record for this three-day trial on a violent, non-parolable offense took place on January 5, 2006, more than a year after Ladson was convicted and sentenced.Â  We are mindful of the tremendous workloads faced by our fine trial court judges.Â  It is simply unrealistic and unreasonable to think that a trial judge and counsel canâ€”under these circumstancesâ€”reconstruct a proper record that will permit meaningful appellate review, especially in light of our issue preservation rules.Â  The continuing dispute as to whether Ladson even testified (much less the content of his purported testimony) is but one example of the trial court and counsel groping in the dark as to what actually happened at trial.
Most cases around the country addressing this subject concern situations where only a part of the trial transcript is unavailable.Â  In many such circumstances, meaningful appellate review can occur and the rights of the parties are not prejudiced.Â  In this case, we are essentially left with a bare bones summary of the evidence (with more remaining unknown than known) from a lengthy multi-day and fact-intensive trial that resulted in a non-parolable twenty-five year prison term.
Moreover, the fact of a missing portion of the trial transcript is usually brought to the courtâ€™s attention much earlier than the year-plus delay present here.Â  We are left with a few gratuitous references to generic motions and objections, but we do not know the context of the motions, the specific nature of the motions, and whether the challenged evidence was cumulative to other unchallenged evidence.Â  The list of unknowns continues.Â  In short, we are left to speculate, and we decline to do so.Â  See In re Rholetter, 592 S.E.2d 237, 244 (N.C. Ct. App. 2004) (â€œIf a transcript is altogether inaccurate and no adequate record of what transpired at trial can be reconstructed, the court must remand for a new trial.â€).Â  
The record before us does not permit meaningful appellate review.Â  To hold this record is sufficient would guarantee the affirmance of Ladsonâ€™s conviction and twenty-five-year non-parolable sentence without a genuine review.Â  We would simply be constrained to affirm based on an insufficient record and issue preservation principles.Â  Moreover, it would effectively foreclose any collateral challenge through post conviction relief or otherwise.Â  We hold Ladson has demonstrated clear prejudice.
We finally remind the State that this court previously remanded this matter to the trial court for the purpose of reconstructing the record on the â€œassuranceâ€ by the State that this was a simple and straightforward case.  The State should therefore have no problem retrying this simple and straightforward case.
III.
For the reasons stated above, we are convinced that under the circumstances of this case the reconstructed record lacks the completeness and reliability necessary for this court to engage in meaningful appellate review.Â  We reverse and remand for a new trial.
 REVERSED and REMANDED.
SHORT, J., concurs.
ANDERSON, J., concurring in result only in a separate opinion. 
 ANDERSON, J. (concurring in result only in a separate opinion):Â  I disagree with the reasoning and analysis of the majority.Â  The reliance by the majority on decisions from other jurisdictions is unnecessary.Â  I respectfully concur in result ONLY.Â  I VOTE to REVERSE and REMAND the convictions and sentences of Travis Anthony Ladson for a new trial.Â  
The precedent extant in South Carolina, consisting of: China v. Parrott, 251 S.C. 329, 162 S.E.2d 276 (1968); Whitehead v. State, 352 S.C. 215, 574 S.E.2d 200 (2002); Koon v. State, 358 S.C. 359, 595 S.E.2d 456 (2004); and Dolive v. J.E.E. Developers, Inc., 308 S.C. 380 418 S.E.2d 319 (Ct. App. 1992), establishes the rule and procedure in regard to reconstruction of the record of the trial court proceedings.Â  Our law places the burden upon the circuit judge to utilize discretion in the reconstruction proceeding.Â  The ruling of the circuit court judge will only be reversed in the event of an abuse of discretion.
In China:
The defendant objects to the fact that the trial judge considered the affidavits of plaintiff's counsel and the court reporter in determining what transpired. The trial of this case was held in January 1965 and the affidavits were signed in April and May of 1967, over two years after the trial. The defendant contends that the long lapse of time since the trial should have rendered the affidavits of little probative value, especially in view of the inability of the trial judge and defendant's counsel to recall what took place and the statement by the trial judge in his previous order that the verdict of the jury apparently exonerated the defendant of the charge of recklessness. We find no error in the action taken by the trial judge.
Where there is a disagreement as to what the record on appeal should contain, the duty and responsibility of settling the question rests upon the trial judge. 
. . . 
In doing so he properly considered the affidavits of counsel and the court reporter as to what happened. The fact that the notes of the court reporter were lost and the trial judge had no independent recollection of the incident under inquiry did not preclude him from determining the question upon the basis of the affidavits submitted. Their probative value was for him to determine and his conclusions thereabout are binding on the court.
251 S.C. at 333-34, 162 S.E.2d at 278 (internal citations omitted).
Whitehead inculcates:
Petitioner sought a remand to reconstruct the record of his first PCR hearing.Â  See China v. Parrott, supra.Â  We now grant his motion and remand the case to Jasper County for a hearing to reconstruct the first PCR record.Â  This hearing should be held within 45 days of the date this opinion is filed.Â  If the circuit court judge determines that reconstruction is not possible, he shall notify this Court and the parties within 15 days of the reconstruction hearing.Â  If the record is reconstructed, the parties shall notify this Court and the matter will proceed according to King v. State, supra.
352 S.C. at 221, 574 S.E.2d at 203.
Our supreme court in Koon succinctly instructs as to the judicial duty if the original trial record is deficient:
Where a transcript has been lost or destroyed, a court may remand to have the record reconstructed.Â  See Whitehead v. State, 352 S.C. 215, 574 S.E.2d 200 (2002); China v. Parrott, 251 S.C. 329, 162 S.E.2d 276 (1968) (trial judge reconstructed the record where court reporter records were unavailable).
358Â  S.C. at 367, 595 S.E.2d at 460.
Finally, this court edifies in Dolive:
Appellants first contend the circuit court erred in allowing additional matters into the record on appeal arguing that, while Title 5 zoning cases allow supplementation of the record, there is no such provision for Title 6 zoning cases under which this case falls.Â  However, this case does not involve supplementation of the record.Â  The circuit court merely allowed J.E.E. to reconstruct the record by means of an affidavit.Â  In China v. Parrott, 251 S.C. 329, 162 S.E.2d 276 (1968), our Supreme Court held, where portions of stenographic notes of a trial proceeding were lost before they were transcribed by the court reporter, it was not error for the trial judge to consider affidavits of plaintiff's counsel and the court reporter in determining what transpired.Â  Based on the fact that this matter has already been twice appealed to the circuit court and the loss of the vital portions of the record appear to have been through no fault of the respondent, we find no error in the circuit court's ruling allowing for reconstruction of the record.
308 S.C. at 383, 418 S.E.2d at 321.
The vagaries and vicissitudes of a reconstruction hearing are demonstrated with clarity in the case sub judice.Â  The reconstructed record contains:Â  
1. Affidavit of the victim, Charles Smith, given on December 21, 2005.
2. Affidavit of the crime scene investigator, Sergeant Ryan Depoppe, given on December 21, 2005.
3. Handwritten notes of the original court reporter, Hilda Jordan.
4. Handwritten notes of M. Thomas, Ladsonâ€™s attorney at trial.
5. Large drawing showing the layout of Smithâ€™s home.
6. Coin box found inside Smithâ€™s home.
7. Hatchet discovered outside Smithâ€™s home.
8. Wallet found inside Smithâ€™s home.
9. Plastic Bag found inside Smith home.
10. Fingerprint samples given by Ladson.
10. Fingerprint analysis from the Charleston Police Department stating prints found on the coin box match those of Ladson.
Despite a brobdingnagian effort by the circuit judge and trial counsel, we are confronted with an epigrammatic record as it relates to appellate issues.
At oral argument, counsel was queried by the court in regard to an identification of appellate issues based on the reconstructed record.Â  Counsel for the State was unable to identify the appellate issues with any degree of exactitude.
Because the reconstructed record is profoundly deficient in guiding the court to preserved appellate issues, I come to the ineluctable conclusion that a retrial is mandated.
I VOTE to REVERSE and REMAND the convictions and sentences of Travis Anthony Ladson for a new trial.

[1] As the original trial took place more than a year before this reconstruction hearing, it was obviously quite difficult to reconstruct the record.Â  Although the hearing was orderly, it took on a conversational toneâ€”counsel and the trial court often informally discussed their recollections of the earlier trial.Â  In fairness to the outstanding trial judge and the partiesâ€™ trial counsel, the order of this court left no option but to attempt a reconstruction of the record.Â  As the trial court noted at the outset of the January 26, 2006, hearing, it would do the â€œbest it can â€¦ to reconstruct the record.â€Â  
[2] At oral argument, the State commented that the court reporter â€œused tapes that just wouldnâ€™t hold sound.â€
