title: State v. Fairey
description: Appellant, who was tried in absentia and without counsel, appeals his conviction for obtaining goods and monies under false pretenses.  He contends the trial judge erred in holding his trial in his absence, finding he knowingly and intelligently waived his right to counsel, and refusing to give him access to grand jury documents.
text:
Right to Counsel


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
William Smoak Fairey, Jr., a/k/a Doak Fairey, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â John L. Breeden, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. Â 4233
Heard March 7, 2007 â€“ Filed April 16, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia and C. Bradley Hutto, of Orangeburg, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman M. Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HUFF, J.:Â Â  William Smoak Fairey was tried in absentia and without counsel for the charge of obtaining goods and monies under false pretenses.Â  A jury found Fairey guilty, and the judge sentenced him to eight years in prison, suspended to five years service and four years probation.Â  On motion to vacate sentence and for a new trial, the judge reduced Faireyâ€™s sentence to eight years, suspended to four years service and four years of probation with a special condition to make restitution.Â  Fairey appeals arguing: (1) the trial court erred in holding trial in his absence, because he was not given proper notice of his trial or warned of possible trial in absentia; (2) the trial judge erred in denying his motion for a new trial because he was not cautioned against proceeding pro se and thereby wrongfully denied the right to counsel; and (3) the trial court erred in refusing to give him access to grand jury documents.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In June 1997, Fairey contracted with Scott Rudisill, a small business owner, to develop and install a computer system for Rudisillâ€™s business and personal records.Â  On July 7, 1997, Fairey approached Rudisill for a $25,000 loan.Â  Fairey told Rudisill that he was offered a job with the White House as a liaison to President Bill Clinton, but he had to overnight $25,000 to secure the position.Â  Fairey explained that the money would be immediately refunded once he began his new position and promised to immediately return the money to Rudisill. Â Rudisill agreed to loan the money and had Fairey sign a promissory note for $25,000 with interest on unpaid principal, at a rate of ten percent.Â  The note indicated all monies were to be paid on October 7, 1997.Â  Before October 7, Rudisill called Fairey a couple times regarding the money; each time Fairey indicated that he would have no problems repaying the loan.Â  However, Fairey did not repay Rudisill on October 7, and when Rudisill contacted Fairey, he said that he would deposit the money in Rudisillâ€™s account but never did.
On January 26, 1998, Fairey was served with an arrest warrant for obtaining goods and monies under false pretenses.Â  Following Faireyâ€™s arrest, Fairey signed a bond sheet, wherein under the heading, â€œAcknowledgment By Defendant,â€ it indicated he understood a trial would proceed in his absence if he failed to appear.Â  On July 23, 1998, notice was sent to Faireyâ€™s attorney, Richard Weldon, that the charge against Fairey had been dismissed.
On June 23, 2001, Fairey was indicted by a grand jury for the same charge of obtaining goods and monies under false pretenses.Â  In June 2002, Weldon made a motion to be relieved as counsel for Fairey.Â  Weldon cited substantial disagreement with Fairey regarding trial strategy, Faireyâ€™s failure to pay Weldon for his services, and Faireyâ€™s desire to proceed pro se as reasons for withdrawal.Â  Weldon additionally stated Fairey was given reasonable warning of Weldonâ€™s intent to withdraw if Fairey did not pay Weldon for his services.Â  On July 23, 2002, the trial judge granted Weldonâ€™s motion to withdraw as counsel.Â  The order stated, â€œ[i]t appears to the court that there is just cause for granting the motion and that Doak Fairey consents to the requested withdrawal as signified by the signature of Doak Fairey on the attached consent form.â€Â  Also in the order, Fairey was instructed that he needed to keep the court informed as to where papers should be served, had the obligation to retain counsel if he desired, and had the responsibility to prepare for trial.Â  
On August 22, 2002, Fairey informed the solicitor of a change of address: 

Pursuant to the Consent Order regarding â€œkeeping the court informed as to where notices, pleadings, and other papers may be served,â€ I am informing the court of my new address. Â All notices, pleadings and other papers should be delivered to:
  
Doak Fairey
31545 Vaca Drive
Castaic, California 91384
  
This address change is valid immediately
So that I might adequately prepare for trial, please assure that any and all future correspondence is sent to this address. 

On September 8, 2002, after being sent a subpoena to his former Florida address, Fairey informed the court and solicitor, once again, that the California address was the correct address to send all correspondence.Â  This letter stated:

Today, I received VIA FAX a copy of a subpoena relating to my case.Â  This document was sent to my old address in Sarasota, Florida.
In my previous correspondence (copy attached), I informed you and the court of my address change.Â  I followed the procedure as spelled out in your correspondence of 7/30/02.Â  You have chosen to ignore the Rule, and your own written procedure, and failed to properly send documents to me at my address . . . .Â  Please assure that all correspondence and information for trial is sent to my new address:
Doak Fairey
31545 Vaca Drive
Castaic, CA 91384Â  

On March 10, 2003, Fairey made a motion to quash the indictment.Â  In his motion to quash, Fairey listed his addresses as:

  
    
      31545 Vaca
        Drive  
      5629 Boulder Blvd
    
    
      Castaic, CA 91384 
      Sarasota, FL 34233
    
    
      941-284-5896
       (temporary address)
    
  

The motion was signed, â€œDefendant pro se.â€Â  (emphasis in original).Â  The motion listed as reasons to quash the indictment: (1) the State failed to provide defendant with a preliminary hearing; (2) the State failed to produce documents related to his previously dismissed charge; and (3) the State failed to produce documents relating to the 2001 grand jury indictment.Â  
A hearing on the motion to quash was held on March 24, 2003.Â  Fairey appeared at the hearing without counsel and proceeded to represent himself. Â Fairey complained that the State possessed documents relating to the case that was originally dismissed in July 1998.Â  Fairey â€œrequested memorialization of the Grand Jury proceedings in this caseâ€ and explained that he was â€œtrying to determine . . . exactly what the Grand Jury saw, what they heardâ€ because of the belief that they could not review evidence relating to the previously dismissed case.Â  Fairey based his argument on an expungement statute, S.C. Code Â§ 17-1-40, which requires the expungement of certain documents after a charge is dismissed.Â  In response the State noted that Fairey was directly indicted by the grand jury after the earlier dismissal of the charge, and â€œ[t]here is no evidence that I could produce to him of the Grand Jury proceeding other than a certified copy of an indictment.â€ Â Further, the State explained that the process of destroying documents provided for in the expungement statute was not an automatic process once a case is dismissed. Â Rather, a defendant must file a motion to have his record expunged and the court sign an order directing the State to destroy the documents relating to the dismissed case. Â During the hearing Fairey made a motion to dismiss and afterward filed the motion to dismiss with the court, indicating Fairey as a pro se defendant and listing a Florida address.Â  
On March 31, 2003, the judge denied Faireyâ€™s motion to quash on the following reasons: (1) Faireyâ€™s right to a preliminary hearing was extinguished by virtue of the fact his case had been presented to the Grand Jury; (2) Faireyâ€™s reliance on a expungement statute in regard to the expungement of the 1998 documents was misplaced in this case: (3) failure to comply with discovery was not remedied through the quashing of an indictment; and (4) there was no merit to Faireyâ€™s allegation regarding the validity of the Grand Jury proceeding.Â  The judge also reinstated Faireyâ€™s previous bond.Â  The order notified Fairey: â€œ[t]he defendant is required to appear at the call of his case by the State and shall keep the Court and the State advised of any changes in his address.â€Â  The court order was sent to Fairey at the temporary Florida address provided in the motion to quash.Â  
The solicitorâ€™s office subpoenaed Fairey to appear in the Conway Judicial Building from July 9 through 23, 2004.Â  The subpoena, dated June 21, 2004, listed Faireyâ€™s California address and a Myrtle Beach address.Â  The case was called on July 21, 2004, but Fairey did not appear.Â  At the hearing, the administrative assistant for the solicitorâ€™s office testified the subpoena was sent to: (1) the California address because it was the last official address provided by Fairey in his August 22 and September 8 letters; and (2) the Myrtle Beach address because it was the address provided in Faireyâ€™s original bond form.Â  After the solicitor presented evidence that Fairey received notice of the date and time of his trial, the court found that the solicitor made an adequate showing Fairey received notice and the trial proceeded in Faireyâ€™s absence.Â  
On July 21, 2004, the trial court sentenced Fairey to eight years imprisonment, suspended to five years service and four years probation.Â  Fairey was also fined $128.75 and ordered to pay restitution of $25,000. 
Fairey was apprehended in Florida and brought in for sentencing on October 21, 2004.Â  Faireyâ€™s counsel moved for a vacation of his conviction and new trial based on the lack of notice and because Fairey was tried without counsel.Â  The judge denied the motion finding Fairey adequately and legally waived his right to counsel and his right to be present at the trial.Â  The judge then reduced Faireyâ€™s sentence to eight years, suspended to four years service and four years probation with a special condition to make restitution to Rudisill in the amount of $25,000.Â  This appeal follows.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Notice and Trial in Absentia 
Fairey argues that the trial court erred in holding his trial in his absence, where the State failed to show: (1) he received notice of his right to be present; and (2) he was warned the trial would proceed in his absence.Â  We disagree.Â  
Although the Sixth Amendment of the Constitution guarantees the right of an accused to be present at every stage of his trial, this right may be waived.Â  State v. Bell, 293 S.C. 391, 401, 360 S.E.2d 706, 711 (1987); Â Ellis v. State, 267 S.C. 257, 260, 227 S.E.2d 304, 305 (1976).Â  Rule 16 of the South Carolina Rules of Criminal Procedure provides:

[A] person indicted for misdemeanors and/or felonies may voluntarily waive his right to be present and may be tried in his absence upon a finding by the court that such person has received notice of his right to be present and that a warning was given that the trial would proceed in his absence upon a failure to attend the court.

Rule 16, SCRCrimP.Â  
However, a waiver of such an important right is permitted only in limited circumstances.Â  Aiken v. Koontz, 368 S.C. 542, 547, 629 S.E.2d 686, 689 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Therefore, before a defendant may be tried in absentia, the trial court must determine a defendant voluntarily waived his right to be present at trial, making findings of fact on the record that the defendant (1) received notice of his right to be present and (2) was warned that the trial would proceed in his absence.Â  Id.Â  
A.  Notice 
â€œNotice of the term of court for which the trial is set constitutes sufficient notice to enable a criminal defendant to make an effective waiver of his right to be present.â€Â  Aiken v. Koontz, 368 S.C. 542, 547, 629 S.E.2d 686, 689 (Ct. App. 2006). Â However, if the record does not reveal that the defendant was afforded notice of his trial, the resulting conviction in absentia cannot stand.Â  State v. Jackson, 290 S.C. 435, 436, 351 S.E.2d 167, 167 (1986).Â  
In the present case, the solicitor subpoenaed Fairey to appear in court from July 9 through July 23, 2004. Â Notice was sent to Fairey at both the California address he forwarded to the solicitorâ€™s office in the August 22 and September 8 letters and the North Myrtle Beach address provided in the reinstated bond.Â  Fairey failed to appear in court when his name was called.Â  The judge heard the solicitor on notice to Fairey and made a determination on the record that: (1) the State made an adequate showing that the defendant was placed on notice of the date and time of his trial; (2) failure of the defendant to appear was willful; and (3) the defendant had â€œnotice that he had a right to be present and that if he wasnâ€™t present he would be tried in his absence.â€ 
Fairey argues that since the solicitor â€œinexplicablyâ€ did not send notice of his trial to Florida, but rather to California, Fairey did not receive notice of his right to be present.Â  Fairey further bolsters his argument claiming that because the solicitor â€œhad been sending legal mail to [Fairey] in Florida since the March 2003 hearing,â€ the solicitor should have sent notice of his trial to his Florida address.Â  However, the record indicates that Faireyâ€™s permanent address for service of notice was his California address, whereas the Florida address was only a â€œtemporary addressâ€ used by Fairey during a period in 2003. 
On July 23, 2002, when the court granted Faireyâ€™s counselâ€™s motion to withdraw, the court warned Fairey that he had â€œthe burden of keeping the court informed as to where notices, pleadings and other papers may be served.â€Â  At that time it was noted that service of notice would be sent to Fairey at his home address in Sarasota, Florida.Â  However, in the August 22 letter Fairey informed the solicitor of a change of address, listing his California address. Â And again, in the September 8 letter Fairey informed the court and solicitor that the California address was the correct address to send all correspondence.Â  
Fairey never sent a letter to the court or solicitor to inform them of a change of address from the California address to the Florida address as he did in his August 22 and September 8 letters.Â  Thus, the last official, permanent address provided to the court and solicitor by Fairey was his California address.Â  Merely because Fairey listed a â€œtemporary addressâ€ on his motion to quash and motion to dismiss over a year prior to his trial does not notify the court and solicitor of a change of address so as to direct where all notices, pleadings and other papers may be served.Â  Therefore, notice of Faireyâ€™s trial was properly sent to California, and as such, Fairey was placed on notice of his right to be present at his July 2004 trial.Â  
 B.  Trial in Absentia 
Further, Fairey contends he was not warned his trial would proceed in his absence.Â  A bond form that provides notice that a defendant can be tried in absentia may serve as the requisite notice.Â  Aiken v. Koontz, 368 S.C. 542, 548, 629 S.E.2d 686 689-90 (Ct. App. 2006); Â State v. Goode, 299 S.C. 479, 385 S.E.2d 844 (1989).Â  
In Aiken v. Koontz the defendant was arrested for driving with a suspended license, and when he posted bond the day after his arrest, he was provided an order specifying methods and conditions of release. Â 368 S.C. at 547-48, 629 S.E.2d at 689. Â The defendant also signed a form entitled, â€œAcknowledgement by Defendant,â€ which read â€œI understand and have been informed that I have a right and obligation to be present at trial and should I fail to attend the court, the trial will proceed in my absence.â€Â  Id. at 548, 629 S.E.2d at 689.Â  Thus, this court held that Koontz was warned a failure to appear would result in a trial in his absence and that he understood the warning and obligation by signing the â€œAcknowledgement.â€ Â Id.  
In January 1998, Fairey signed a bond sheet wherein under the heading, â€œACKNOWLEDGEMENT BY DEFENDANT,â€ it reads: â€œI understand and have been informed that I have a right and obligation to be present at trial and should I fail to attend the court, the trial will proceed in my absence.â€Â  As in Koontz, Faireyâ€™s signature on the â€œAcknowledgementâ€ served as a warning that he would be tried in his absence, and therefore, Fairey understood such warning.Â  
Relying on State v. Goode, Fairey contends because the indictment, for which the bond was signed, was dismissed, it was thereby extinguished and could not serve as notice to appear.Â  In State v. Goode the defendant was arrested for breaking into a motor vehicle and released on bond.Â  299 S.C. at 480, 385 S.E.2d at 845.Â  He signed a bond form that provided him notice that his trial would proceed in his absence if he failed to appear. Â Id.Â  He failed to appear and a bench warrant was issued. Â He was subsequently indicted for both breaking into a motor vehicle and grand larceny and was tried in his absence for both charges. Â Id. at 481, 385 S.E.2d at 845. Â The supreme court held that Goode did not have adequate notice that he would be tried for the newly indicted crime, grand larceny, in his absence since the crime was not listed on the bond signed by Goode. Â Id. at 842-43, 385 S.E.2d at 846.Â  However, because Goode signed the bond form related to the charge of breaking into a vehicle the court held that he had notice he would be tried for that crime in his absence. Â Id. at 842, 385 S.E.2d at 846.
While Faireyâ€™s original indictment was dismissed, he was directly indicted for the same crime on June 26, 2001, and the 1998 bond was reinstated on July 23, 2002 by court order.Â  Therefore, the 1998 bond was in effect and thereby served as notice to Fairey that he would be tried in his absence. 
II.  Right to Counsel 
Fairey also argues the trial judge erred in denying his motion for a new trial because he was denied the right to counsel.Â  We disagree
â€œThe Sixth Amendment guarantees criminal defendants a right to counsel.â€Â  State v. Gill, 355 S.C. 234, 243, 584 S.E.2d 432, 437 (Ct. App. 2003) (citations omitted).Â  â€œOf all the rights that an accused person has, the right to be represented by counsel is by far the most pervasive for it affects his ability to assert any other rights he may have.â€Â  United States v. Cronic, 466 U.S. 648, 654 (1984).Â  However, this right may be waived.Â  State v. Gill, 355 S.C. at 243, 584 S.E.2d at 437. Â This court has explained that â€œa defendant may surrender his right to counsel through (1) waiver by affirmative, verbal request; (2) waiver by conduct; and (3) forfeiture.â€Â  State v. Thompson, 355 S.C. 255, 262, 584 S.E.2d 131, 134 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
In this case we confine our analysis to the question of whether Fairey waived this right by his conduct.Â  A defendant may waive his right to counsel through his conduct. Â Id. at 263, 584 S.E.2d at 135 (citations omitted). Â Deliberate and dilatory conduct on behalf of a defendant can suffice to waive the right to counsel.Â  State v. Pride, Op. No. 4208 (S.C. Ct. App. Feb. 21, 2007) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 7 at 69);Â  see also State v. Jacobs, 271 S.C. 126, 128, 245 S.E.2d 606, 608 (1978) (holding a waiver of the right to counsel can be inferred from a defendantâ€™s actions).
In support of his argument, Fairey relies on our decision in Thompson.Â  However, neither Thompson nor our more recent case of State v. Roberson, 371 S.C. 334, 638 S.E.2d 93 (Ct. App. 2006) requires reversal of Faireyâ€™s conviction and sentence.Â  Rather, we are guided by this courtâ€™s recent decision in State v. Pride.Â  As discussed in Pride, there is a crucial difference between the facts in Prideâ€™s and Faireyâ€™s cases and those of Thompson and Roberson.Â  
In Pride, the defendant was indicted for possession of crack cocaine with intent to distribute (PWID) and PWID within proximity of a school. Â On the first day of the term of court for which Pride was originally scheduled to go to trial, a public defender, William All, was appointed to represent Pride.Â  On that same day Pride was also represented by a private attorney, Fletcher Smith.Â  Smith subsequently withdrew as counsel and All was appointed.Â  Pride failed to appear for two scheduled appointments with All.Â  All sent letters to Pride indicating the date of trial and that he could not adequately represent Pride without speaking to him.Â  Pride scheduled another appointment, which he again failed to appear for and offered no explanation.Â  Eventually when Pride and All met, Pride indicated Smith was again representing him.Â  However, when All contacted Smithâ€™s office, the administrative assistant indicated that Smith did not represent Pride.Â  On the morning of the trial Pride did not appear, and Smithâ€™s office informed the solicitor that Smith did not represent Pride. Â The solicitor moved to have Pride tried in absentia, and All was relieved as counsel.Â  The judge specifically found Pride waived his right to counsel by conduct and Pride was then tried and convicted for the drug offenses.Â  When Pride eventually appeared before the judge for sentencing, All appeared at the hearing and indicated he could â€œperfect an appeal for [Pride] if he wants to raise the issue of whether or not he shouldnâ€™t have been tried in his absence.â€Â  The judge imposed his sentencing. 
On appeal, Pride argued the circuit court erred in relieving All as his counsel and proceeding with the trial in his absence, contending that his conduct was insufficient to establish that he waived his right to counsel.Â  This court acknowledged the significance of Thompson and Roberson as it applied to Prideâ€™s case but found a â€œcrucial differenceâ€ between the facts in his case and those of Thompson and Roberson.Â  The defendants in both Thompson and Roberson were not represented by counsel until the sentencing hearing.Â  This court concluded if it were to find the defendants in Thompson and Roberson waived their right to counsel it would be based solely on their failure to appear for trial.Â  On the other hand, Pride not only failed to appear for trial, but he was afforded a public defender whom he failed to cooperate with prior to his trial.Â  He was also given additional time to prepare for the trial, failed to appear for his scheduled appointments with the public defender and failed to offer any assistance in preparation for his defense.Â  Further, he gave assurances to the public defender, up to the day before his trial, that a private attorney would represent him, yet was aware that this private attorney was relieved as counsel.Â  Based on Prideâ€™s actions, this court found that it was not only Prideâ€™s failure to appear for trial but also â€œPrideâ€™s deliberate and dilatory conduct [which were] sufficient to waive his right to counsel.â€Â  State v. Pride, Op. No. 4208 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Feb. 20, 2007) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 7 at 69). 
In this case, just as in Pride, Fairey was originally represented by counsel, and it was because of his own conduct and failure to cooperate with his counsel that he failed to be represented at the time of his trial.Â  Fairey hired private counsel, Weldon, and had ample opportunities to meet with him and discuss the case.Â  At some point in his representation, Fairey had a disagreement with Weldon as to the fundamental representation and trial strategies and failed to pay Weldon for his services even after a â€œreasonable warningâ€ that Weldon would withdraw.Â  Finally, Fairey desired to represent himself pro se and signed a consent form agreeing to relieve Weldon.Â  
From the date the court granted Weldonâ€™s motion to be relieved, Fairey was aware of his duties and obligation as a pro se litigant and was alternatively instructed to hire counsel.Â  Fairey failed to hire another attorney and proceeded to represent himself.Â  Fairey was aware of his obligations and seemed knowledgeable about the legal system, as he maintained contact with the court and solicitor, made two requests to produce to the solicitor and filed various pro se motions.Â  Further, his statements and conduct during proceedings reflected a familiarity with the workings of the legal system and the options legally available to him.Â  The circuit court found:

[Fairey] had been acting as his attorney for some time, making erudite motions and other things. Â Itâ€™s not like we had some ignorant person here that didnâ€™t know anything, we had a very intelligent person here acting as his own attorney. Â And asking that notices be sent to him and not his attorney. Â To be sent to him. Â He knew he was acting as his attorney.

Yet, during that period, Fairey also engaged in delay tactics.Â  He moved throughout the country, making service and notice difficult for the solicitor.Â  In the instances the solicitor was able to track Faireyâ€™s whereabouts and serve notice, Fairey made motions to continue, based on the inconvenience of appearing in South Carolina on the noticed dates.Â  The solicitor agreed to Faireyâ€™s motions and continuances were granted.Â  When the solicitor sent Fairey a certified copy of his indictment, a consent order for a personal recognizance bond and an acknowledgement for the receipt of the indictment, Fairey failed to sign and return any of the items.Â  Faireyâ€™s tactics further delayed the case and required the aforementioned items be addressed at a later hearing in March 2003.Â  Based on Faireyâ€™s actions, we find Fairey engaged in deliberate and dilatory conduct sufficient to waive his right to counsel.
III.  Grand Jury Documents
Fairey argues the trial court erred by refusing to grant his request for grand jury documents to prepare for his defense.Â  We disagree.
In Faireyâ€™s written motion to quash and at the hearing on the motion, Fairey claimed the solicitor failed to comply with his discovery requests for documents memorializing the grand jury proceeding in his case.Â  Fairey contended that documents relating to his previously dismissed case should have been expunged and therefore not reviewed by the grand jury. Â In his March 31, 2003 order the judge denied Faireyâ€™s motion to quash finding that Faireyâ€™s reliance on the expungement statute was misplaced and that the failure to comply with discovery requests was not remedied through the quashing of an indictment.Â  Fairey failed to challenge either ruling and therefore they are the law of the case.Â  State v. Sampson, 317 S.C. 423, 427, 454 S.E.2d 721, 723 (Ct. App. 1995) (holding that an unchallenged ruling, right or wrong, is the law of the case);Â  Sims v. Hall, 357 S.C. 288, 293 n. 2, 592 S.E.2d 315, 318 n.2 (Ct. App. 2003) (finding an unappealed ruling becomes the law of the case and precludes further consideration of the issue on appeal).Â  
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, Faireyâ€™s conviction and sentence are
AFFIRMED.
BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ. concur.Â

title: Eastern Savings Bank v. Sanders
description: In this civil case, Appellant contends that the Master in Equity erred by (1) not granting Plaintiffâ€™s motion to set aside the sale based on the test in Poole v. Jefferson Standard Life Ins. Co., 174 S.C. 150, 177 S.E. 24 (1934), as applied in Spillers v. Clay, 233 S.C. 99, 103 S.E.2d 759 (1958); and (2) finding the final bid was not so inadequate so as to shock the conscience of the court.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ex Parte:
Eastern Savings Bank, FSB, Appellants,
v.
Albert J. Sanders, Jr., Respondent.
In Re:
Eastern Savings Bank, FSB, Plaintiff,
v.
Roy A. Rouse, a/k/a Roy Rouse; Jean C. Rouse, a/k/a Jean Rouse; Neff Rental, Inc.; and Oswald Wholesale Lumber, Inc.,
Defendants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Clyde N. Davis, Jr., Master-In-Equity

Opinion No. 4234
Heard April 3, 2007 â€“ Filed April 16, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Thomas A. Shook and Sean Oâ€™Connor, both of North Charleston, for Appellant.
James W. Poag, Jr., of West Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Eastern Savings Bank, FSB appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s denial of its motion to vacate and set aside a foreclosure sale because of a bidding mistake by Bankâ€™s counsel and low sales price that resulted.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Eastern Savings Bank, FSB (â€œthe Bankâ€) obtained a mortgage from Roy and Jean Rouse in the amount of $490,000.00 on real property and a house located at 117 Maxie Road in Lexington (â€œthe Propertyâ€).Â  When the Rouses failed to make their scheduled payments, the Bank elected to accelerate payment of the entire indebtedness, which, including attorneyâ€™s fees and costs, amounted to $578,303.20.Â  In August 2005, the Bank sought foreclosure of the mortgage and expressly demanded the right to a deficiency judgment, reserving the right to waive the deficiency at the time of sale.Â  The master entered a judgment of foreclosure for the Bank and ordered the Property sold at public auction.
Following advertisement, the Property was set to be auctioned on October 3, 2005, a regularly scheduled sales date.Â  The Bank instructed its counsel to bid up to $550,000.00 for the property.Â  This information was communicated to Bonnie Hook, a paralegal for the Bankâ€™s law firm who typically worked with foreclosures.Â  Hook did not personally go to the sale, but instead sent her assistant with instructions to â€œbegin [bidding] at $100,000.00 and to go up to $550,000.00.â€Â  Following Hookâ€™s instructions, the representative bid $100,000.00.Â  There were no other bids made at that time.
Pursuant to section 15-39-720 of the South Carolina Code (2005), bidding was reopened on November 2, 2005, with several individuals placing offers.Â  Albert Sanders had the highest bid ($246,000.00) and paid the requisite five percent deposit to the court.Â  Neither the Bank, its counsel, nor any other representative was present at the second auction.Â  Presumably, they declined to attend because the Bank was barred from making another bid under section 15-39-720, or possibly because they simply had not realized bidding had not closed after the October 2 proceeding. Â 
On November 3, 2005, the Bank inquired with Hook in regard to the bid from Sanders.Â  Hook then contacted the court, whereupon she learned the Property involved a deficiency judgment and immediately recognized she had made a mistake in her earlier bidding instructions to her assistant.Â  
On November 9, 2005, the Bank filed a motion to vacate and set aside the sale to Sanders.Â  The Bank argued the low sales price, along with the misunderstanding and circumstances that caused the Bank to mistakenly bid only $100,000.00, dictated the sale be set aside.Â  Additionally, the Bank asserted the price Sanders paid was so low as to shock the conscience of the court.
The master held a hearing on the matter in January 2006.Â  As stated in the masterâ€™s order, Hook â€œcandidly admitted that she made a mistake in her bid instructions and that no one else was responsible for the error.Â  She stated that the sale was properly held and that no third party interfered with bidding.â€Â  
Testimony and other evidence provided values of the Property ranging from $324,940.00 to $900,000.00.Â  The assistant vice-president for the Bank testified that despite Bank authorizing only $550,000.00 as its highest bid, he valued the Property at $700,000.00 for lending purposes.Â  Although the Rouses never received an offer, the home had been marketed for sale prior to foreclosure and was listed for as low as $625,000.00.Â  Renee Bolos, the real estate agent who first represented the Rouses, stated she estimated the Property to be worth $900,000.00. Â Rusty Johnson, a real estate agent who later attempted to sell the Property, valued it at $750,000.00.Â  After listing the Property at this price for six months, the amount was reduced to $600,000.00. Â Â Nevertheless, Johnson was unable to generate any offers. Â When the Rouses attempted to sell the Property at private auction with a reserve price of $650,000.00, the highest bid received was $350,000.00.Â  The county tax appraisal for the home was $324,940.00.
The master found the value of the Property to be $550,000.00.Â  Although recognizing the sales price was below market value, he stated that he did not believe it to be so inadequate as to shock the conscience of the court.Â  Further, the master determined it was by mistake on the part of the bidder on the Bankâ€™s behalf, not any conduct by the sales officer or other bidder, that caused the winning bid to be less than the actual value of the Property. Â Accordingly, the master denied the Bankâ€™s motion to vacate and set aside the sale.Â  The Bank filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter or amend the judgment.Â  The master denied this motion.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA mortgage foreclosure is an action in equity. Â Our scope of review of a case heard by a master who enters a final judgment is to determine facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€ Â Hayne Federal Credit Union v. Bailey, 327 S.C. 242, 248, 489 S.E.2d 472, 475 (1997) (internal citations omitted).Â  However, the determination of whether a judicial sale should be set aside is a matter left to the sound discretion of the trial court. Â Investors Sav. Bank v. Phelps, 303 S.C. 15, 17, 397 S.E.2d 780, 781 (Ct. App. 1990) (citing Bonney v. Granger, 300 S.C. 362, 387 S.E.2d 720 (Ct. App. 1990)). Â The review of a judicial sale is equitable in nature and within the discretion of the trial court. Fed. Natâ€™l Mortgage Assâ€™n v. Brooks,304 S.C. 506, 512, 405 S.E.2d 604, 607 (Ct. App. 1991) (citing Spillers v. Clay, 233 S.C. 99, 102, 103 S.E.2d 759, 760 (1958)). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Bank contends the master erred in failing to grant its motion to set aside and vacate the sale.Â  We disagree.
Where a mortgagee has sought a deficiency judgment, law requires the foreclosure sale held open for thirty days after the initial sale date. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-39-720 (2005).Â  The South Carolina Code provides:

In all judicial sales of real estate for the foreclosure of mortgages and sales in execution the bidding shall not be closed upon the day of sale but shall remain open until the thirtieth day after such sale, exclusive of the day of sale. Â Within such thirty day period any person other than the highest bidder at the sale or any representative thereof in foreclosure and execution suits may enter a higher bid upon complying with the terms of sale by making any necessary deposit as a guaranty of his good faith, and thereafter within such period any person, other than such highest bidder at the sale or any representative thereof, in foreclosure suits may in like manner raise the last highest bid, and the successful purchaser shall be deemed to be the person who submitted the last highest bid within such period and made the necessary deposit or guaranty. Â But the mortgagee or his representative shall enter such bid as he desires at the time the sale is made, and he and all persons acting in his behalf shall be precluded from entering any other bid in any amount at any other time except the single or last bid made by him or in his behalf at the sale. . . .
The bidding shall be reopened by the officer making the sale on the thirtieth day after the sale, exclusive of the day of the sale, at eleven o'clock in the forenoon and the bidding shall be allowed to continue until the property shall be knocked down in the usual custom of auction to the successful highest bidder complying with the terms of sale. . . .

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-39-720 (2005).Â  Thus, â€œ[t]he mortgagee must enter his bid at the time the sale is made and is precluded from entering any other bid after his last bid at the initial sale. Â This effectively forces the mortgagee to enter his highest and best bid at the initial sale.â€Â  27 S.C. Juris. Manner of Sale Â§ 128 (1996) (internal citation omitted).
â€œA judicial sale should not be set aside except for cogent reasons. Â The purpose of the law and of the proceedings in which a sale has been decreed is that it shall be final.â€Â  Spillers v. Clay, 233 S.C. 99, 104, 103 S.E.2d 759, 761-62 (1958). Â â€œAs has been said time and again in cases involving the setting aside of judicial sales, it is the policy of the Courts to uphold such sales when regularly made, and when it can be done without violating principle or doing injustice . . . .â€ Â Henry v. Blakely, 216 S.C. 13, 18, 56 S.E.2d 581, 583 (1949). Â Our courts zealously insure judicial sales be openly and freely conducted and nothing be allowed to chill the bidding.Â  Howell v. Gibson,208 S.C. 19, 31, 37 S.E.2d 271, 276 (1946).
â€œ[T]he rule is well settled that inadequacy of price, unless so gross as to shock the conscience of the court, or accompanied by other circumstances warranting the interference of the court, will not justify the setting aside of a judicial sale.â€Â  Spillers, 233 S.C. 99, 104, 103 S.E.2d 759, 761 (citing Brownlee v. Miller, 208 S.C. 252, 37 S.E.2d 658 (1946)).Â  â€œ[M]ere inadequacy of price, unaccompanied by other circumstances which would invoke the exercise of the Courtâ€™s discretion is not sufficient, unless, perhaps, it is so great as to raise a presumption of fraud or to shock the conscience of the Court.â€ Â Henry, 216 S.C. at 18, 56 S.E.2d at 583.Â  â€œWhere unfair means have not been employed to prevent competition at a judicial sale, mere inadequacy of price is no ground for setting [the sale] aside.â€Â  Ex parte Cooley,69 S.C. 143, 154-55, 48 S.E. 92, 95 (1904).Â  Thus, a judicial sale can be set aside for two reasons: (1) if the inadequacy of the price is so gross as to shock the conscience of the court; or (2) if the price is inadequate and this inadequacy is accompanied by other circumstances that warrant the interference of the court.Â  
I. Circumstances Impeaching the Fairness of the Transaction 
When an inadequacy of price exists and is the result of action by the officer selling the property or successful bidder, and that action could not have been reasonably anticipated by the party for whose benefit the property was being sold, the court should provide relief by setting aside the sale.Â  See Henry, 216 S.C. at 19, 56 S.E.2d at 583. Â â€œ[T]he circumstances impeaching the fairness of the transaction should relate to the conduct of the officer making the sale . . . or to the conduct of the purchaser participating in the attempt to stifle competition or affected with notice thereof . . . .â€ Â Â Appeal of Paslay, 230 S.C. 55, 61, 94 S.E.2d 57, 59-60 (1956) (quoting Ex parte Cooley, 69 S.C. 143, 155, 48 S.E. 92, 96 (1904)).Â  If neither the officer making the sale nor the purchaser contributed to the mistake of a party intending to bid higher, and the sale was fair and regularly conducted, simply because a party intended to bid higher, but neglected to do so, or was prevented by a mistake, is not a sufficient ground for setting aside a judicial sale.Â  Id. at 154, 48 S.E. at 95; see also Howell, 208 S.C. at 33, 37 S.E.2d at 276 (declining to set aside the sale where a plan to bid did not succeed, but its failure was due to no fault of the master, auctioneer, the winning bidder or any other person connected with the sale, but was due to the negligence or fault of the party complaining).
In Appeal of Paslay, 230 S.C. 55, 94 S.E.2d at 57 (1956), the appellant alleged he had been prepared to bid at least $1,000.00 for property that sold for $450.00.Â  The appellant instructed his lawyer to bid as such; however, the attorney was prevented from attending the sale as a result of the mechanical failure of his automobile.Â  Noting counselâ€™s explanation for his absence did not involve the actions of the selling officer, the South Carolina Supreme Court found the circumstances did not warrant vitiating the sale. Â Â Id. at 58, 94 S.E.2d at 58. Â 
In Spillers, where the officer conducting the sale deviated from the usual sales procedure, the Supreme Court found the claim of misapprehension and excusable mistake on the part of counsel was in relation to the conduct of the sale and accordingly affirmed the setting aside of the sale.Â  233 S.C. 99, 105, 103 S.E.2d 759, 762 (1958).Â  Distinguishing the facts of Spillers and Paslay, the court enunciated:

Distinction between that case and this is readily apparent. Â There no factor was present for which the selling officer had any responsibility; here the claim of misapprehension and excusable mistake on the part of counsel was in relation to the conduct of the sale.
. . .
In the case at bar Judge McGowan concluded from all of the evidence that the auctioneer had probably been overhasty in knocking the property down to Mr. Spillers, and that under all the circumstances Mr. Clayâ€™s misapprehension of the final bid was excusable. These conclusions, together with his further finding that the property is worth much more than the price at which it was knocked down, that the parties to the cause were ready to bid a much higher figure, and that to permit completion of the sale at the price bid by Mr. Spillers would result in injustice to the partitioners, are not without support in the evidence.

Id. at 105, 103 S.E.2d 762.
In the case sub judice, neither the officer presiding over the sale, Sanders, nor any other buyer made a mistake or perpetrated a fraud.Â  The Bank demanded the deficiency judgment and therefore knew, or should have known, the sale would follow the deficiency procedure.Â  Hook, whose actions are imputable to the Bank, testified the mistake was solely her own.Â  Assuming, arguendo, the selling price to Sanders was inadequate (but not so great as to shock the conscience), there are simply no factors attributable to the selling officer or successful bidder or other circumstances warranting the sale be set aside.Â  Accordingly, the master correctly found the judicial sale should not be vitiated.Â  
II. Inadequacy of Price as to Shock the Conscience
The Bank argues the master incorrectly determined the value of the Property and therefore erred in finding the final bid was not so inadequate as to shock the conscience of the court because.Â  We disagree.
Although the master found the Property to be worth $550,000.00, the Bank urged the master to set the value of the Property at $750,000.00.Â  We find no error in the masterâ€™s valuation.Â  When offered at private auction, the property did not receive a bid remotely close to its $650,000.00 reserve price.Â  Real estate agent Johnson tried for over half a year to sell the property at $750,000.00 and was still unable to sell the property when the Rouses dropped the listing price to $600,000.00.Â  Even the Bankâ€™s own witnesses agree there were copious factors negatively affecting the Propertyâ€™s curb appeal and value.Â  Testimony revealed the house is not in a particularly attractive location but is on a busy thoroughfare with commercial property next door and a trailer across the street, has no yard, remains unfinished, and is over-sized for the area it is located.Â  Chris Johnson, an assistant vice-president at the Bank asseverated, â€œI said bid up to $550,00.00 based on what I consider the value to be at the time and on subsequent events, the fact that it hadnâ€™t yet sold and the list price was down to $600,000.00, so given that situation, I thought if a third party bid that [on] sale, that was a number that we were willing to let the property go.â€Â  The evidence luculently supports the masterâ€™s finding that the Property value be set at $550,000.00.
Even assuming the master should have determined the value of the Property to be $750,000.00, Sanders still paid a third of the value.Â  While this may have been inadequate, it is not so grossly inadequate as to shock the conscience of the court.Â  
South Carolina has not established a bright line rule for what percentage the sale value must be with respect to the actual value in order to shock the conscience of the court.Â  However, a search of South Carolina jurisprudence reveals only when judicial sales are for less than ten percent of a propertyâ€™s actual value, have our courts consistently held the discrepancy to shock conscience of the court. Â In Investors Sav. Bank v. Phelps, 303 S.C. 15, 19, 397 S.E.2d 780, 782 (Ct. App. 1990), this court affirmed the masterâ€™s decision to set aside a sale where the bid of $510.00 was slightly more than one percent of the original amount of the loan and mortgage.Â  We found that even if the property was worth only a fourth of the amount loaned on it four and a half years earlier, the bid was still only four percent of the value.Â  Id.Â  The court noted New York courts consistently hold foreclosure sale bids of less than ten percent of the value are unconscionably low.Â  Id. (citing Polish Natâ€™l Alliance of Brooklyn, U.S.A. v. White Eagle Hall Co., 470 N.Y.S.2d 642, 649 (N.Y. App. Div. 1983) (â€œ[F]oreclosure sales at prices below 10% of value have consistently been held unconscionably low in this State . . . .â€)).Â  In Poole v. Jefferson Standard Life Ins. Co., 174 S.C. 150, 158, 177 S.E. 24, 28 (1934), the South Carolina Supreme Court set aside a foreclosure sale based, in part, on the fact that the high bid was $500.00 for property worth more than $5,000.00. Â 
By comparison, in Peoples Fed. Sav. & Loan Assâ€™n v. Graham, 291 S.C. 178, 352 S.E.2d 511 (Ct. App. 1987), this court found the sale price of $48,100.00 for property subsequently appraised at $73,000.00, was not so inadequate as to shock the conscience of the court and affirmed the trial courtâ€™s decision not to set aside the sale.Â  The court stated, â€œAlthough the sale price in the instant case was less than the value of the property, it was not so grossly inadequate as to shock . . . .â€Â  Id. at 182, 352 S.E.2d at 513.
In the present case, the Property would have to be worth more than $2,460,000.00 for the sale price to be less than ten percent of the actual value.Â  None of the Bankâ€™s experts set its worth at more than $900,000.00.Â  Taking the value the Bank asserts the master should have placed on the Property, $750,000.00, the sale price was approximately a third of the actual value.Â  Accordingly, the inadequacy of the price was not so gross as to shock the courtâ€™s conscience. 
CONCLUSION
We hold the master did not err in determining the sale should not be set aside. Â The sale price was less than the value of the Property because of a mistake by the Bankâ€™s counsel, not as a result of conduct by an official conducting the sale or another bidding party.Â  The master correctly determined the inadequacy of the sale was not so gross as to shock the conscience of the court.Â  Therefore, the order of the master is 
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE and SHORT, JJ., concur.

title: Collins Holding Corp. v. Defibaugh
description: Reverses an award for a violation of the Unfair Trade Practices Act after concluding any damages suffered were not the result of a deceptive act on the part of the defendants.
text:
Collins Holding v. Defibaugh


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Collins Holding Corp., Respondent/Appellant,
v.
Richard Defibaugh, individually, and Robert
Defibaugh, individually and d/b/a Lucky Dâ€™s, Appellants/Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4235
Heard March 6, 2007 â€“ Filed April 16, 2007

REVERSED


  
    
      
A. Christopher Potts, of Charleston, for Appellants-Respondents.
Eric Steven Bland, of Columbia, and Scott Michael Mongillo, of Summerville, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  In this cross-appeal, Richard and Robert Defibaugh, individually, and d/b/a Lucky Dâ€™s (collectively the Defibaughs), appeal the trial courtâ€™s decision finding the Defibaughs violated the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act (UTPA).Â  Collins Holding Corp. appeals the trial courtâ€™s refusal to treble the damages it was awarded.Â  We reverse the finding of a UTPA violation.
FACTS
Collins is in the business of placing pool tables, foosball machines, jukeboxes, pinball games, and other games in bars, restaurants, and convenience stores across several states including South Carolina.Â  Collins divided the profits of the games with the business in which the machine was placed.Â  
Richard and Robert Defibaugh are brothers who were employed by Collins as collectors to gather the revenue from machines within certain regions.Â  Both signed employment contracts with Collins that included covenants not to compete.Â  In 2001, Collins fired Richard after eighteen years employment.Â  Following an unsuccessful job search, Richard began leasing pull-tab horoscope machines to different businesses, including some with which Collins also did business.Â  Robert was employed by Collins for three years before he resigned in 2002 following Collinsâ€™ reduction of his hours.Â  After an unsuccessful attempt at starting a wallpaper business, Robert went to work with Richard.Â  
The Defibaughs expanded their business to include leasing jukeboxes, pool tables, and video games.Â  When the Defibaughs wanted to place their machines in a location, they would inquire if the location already had a contract with Collins.Â  If the business informed them it had an exclusive contract with Collins, they would not place their machines there.Â  Despite the Defibaughsâ€™ questioning, some of the businesses where their machines were placed did in fact have exclusive contracts with Collins.Â  
On August 13, 2002, Collins filed a complaint against the Defibaughs alleging: Â (1) breach of employment contracts; (2) breach of Collinsâ€™ location contracts; (3) tortious interference with Collinsâ€™ location contracts; (4) violation of the UTPA; (5) breach of fiduciary duty; and (6) breach of the covenant of good faith and fair dealing.Â  Collins also requested permanent injunctive relief.Â  
Collins dismissed its causes of action for breach of location contracts, breach of fiduciary duty, and breach of the covenant of good faith and fair dealing, and at the conclusion of Collinsâ€™ case the trial court dismissed both the breach of employment contract cause of action pertaining to Richard and the request for a permanent injunction.Â  The trial court issued an order entering judgment for the Defibaughs on all of the remaining causes of action.Â  
Collins filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion for reconsideration on the basis that the trial court failed to address Collinsâ€™ assertion that the Defibaughsâ€™ machines were deceptive and harmful to the general public and thus violated the UTPA.Â  The trial court issued an amended order finding the Defibaughsâ€™ machines utilized a technique known as â€œreflexive payout,â€ meaning the owner of the machine can control how much the machine pays back to players over the lifetime of the machine.Â  The machine, unbeknownst to the player, makes adjustments to the gameâ€™s outcome to stay within the payback percentage.Â  The machine simply discards the winning symbol or icon that would have exceeded the allowable payout percentage and selects a symbol that will keep the payout within the predetermined percentage.Â  This is referred to as â€œmorphing.â€Â  
The trial court found Collins met its burden of demonstrating the machines were misleading and deceptive due to their utilization of reflexive payout.Â  Further, the trial court found because the use of the machines was continuous, ongoing, and capable of repetition, Collins demonstrated an adverse effect on the public.Â  The trial court found Collins suffered ascertainable damages consisting of Collinsâ€™ lost profits during the time period both partiesâ€™ machines were at the same locations.Â  
The lost profits were determined by taking the weekly average of Collinsâ€™ income earned before the Defibaughsâ€™ games were placed at the location and subtracting the weekly average for the income earned when the Defibaughsâ€™ games were at the same locations.Â  Some weeks, Collinsâ€™ games actually earned more money than they had before the Defibaughsâ€™ games were placed there.Â  Those weeks were not factored into the lost profits calculation.Â  The damages amounted to $107,461.00.Â  The trial court determined the violation was not willful, because Collins failed to demonstrate that the Defibaughs knew that changing the payout percentage would affect the outcome of the games.Â  Therefore, the trial court declined to treble Collinsâ€™ damages.Â  Both parties appeal.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal of an action at law tried without a jury, the findings of fact of the trial court will not be disturbed unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the trial courtâ€™s findings.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  The trial courtâ€™s findings are equivalent to a juryâ€™s findings in a law action.Â  Chapman v. Allstate Ins. Co., 263 S.C. 565, 567, 211 S.E.2d 876, 877 (1975).Â  This court must determine whether any evidence reasonably supports the factual findings of the trial court.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd., 266 S.C. at 86, 221 S.E.2d at 776.Â  Additionally, the appellate court can correct errors of law.Â  Okatie River,
L.L.C. v. Se. Site Prep, L.L.C. 353 S.C. 327, 334, 577 S.E.2d 468, 472 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Defibaughs argue the trial court erred in finding Collins suffered damages under the UTPA.Â  We agree.
The UTPA declares unlawful the employment of â€œunfair or deceptive acts or practices in the conduct of any trade or commerce . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-5-20(a) (1976).Â  Section 39-5-140(a) creates a private right of action in favor of â€œ[a]ny person who suffers any ascertainable loss of money or property, real or personal, as a result of the use or employment by another person of an unfair or deceptive method, act or practice declared unlawful by Â§ 39-5-20 . . . .â€Â  Additionally, under Section 39-5-140(a), a plaintiff can recover treble damages where â€œthe use or employment of the unfair or deceptive . . . act or practice was
a willful or knowing violation of Â§ 39-5-20.â€Â  Noack Enters., Inc. v. Country Corner Interiors of Hilton Head Island, Inc., 290 S.C. 475, 477, 351 S.E.2d 347, 348-49 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  
â€œRecoverable damages include compensation for all injury to plaintiffâ€™s property or business which is the natural and probable consequence of defendantâ€™s wrong.â€ Â Global Prot. Corp. v. Halbersberg, 332 S.C. 149, 159, 503 S.E.2d 483, 488 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  â€œActual damages under the UTPA include special or consequential damages that are a natural and proximate result of deceptive conduct.â€Â  Id. (citing Taylor v. Medenica, 324 S.C. 200, 479 S.E.2d 35 (1996)).
While Collins may have demonstrated some lost profits arising from the Defibaughsâ€™ placement of their machines at the same locations as where Collinsâ€™ machines were placed, Collins did not show that the utilization of reflexive payout on those machines was the cause of any lost revenue.Â  Collinsâ€™ director of operations, Jefferson Gibbons, testified that the primary reason the Defibaughsâ€™ machines hurt Collinsâ€™ business was because the Defibaughsâ€™ machines were easy to play.Â  Gibbons also testified that the Defibaughsâ€™ machines were faster and involved no thinking or skill.Â  The UTPA only creates causes of action in those suffering a loss as a result of a deceptive act.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 39-5-140(a) (emphasis added). Â While â€œmorphingâ€ may have affected the players of the games, that feature is not what caused Collinsâ€™ machines to earn less money than before the Defibaughsâ€™ machines were placed at the same locations.Â  Accordingly, the trial court erred in finding for Collins on the UTPA cause of action.[1]
Based on all of the foregoing, the decision of the trial court is 
REVERSED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY, J., concur.

[1] Therefore, we need not consider the Defibaughsâ€™ remaining issues including whether or not â€œmorphingâ€ is deceptive, or Collinsâ€™ argument that its damages should be trebled. Â Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (holding an appellate court need not review remaining issues when its determination of a prior issue is dispositive of the appeal).

title: Dropkin v. Beachwalk Villas Condominium Association
description: The court affirms the denial of a motion for directed verdict and a motion for a new trial in this personal injury case, finding the jury's general verdict for the defense justified based on a lack of proximate cause.
text:
Dropkin v. Beachwalk Villas


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Kathe Dropkin, Appellant,
v.
Beachwalk Villas Condominium Association, Inc.,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4236
Heard March 6, 2007 â€“ Filed April 16, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
David H. Berry, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.Â  
Erin DuBose Dean, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.: Â Kathe Dropkin filed this negligence action against Beachwalk Villas Condominium Association, Inc.Â  Dropkin appeals the trial courtâ€™s denial of her motion for a directed verdict on the issue of negligence per se and her motion for a new trial.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
In April 1998, Dropkin vacationed with her family at a Beachwalk condominium on Hilton Head Island, South Carolina.Â  As Dropkin left the condominium one night to go to dinner, she slipped and fell down the staircase.Â  Dropkin suffered serious injuries to her hip and incurred $60,000 in medical expenses.Â  Dropkin commenced this action for negligence against Beachwalk.Â  
Beachwalk was constructed in approximately 1980.Â  Prior to trial, the parties stipulated the 1979 Standard Building Code applied at the time of construction.Â  The 1979 Standard Building Code required the staircase to include a handrail located between thirty and thirty-four inches above the stair tread.Â  The parties do not dispute that the handrail failed to meet the code.[1]Â  
At trial, Dropkin moved for a directed verdict on the issue of negligence per se because the staircase was not code compliant.Â  Dropkin did not move for a directed verdict on the issue of proximate cause.Â  The trial court denied the motion finding the code violation merely evidence of Beachwalkâ€™s violation of its duty of care.Â  The court submitted the case to the jury.
The verdict form asked, in pertinent part:Â  â€œDo you find that the Defendant, Beachwalk Villas Condominium Association, Inc., was negligent and that this negligence proximately caused the Plaintiffâ€™s injuries?â€Â  Dropkin did not object to the verdict form.Â  The jury rendered a verdict in favor of Beachwalk.Â  Dropkin moved for a new trial, arguing the trial court erred in failing to direct a verdict based on negligence per se, or, in the alternative, by failing to charge negligence per se to the jury.Â  The trial court denied the motion.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When ruling on directed verdict or JNOV motions, the trial court must view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Sabb v. S.C. State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).Â  The decision whether to grant a
new trial is left to the sound discretion of the trial court and generally will not be disturbed on appeal.Â  Rush v. Blanchard, 310 S.C. 375, 380, 426 S.E.2d 802, 805 (1993).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Dropkin contends the trial court erred in refusing to direct a verdict as to her allegation of negligence per se, and erred in failing to grant her post-trial motions, because Beachwalk was negligent as a matter of law.[2]Â  We find no reversible error.Â  
In order to recover for negligence per se in this case, Dropkin must prove an alleged duty, breach thereof, and the causal connection between Beachwalkâ€™s negligence and her injury before she is entitled to damages.Â  â€œThe finding of a statutory violation [in an action alleging negligence per se], however, does not end the inquiry.Â  The causation of the injury must also be evaluated.â€Â  Whitlaw v. Kroger Co., 306 S.C. 51, 54, 410 S.E.2d 251, 253 (1991).Â  In Rowe v. Frick, the plaintiff, a young boy injured while crossing a highway, alleged the defendant violated the applicable statute and injured him.Â  250 S.C. 499, 504-05, 159 S.E.2d 47, 50 (1968).Â  Our supreme court found the issue of whether such an alleged breach proximately caused plaintiffâ€™s injury a question for the jury.Â  Id. at 505, 159 S.E.2d at 51.

Although Dropkin requested a directed verdict on the theory of negligence per se, a verdict form combining this issue with the issue of proximate cause was submitted to the jury without objection.Â  The verdict the jury rendered could have been based on the lack of proximate cause.Â  Furthermore, although Dropkin argues there is no evidence supporting a defense verdict on the issue of proximate cause, the record contains evidence from which the jury could conclude the handrail violation was not the proximate cause of Dropkinâ€™s injuries.Â  Dropkinâ€™s own expert witness, Bryan Durig, testified as follows:Â  
Counsel for Beachwalk:Â  Now we all agree here today that the railings . . . are in violation of the standard 1979 Standard Building Code based on the improper height; correct?
Mr. Durig:Â  Yes.Â  I mean, in my opinion they are, yes.
Counsel for Beachwalk:Â  But that doesnâ€™t necessarily mean . . . [the] code violation was the proximate . . . cause of Mrs. Dropkinâ€™s fall; correct?Â  
Mr. Durig:Â  No, not â€“ not the initiating event of the fall, no.Â  The handrails are there to provide you [sic] once you have a mis-step. Â So uh my comments earlier about the roundness of the stairs and the fact that they were wet and donâ€™t have any traction, thatâ€™s what initiated this event where she slipped and mis-stepped and lost her balance, and the handrails are designed to provide you some assistance in the case that you have that event, and in this case, they didnâ€™t provide them, so she continued to fall down.Â  
So itâ€™s not the initiating event.Â  Itâ€™s a contributing factor, because they werenâ€™t there to properly help her regain her balance.Â  

Beachwalkâ€™s expert witness, Allen Campbell, testified as follows:Â  

Counsel for Beachwalk:Â  All right.Â  And were you able to come up um with â€“ with an opinion, based on a reasonable degree of engineering certainty, uh with regard to the construction of the stairway relative to Mrs. Dropkinâ€™s accident?Â  
Mr. Campbell:Â  Yes.Â  
Counsel for Beachwalk:Â  And what â€“ what opinion was that?Â  
Mr. Campbell:Â  Based on my review of the stairs, my assessment and reviewing her testimony, based on her own description of â€“ of how she fell, it certainly is my opinion that she slipped on the stairs as she was descending, and the handrail is not an issue.Â  She slipped on the treads, on more than one occasion.Â Â  

Because there is evidence to support the verdict on the issue of proximate cause, and the jury returned a general verdict as to the issues of negligence and proximate cause, we must uphold the verdict.Â  Where a case is submitted to the jury on two or more issues and a general verdict is returned, the verdict will be upheld if it is supported by at least one issue.Â  Anderson v. West, 270 S.C. 184, 188, 241 S.E.2d 551, 553 (1978).

Our supreme court has discussed this rule in detail:Â  
  
â€˜Under the â€œtwo issueâ€ rule, when the jury returns a
general verdict involving two or more issues and its verdict is supported as to at least one issue, the
verdict will not be reversed on appeal.â€™ Â Todd v. South Carolina Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 287 S.C. 190, 193, 336 S.E.2d 472, 473-74 (1985). Â The â€œtwo
issueâ€ rule may be applied by appellate courts in a few situations. Â In one situation, when a juryâ€™s
general verdict is supportable by more than one cause of action submitted to it, the [appellate] court will affirm unless the appellant appeals all causes of action. Â See Sierra v. Skelton, 307 S.C. 217, 414 S.E.2d 169 (Ct. App. 1991) (trial courtâ€™s decision affirmed where jury returned a general verdict, and appellant only raised abuse of process issue, but failed to raise defamation issue). Â Under a second application of the â€œtwo issueâ€ rule, the appellate court will find it unnecessary to address all the grounds appealed where one requires affirmance. Â See Smoak v. Liebherr-America, Inc., 281 S.C. 420, 315 S.E.2d 116 (1984) (where case was presented to jury on negligence and breach of warranty causes of action, appellate court need not address breach of warranty
exceptions if it finds that verdict was supported by the evidence under the theory of negligence).

These two applications of the â€œtwo issueâ€ rule are illustrated in the following example: Â A case is submitted to the jury on the issues of defamation and invasion of privacy. Â The jury returns a
general verdict for the plaintiff. Â The defendant appeals, arguing that the trial court erred by failing to direct a
verdict on the defamation issue. Â Under one application of the â€œtwo issueâ€ rule, an appellate court would affirm because defendant has failed to appeal the invasion of privacy issue as well. Â Assuming, however, that the defendant has appealed both issues, the appellate court would affirm on the basis of a second application of the â€œtwo
issueâ€ rule, if either of the two issues supported affirmance.
  

Anderson v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 322 S.C. 417, 419-20, 472 S.E.2d 253, 254-55 (1996) (footnote omitted). Â 
In this case, the issue of proximate cause supports affirmance.Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not err in failing to direct a verdict and acted within its discretion in denying Dropkinâ€™s motion for a new trial.Â  The order on appeal is
AFFIRMED.Â  
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY, J., concur.

[1] It is difficult from the record to discern whether a handrail even existed.Â  The staircase was flanked by a tall, solid-surface wall with a flat top on one side and a tall, wooden barrier with a wide, cupped top on the other side.Â  As each was located approximately forty-three inches above the stair tread, neither was at the appropriate height to comply with the code. 
[2] Dropkinâ€™s theory of negligence per se was not presented to the jury in the form of a jury instruction.Â  Following the jury charge, Dropkin made no objection to the omission of an instruction on negligence per se.
