title: State v. Grigg
description: Appellant Rebecca Lee-Grigg (â€œLee-Griggâ€) challenges her conviction for forgery, contending the trial court erred in denying her (1) motion for a directed verdict; (2) request to charge the jury on a good faith defense; and (3) request to instruct the jury on use of evidence of good character.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
State of South Carolina,
Respondent,
v.
Rebecca Lee-Grigg, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Greenwood County
Â Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4237
Heard April 3, 2007 â€“ Filed April 16, 2007

REVERSED


  
    
      
C. Rauch Wise, of Greenwood, and James W. Bannister of Greenville, for Appellant.Â Â  
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Special Assistant Attorney General Amie L. Clifford, all of Columbia; Â and Solicitor Jerry W. Peace, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Appellant Rebecca Lee-Grigg (â€œLee-Griggâ€) challenges her conviction for forgery, contending the trial court erred in denying her (1) motion for a directed verdict; (2) request to charge the jury on a good faith defense; and (3) request to instruct the jury on use of evidence of good character.Â  We reverse.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Lee-Grigg worked as the director of MEGS House, a shelter for abused women serving McCormick, Edgefield, Greenwood, and Saluda counties.Â  In that capacity, she arranged for the relocation of an endangered victim to another state. Â Lee-Grigg planned to accompany the victim to assist with the transition.Â  Initially Lee-Grigg sought financial assistance for relocation expenses from the South Carolina Victimâ€™s Assistance Network (â€œSCVANâ€).Â  SCVAN generally provides financial assistance to cover only a victimâ€™s expenses and reimburses mileage at less than the state reimbursement rate.Â  Lee-Grigg found SCVANâ€™s coverage inadequate.Â  Subsequently, she contacted Police Chief Brooks (â€œChiefâ€) of the City of Greenwood (â€œCityâ€) to ask for help.Â  The City furnished a vehicle and a driver to transport the victim.Â  Lee-Grigg accompanied the driver and the victim to facilitate the relocation on October 10-11, 2003.Â  The City paid for fuel and lodging for the driver and victim only; Lee-Griggâ€™s costs were not covered.Â  Lee-Grigg testified the Chief told her she could apply for reimbursement of the expenses the City paid in relocating the victim.Â  Lee-Grigg emphasized the Chief assured her he would not apply for reimbursement of the Cityâ€™s costs. 
Following the trip, Lee-Grigg submitted documents to SCVAN requesting reimbursement for the Cityâ€™s relocation expenditures.Â  However, she represented those expenditures as her own.Â  Included among the materials Lee-Grigg supplied was a â€œTravel Support Documentâ€ with the following attestation signed by
Lee-Grigg:

I hereby certify or affirm that the above expenses were actually incurred by me as necessary traveling expenses in the performance of my official duties; any meals or lodging included in a conference or convention registration fee have been deducted from this travel claim, conforms with the requirements of local and grant laws, rules and regulations.Â  

Lee-Grigg requested mileage reimbursement in the amount of $189.23 and attached copies of fuel receipts she obtained from the Cityâ€™s driver to support that request.Â  The signature of the driver and the Chiefâ€™s initials that appeared on the original fuel receipts were absent from the copies Lee-Grigg submitted to SCVAN.Â  Lee-Grigg averred she concealed the driverâ€™s signature and the Chiefâ€™s initials in order to obscure any trail that might lead to discovery of the victimâ€™s new location. Â Lee-Grigg additionally enclosed:

Â· a receipt for fuel costs incurred on October 8, 2003 involving transportation of the victim from Charleston to Greenwood Â 
Â· copies of meal receipts that obviously included meals other than the victimâ€™s
Â· a copy of a Holiday Inn receipt for $88.76, paid in full by the Cityâ€™s driver.

Shortly thereafter, the Cityâ€™s driver contacted SCVAN to inquire about obtaining reimbursement for the same relocation costs.Â  SCVAN identified the potential duplication of reimbursement requests.Â  A SLED investigation ensued leading to Lee-Griggâ€™s indictment and conviction for forgery.Â  Lee-Grigg was sentenced to two years of imprisonment, suspended to one year of probation.Â  
ISSUES

(1) Did the trial court err in denying Lee-Griggâ€™s motion for a directed verdict when the document in question was a genuine document with a genuine signature, and the State failed to prove the document in question was falsely made, forged or counterfeited?
(2) Did the trial court err in failing to instruct the jury on the defense of good faith?
(3) Did the trial court err in failing to charge the jury on the use of evidence of good character when Lee-Grigg presented testimony of her good character and reputation in the community?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, an appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006); State v. Douglas, 367 S.C. 498, 506, 626 S.E.2d 59, 63 (Ct. App. 2006) cert. pending; State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 525, 608 S.E.2d 435, 438 (Ct. App. 2004). Â Thus, an appellate court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  Id.; State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 101, 606 S.E.2d 503, 504 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  On appeal, we are limited to determining whether the trial court abused its discretion. Â State v. Walker, 363 S.C. 643, 653, 623 S.E.2d 122, 127 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The conduct of a criminal trial is left largely to the sound discretion of the trial judge, who will not be reversed absent a prejudicial abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Bridges, 278 S.C. 447, 448, 298 S.E.2d 212, 212 (1982); State v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 230, 625 S.E.2d 239, 245 (Ct. App. 2006) cert. pending.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Directed Verdict
Lee-Grigg contends the trial court erred in denying her motion for a directed verdict because the State failed to prove all of the statutory elements for the charge of forgery.Â  Specifically, Lee-Grigg alleges the document in question was not falsely made, forged, or counterfeited as required by statute because the document was a genuine document that contained a genuine signature.Â  We disagree.Â  
When ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight.Â  State v. Weston, 367 S.C. 279, 292, 625 S.E.2d 641, 648, (2006); State v. Stanley, 365 S.C. 24, 41-42, 615 S.E.2d 455, 464 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. Padgett, 354 S.C. 268, 271, 580 S.E.2d 159, 161 (Ct. App. 2003). Â A defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged. Â State v. Cherry, 361 S.C. 588, 593, 606 S.E.2d 475, 478 (2004) (citing State v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 642, 576 S.E.2d 168, 171 (2003)); State v. Crawford, 362 S.C. 627, 633, 608 S.E.2d 886, 889 (Ct. App. 2005); Padgett, 354 S.C. at 271, 580 S.E.2d at 161.Â  When reviewing a denial of a directed verdict, an appellate court views evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the State.Â  Weston, 367 S.C. at 292, 625 S.E.2d at 648; State v. Zeigler, 364 S.C. 94, 101, 610 S.E.2d 859, 863 (Ct. App. 2005) cert. denied; State v. Al-Amin, 353 S.C. 405, 578 S.E.2d 32 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  If there is any direct evidence or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, we must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  Weston, 367 S.C. at 292-93, 625 S.E.2d at 648; Cherry, 361 S.C. at 593, 606 S.E.2d at 478; McKnight, 352 S.C. at 642, 576 S.E.2d at 172; State v. Condrey, 349 S.C. 184, 190, 562 S.E.2d 320, 323 (Ct. App. 2002); see also State v. Horton, 359 S.C. 555, 563, 598 S.E.2d 279, 284 (Ct. App. 2004) (noting judge should deny motion for directed verdict if there is any direct or substantial circumstantial evidence that reasonably tends to prove the defendantâ€™s guilt, or from which guilt may be fairly and logically deduced).Â  The appellate court may reverse the trial courtâ€™s denial of a motion for a directed verdict only if there is no evidence to support the courtâ€™s ruling. Â State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 564 S.E.2d 87 (2002).
The trial court should grant a directed verdict when the evidence merely raises a suspicion that the defendant is guilty. Â State v. Arnold, 361 S.C. 386, 390, 605 S.E.2d 529, 531 (2004).Â  â€œSuspicionâ€ implies a belief or opinion as to guilt based upon facts or circumstances which do not amount to proof.â€ Â Cherry, 361 S.C. at 594, 606 S.E.2d at 478. Â However, a trial court is not required to find that the evidence infers guilt to the exclusion of any other reasonable hypothesis. Â Cherry, 361 S.C. at 594, 606 S.E.2d at 478.Â  
Section 16-13-10 of the South Carolina Code of Laws (2003) provides, in pertinent part:

(A) It is unlawful for a person to
(1) falsely make, forge, or counterfeit; cause or procure to be falsely made, forged, or counterfeited; or wilfully act or assist in the false making, forging, or counterfeiting of any writing or instrument of writing;
(2) utter or publish as true any false, forged, or counterfeited writing or instrument of writing;
. . . or . . . 
(4) willingly act or assist in any of the premises, with an intention to defraud any person.

Forgery consists of the fraudulent making or altering of a writing by one intending to defraud, prejudice, or damage another person. Â Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 650 (6th ed. 1990).Â  It has been defined as a false making of an instrument, on its face purporting to be good and valid, with a design to defraud, prejudice, or damage another. Â See State v. Walton, 107 S.C. 353, 356, 93 S.E. 5, 6 (1917); State v. Floyd, 36 S.C.L. 58 (5 Strob. 58) (S.C. App. L. 1850).
In order to constitute forgery by uttering or publishing a forged instrument or writing the instrument must be uttered or published as true or genuine, known by the party uttering or publishing it that it is false, forged, or counterfeited, and intended to prejudice, damage or defraud another person.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-10(A) (2003); State v. Pace, 337 S.C. 407, 417, 523 S.E.2d 466, 471 (Ct. App. 1999) (citing State v. Wescott, 316 S.C. 473, 450 S.E.2d 598 (Ct. App. 1994)); State v. Singletary, 187 S.C. 19, 196 S.E. 527 (1938); State v. Murray, 72 S.C. 508, 52 S.E. 189 (1905). 
The crime of forgery involves: (1) a false making or material alteration of some written instrument; (2) that is the apparent foundation of some legal liability; and (3) that is uttered or published with the intent to defraud or prejudice another.Â  Walton, 107 S.C. at 356, 93 S.E. at 6 (defining the offense of forgery asâ€œ[t]he material altering, with intent to defraud, of any writing, which, if genuine, might apparently be the foundation of a legal liability.â€); see also William Shepard McAninch & W. Gaston Fairey, The Criminal Law of South Carolina 421 (4th ed. 2002). 
 A.  False Making or Material Alteration of a Written Instrument
A material alteration of an instrument makes it speak a language different in legal effect from the language it originally spoke, or generates some change in the rights, interests, or obligations of the parties to the writing. Â McAninch at 422.Â  The alteration may be accomplished by additions to or subtractions from the instrument, such as erasures or deletions of words, numbers, or symbols that change the instrumentâ€™s effect.Â  See State v. Wescott, 316 S.C. 473, 477-78, 450 S.E.2d 598, 601 (Ct. App. 1994). Â â€œAs a general rule, forgery cannot be committed by the genuine making of an instrument for the purpose of defrauding; however, the making of a false instrument is as much a forgery as is the false making of an instrument.â€Â  Id. at 477-78, 450 S.E.2d at 601 (affirming forgery conviction for passing a legitimate check, drawn on a legitimate account with an authorized signature because the account was opened with intent to defraud).Â  â€œForgery is the alteration of a deed or writing, in a material part, to the prejudice of another, as well as where the whole deed or writing is forged.â€ Â State v. Floyd, 36 S.C.L. 58 (5 Strob. 58) (S.C. App. L. 1850) (proclaiming â€œ[t]he alteration of a receipt for money, by erasing the word â€œpart,â€ and inserting, in lieu of it, the words â€œfull up to date,â€ constitutes the offence of forgery. . . .â€). Â 

[T]he mischief is just as fully and conveniently perpetrated by one of various alterations, as it could be by fabricating the whole instrument. Â A note or a receipt is either genuine, or it is not. Â If it be falsely and fraudulently altered in a particular making, it speaks a different language, calculated to produce a different result in its operation, to the prejudice of some one who is designed to be defrauded or injured thereby.

Id.
â€œOnly those alterations which change, or initially create, the legal meaning of the document will suffice.â€ Â McAninch at 422 (â€œAlteration of an immaterial part of the document does not affect its genuineness.â€). 
 B. Legal Efficacy of the Instrument

Kelley, 319 S.C. 173, 460 S.E.2d 368 (1995) (noting this court will not set aside conviction for insubstantial errors not affecting result when guilt is conclusively proven by competent evidence, such that no other rational conclusion could be reached). 
To warrant reversal based on the trial courtâ€™s failure to give a requested jury instruction, the failure must be both erroneous and prejudicial.Â  State v. Taylor, 356 S.C. 227, 231, 589 S.E.2d 1, 3 (2003); State v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 232, 625 S.E.2d 245, 239 (Ct. App. 2006) cert pending; State v. Harrison, 343 S.C. 165, 172, 539 S.E.2d 71, 74 (Ct. App. 2000) (citing State v. Hughey, 339 S.C. 439, 450, 529 S.E.2d 721, 727 (2000)).Â  Prejudice to the appellantâ€™s case is a prerequisite to reversal of a verdict due to an erroneous jury charge.Â  State v. Williams, 367 S.C. 192, 195-96, 624 S.E.2d 443, 445 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. Adkins, 353 S.C. 312, 318, 577 S.E.2d 460, 463 (Ct. App. 2003); Brown v. Pearson, 326 S.C. 409, 417, 483 S.E.2d 477, 481 (Ct. App. 1997) (holding â€œ[a]n error not shown to be prejudicial does not constitute grounds for reversalâ€).Â  Failure to give requested jury instructions is not prejudicial error when the instructions given afford the proper test for determining the issues.Â  State v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 263, 565 S.E.2d 298, 304 (2002) (citation omitted). Â 
Arnold v. State provides a reviewing court with the accepted framework for analyzing a defective jury instruction for harmless error.Â  309 S.C. at 166, 420 S.E.2d at 838.Â  

To say that an error did not contribute to the verdict is, rather, to find that error unimportant in relation to everything else the jury considered on the issue in question, as revealed in the record. . . .
Before reaching such a judgment, a court must take two quite distinct steps. Â First, it must ask what evidence the jury actually considered in reaching its verdict ... [Secondly, the Court] must weigh the probative force of the evidence as against the probative force of the presumption standing alone.
Following Arnold, the court applied this bifurcated analysis in Taylor v. State and reversed the defendantâ€™s conviction for possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine and marijuana.Â  312 S.C. at 183, 439 S.E.2d at 822.Â  The court determined the jury heard sufficient evidence on possession, but no direct evidence on intent to distribute.Â  Instead, the State relied on statutory inferences of the defendantâ€™s intent.Â  Id. at 182, 439 S.E.2d at 821.Â  In light of the trial courtâ€™s jury instructions, those inferences became presumptions that the defendant was required to rebut. Â Id.Â  â€œWhile there was sufficient evidence from which the jury could have inferred the Petitionerâ€™s intent to distribute the cocaine and marijuana, we cannot say beyond a reasonable doubt the jury did not base its verdict on the erroneous jury charge.Â  Id.

In State v. Jeffries, our supreme court considered an inadequate and confusing jury charge on an element of the crime of kidnapping.Â  316 S.C. at 22, 446 S.E.2d at 432.Â  Accordingly, the court weighed the facts the jury actually heard against the trial courtâ€™s confusing jury charge to determine what effect, if any, it had on the verdict.Â  Id. Â Concluding the juryâ€™s confusion centered on a defense that had no support in view of the facts, the supreme court decided, beyond a reasonable doubt, that the jury verdict did not rest on the inadequate charge.Â  Id. at 23, 446 S.E. 2d at 433.Â  Â Â 
Addressing the trial courtâ€™s failure to instruct on good character evidence, our supreme court held the error was harmless when the whole record conclusively established the defendantâ€™s guilt.Â  State v. Green, 278 S.C. 239, 240, 294 S.E.2d 335, 335 (1982).Â  Concomitantly, in State v. Harrison, the Court of Appeals found the trial courtâ€™s failure to issue a good character charge was not harmless error because the State did not present overwhelming evidence of the defendantâ€™s guilt.Â  343 S.C. at 175, 539 S.E.2d at 76.Â  The State charged and tried Harrison for simple possession of cocaine.Â  Harrison admitted he attempted to purchase cocaine but denied he ever possessed the substance.Â  Id.Â  Harrison submitted evidence of his community involvement with adolescents and testimony about the assistance he provided to two single mothers.Â  Id. at 170, 539 S.E.2d at 73. Â The Stateâ€™s main evidence consisted of the arresting officerâ€™s testimony that he saw Harrison drop the drugs. Â Id. at 174, 539 S.E.2d at 75.Â  Harrison requested an instruction regarding the evidence of his good character, which the trial court denied.Â  Id. at 173, 539 S.E.2d at 75.Â  While deliberating, the jury repeatedly questioned the trial court, indicating it struggled significantly with the decision of Harrisonâ€™s guilt.Â  Id.Â  We ruled the trial courtâ€™s denial was reversible error: 

A different verdict might have been reached if the jury had been instructed that evidence of good character and good reputation may in and of itself create a doubt as to guilt and should be considered by the jury, along with all the other evidence, in determining the guilt or innocence of the defendant. Â The State did not present overwhelming evidence of Harrisonâ€™s possession of cocaine, and did not try him for attempting to possess cocaine.Â  Thus, the refusal to charge the requested instruction regarding evidence of good character and reputation was not harmless, but was reversible error.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

Id. at 175, 539 S.E.2d at 76.
In the present case, the jury had before it evidence that Lee-Grigg signed a reimbursement request claiming she had incurred the relocation expenses.Â  The State presented testimony that the City actually paid the costs of relocating the victim.Â  Lee-Grigg professed she attempted to collect the funds because she believed the Chief had authorized her reimbursement.Â  Furthermore, she asserted the Chief did not plan to claim reimbursement for the Cityâ€™s costs.Â  Lee-Grigg averred she concealed the driverâ€™s signature and the Chiefâ€™s initials on the Cityâ€™s fuel receipts to protect the victimâ€™s new location.Â  At least two witnesses testified as to Lee-Griggâ€™s good character and reputation in the community.
After deliberating an hour, the jury asked for clarification on the definition of criminal intent.Â  The trial court recharged criminal intent.Â  Subsequently, the jury notified the trial court it was deadlocked, with â€œsix for guilty, four not guilty, and two undecided.â€Â  The trial court then issued an Allen charge.[1]Â  Within an hour the jury returned a verdict of guilty. 
Weighing the evidence the jury had before it against the failure of the trial court to issue the good character charge, we cannot conclude the trial courtâ€™s error was harmless.Â  The linchpin of Lee-Griggâ€™s defense was her claim she lacked the criminal intent necessary to constitute the crime of forgery.Â  She repeatedly testified the Chief authorized her claim for reimbursement and assured her the City would not attempt to recoup its costs.Â  The Chiefâ€™s testimony neither confirmed, nor denied Lee-Griggâ€™s assertion.Â  Because she relied on the Chiefâ€™s authorization, Lee-Grigg contends she did not have the requisite intent to defraud.Â Â Â Â  Â 
Indubitably, the jury struggled with this case (to the point an Allen charge was given), and it seems fair to conclude the struggle centered around whether the State proved the critical element of criminal intent. Â In our view, the element of intent is inextricably connected to defendantâ€™s character. Â We cannot say, beyond a reasonable doubt, that the good character charge would not have made a difference in the outcome.
CONCLUSION
We hold the State provided direct and substantial circumstantial evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s denial of Lee-Griggâ€™s motion for directed verdict.Â  We adhere to our established precedent that good faith is not a defense to forgery.Â  We rule that Lee-Grigg was entitled to a jury instruction on good character and the trial courtâ€™s failure to issue that instruction was reversible error.Â  
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s ruling on the request to charge evidence of good character is
 REVERSED.
 KITTREDGE and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] An Allen charge is â€œan instruction advising deadlocked jurors to have deference to each otherâ€™s views, that they should listen, with a disposition to be convinced, to each otherâ€™s argument; deriving its name from the case of Allen v. United States, 164 U.S. 492 (1896).â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary, 74 (6th ed. 1990).

description: The South Carolina Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund (the Fund) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order finding Kajima USA, Inc. (Kajima) and its workersâ€™ compensation carrier were entitled to transfer liability to the Fund pursuant to Section 42-1-415 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006).  The Fund argues the circuit court erred by: (1) concluding Kajima satisfied the requirements of section 42-1-415 to transfer liability; (2) concluding no substantial evidence existed to support the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s finding that the certificate of insurance presented to Kajima showed coverage only in Georgia; and (3) relying on our decision in South Carolina Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund v. House, 360 S.C. 468, 602 S.E.2d 81 (Ct. App. 2004).  We reverse.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Timothy Mark Hopper, Employee/Claimant,
				v.
				Terry Hunt Construction, Employer, Uninsured, South Carolina Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund, Kajima USA, Inc., Statutory Employer, and Zurich American Insurance Company, Carrier, Defendants,
				of whom Kajima USA, Inc., Statutory Employer, and Zurich American Insurance Company, Carrier are Respondents,
				and South Carolina Employersâ€™ Fund is Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenwood County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4238
Submitted February 1, 2007 â€“ Filed April 23, 2007

REVERSED


	
		
			
				Latonya Dilligard Edwards, of Columbia and Terry M. Mauldin, of Lexington, for Appellant.
				Steven M. Rudisill, of Charlotte, for Respondents.
			
		
	

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  The South Carolina Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund (the Fund) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s reversal of the Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (the Commission).Â  The circuit court found Kajima USA, Inc. (Kajima) and its workersâ€™ compensation carrier, Zurich American Insurance Company (Zurich), were entitled to transfer liability to the Fund pursuant to Section 42-1-415 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006).Â  The Fund argues the circuit court erred by: (1) concluding Kajima satisfied the requirements of section 42-1-415 to transfer liability; (2) concluding no substantial evidence existed to support the Commissionâ€™s finding that the certificate of insurance presented to Kajima showed coverage only in Georgia; and (3) relying on our decision in South Carolina Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund v. House, 360 S.C. 468, 602 S.E.2d 81 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  We reverse.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
FACTS
Timothy Hopper suffered an injury while working for Hunt Construction Company (Hunt) in Greenwood, South Carolina.Â  Hopper sought workersâ€™ compensation benefits from Hunt and Kajima.Â  In response, Kajima and Zurich sought to transfer liability to the Fund pursuant to section 42-1-415. 
 
At the time of the accident, Hunt was performing work as a subcontractor for the general contractor Kajima.Â  Both companies are based in Georgia, and at the time of the accident, Hunt did not have workersâ€™ compensation insurance coverage in South Carolina.Â  However, prior to Hopperâ€™s injury, Hunt presented a certificate of workersâ€™ compensation insurance to Kajima.Â  
 
The single commissioner found Kajima was not entitled to transfer liability to the Fund pursuant to section 42-1-415 and ordered Kajima and Zurich to pay benefits to Hopper.Â  The commissioner reached this conclusion by stating Hunt lacked workersâ€™ compensation insurance coverage in South Carolina at the time of the accident and the certificate of insurance Hunt provided to Kajima showed coverage in Georgia but no coverage in South Carolina.Â  Kajima and Zurich appealed this decision to the Commission, which affirmed the single commissioner.Â  Thereafter, Zurich and Kajima appealed to the circuit court.Â 
 
The circuit court ruled no substantial evidence existed to support the Commissionâ€™s finding that the certificate of insurance showed coverage only in Georgia.Â  The circuit court determined the Commission erred in its application of section 42-1-415 and concluded Kajima and Zurich were entitled to transfer liability to the Fund pursuant to section 42-1-415.Â  The Fund now appeals the circuit courtâ€™s rulings.Â  
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act applies to appeals from decisions of the Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  In an appeal from the Commission, neither this Court nor the circuit court may substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but it may reverse when the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 617, 571 S.E.2d 92, 95 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
 
â€œAny review of the [C]ommissionâ€™s factual findings is governed by the substantial evidence standard.â€Â  Lockridge v. Santens of Am., Inc., 344 S.C. 511, 515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence that, in viewing the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the same conclusion that the full commission reached.â€Â  Id. at 515, 544 S.E.2d at 844.Â  â€œThe possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence.â€Â  Lee v. Harborside CafÃ©, 350 S.C. 74, 78, 564 S.E.2d 354, 356 (Ct. App. 2002) (internal quotations and citations omitted).
As noted above, an appellate court may reverse the Commission when the Commissionâ€™s decision is based on an error of law.Â  Corbin, 351 S.C. at 617, 571 S.E.2d at 95.Â  Certain situations involve a mixed question of law and fact.Â  Statutory interpretation is a question of law.Â  House, 360 S.C. at 470, 602 S.E.2d at 82.Â Â  But whether the facts of a case were correctly applied to a statute is a question of fact, subject to the substantial evidence standard.Â  Bursey v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 369 S.C. 176, 184-85, 631 S.E.2d 899, 904 (2006) (The meaning of a statutory term is a question of law, but whether a gas and electric companyâ€™s activities met this definition is a question of fact.).
Therefore, the determination of the requirements to transfer liability under section 42-1-415 is a question of law.Â  However, whether Kajima and Zurich met those requirements is a question of fact.
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Fund initially argues the circuit court erred by concluding Kajima satisfied the requirements of section 42-1-415 to transfer liability to the Fund.Â  In other words, the Fund contends the circuit court erred because substantial evidence existed to support the Commissionâ€™s conclusion that Kajima did not satisfy the requirements under section 42-1-415.Â  However, before we determine the issue of whether Kajima met the requirements of section 42-1-415, we must ascertain what those requirements are. 
 
A.Â  Requirements of section 42-1-415 

	Section 42-1-415 in pertinent part provides:
	(A) [U]pon the submission of documentation to the commission that a . . . subcontractor has represented himself to a higher tier . . . contractor . . . as having workersâ€™ compensation insurance at the time the . . . subcontractor was engaged to perform work, the high tier . . . contractor . . . must be relieved of any and all liability. . . . In the event that [the subcontractor] is uninsured . . . the higher tier . . . contractor . . . shall . . . pay all benefits due. . . . The higher tier . . . contractor . . . may petition the commission to transfer responsibility for continuing compensation and benefits to the Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund.Â  The Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund shall assume responsibility for claims within thirty days of a determination of responsibility made by the commission.
	(B) To qualify for reimbursement . . . the higher tier . . . contractor . . . must collect documentation of insurance as provided in subsection (A) on a standard form acceptable to the commission.Â  The documentation must be collected at the time the . . . subcontractor is engaged to perform work and must be turned over to the commission at the time a claim is filed by the injured employee.Â 
	

If the language in the statute is plain and unambiguous, there is no need to resort to the rules of statutory interpretation.Â  City of Columbia v. Am. Civil Liberties Union of South Carolina, Inc., 323 S.C. 384, 387, 475 S.E.2d 2d 747, 749 (1996).Â  If the terms of the statute are clear, the court must apply those terms according to their literal meaning.Â  Id.Â  Therefore, we must first determine if the language used in section 42-1-415 is ambiguous.
The dispute between Kajima and the Fund arises in their interpretation of the type of documentation required to transfer responsibility for compensation.Â  Kajima ultimately argues as long as a subcontractor provides a general contractor with proof of workersâ€™ compensation insurance in any state, the general contractor is relieved of its duty, irrespective of whether the subcontractor has coverage in South Carolina.Â  The Fund argues there must be coverage in South Carolina for section 42-1-415 to apply.
Section 42-1-415 provides the means for a general contractor to shift liability for workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  To gain this benefit, the subcontractor has to provide the general contractor with â€œdocumentationâ€ that shows the former has workersâ€™ compensation insurance.Â  Â§ 42-1-415.
â€œDocumentationâ€ is not a defined term in section 42-1-415.Â  However, Regulation 67-415 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) sets out an acceptable way to demonstrate insurance coverage.Â  This regulation provides: 
 

	For purposes of Section 42-1-415, the ACORD Form 25-S, Certificate of Insurance, as published by the ACORD Corporation and as issued by the insurance carrier for the insured, shall serve as documentation of insurance.Â  The Certificate of Insurance must be dated, signed, and issued by an authorized representative of the insurance carrier for the insured.

On the surface, it would appear Regulation 67-415 sets out the definition of â€œdocumentation.â€Â  However, our recent decision in Barton v. Higgs, Op. No. 4197, --- S.C. ----, ---S.E.2d ----, 2007 WL 102986 (Ct. App. 2007), is illustrative on this point.Â  In that case, we held Regulation 67-415 describes documentation that is always acceptable.Â  Id.Â  But the Regulation does not set out the only acceptable means to prove coverage.Â  Id.Â  
 
Because the term is susceptible to at least two different meanings, it is ambiguous.Â  Consequently, we must resort to the rules of statutory construction to ascertain its meaning.Â  
 
The cardinal rule of statutory construction is to determine and give effect to the intent of the legislature.Â  Charleston County Sch. Dist. v. State Budget & Control Bd., 313 S.C. 1, 5, 437 S.E.2d 6, 8 (1993).Â  Following Kajimaâ€™s interpretation of the statute would lead to a conclusion that the legislature did not intend.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â 
Kajimaâ€™s argument stands for the proposition that although a subcontractor does not have workersâ€™ compensation insurance in South Carolina, if a subcontractor shows a general contractor proof of coverage in another state, a general contractor is relieved of liability.Â  In other words, if Hunt, the subcontractor, had coverage only in Alaska and showed proof of this coverage to Kajima, Kajima would be relieved of liability.Â  
 
Following this interpretation would allow a general contractor to escape liability by turning a blind eye towards the obvious.Â  Moreover, such an interpretation would place a general contractorâ€™s liability upon the shoulders of South Carolina, by deducting from the State treasury money owed by a general contractor.Â  Surely, the legislature did not intend such a result when it enacted section 42-1-415.Â  See Mauldin v. Dyna-Color/Jack Rabbit, 308 S.C. 18, 22, 416 S.E.2d 639, 641 (1992) (Workersâ€™ compensation statutes are to be liberally construed in favor of coverage.); see also Bayle v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 123, 542 S.E.2d 736, 740 (Ct. App. 2001) (Statutes that impose liability on the State must be liberally construed in favor of limiting liability to the State.); Vulcan Materials Co. v. Greenville County Bd. of Zoning Appeals, 342 S.C. 480, 496, 536 S.E.2d 892, 900 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œThe construction of a statute by the agency charged with its administration should be accorded great deference and will not be overruled without a compelling reason.â€). Â 
Nonetheless, Kajima argues the language of section 42-1-415 is unambiguous.Â  However, no matter how â€œclear the language of a statute may be, the court will reject that meaning when it leads to an absurd result not possibly intended by the legislature.â€Â  Hamm v. South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 287 S.C. 180, 182, 336 S.E.2d 470, 471 (1985).Â  Even if we were to assume the language of section 42-1-415 is clear, such a reading would lead to the absurd result described above.[1]Â  Having determined that section 42-1-415 does not reward a general contractor for turning a blind eye to the obvious, we must now determine whether Kajima complied with this section. 
 
B.  Kajima noncompliance with section 42-1-415 Â 
The Fund argues the circuit court erred by concluding Kajima satisfied the requirements of section 42-1-415 to transfer liability.Â  In other words, the Fund contends there was substantial evidence that the certificate of insurance presented to Kajima showed coverage only in Georgia and not in South Carolina.Â  WeÂ  agree. Â 
As described above, whether an agency correctly applied the facts of a case to a statute is a question of fact, subject to the substantial evidence standard.Â  Bursey, 369 S.C. at 184-85, 631 S.E.2d at 904.Â  Thus, our review of whether the Commission correctly concluded Kajima met the requirements of section 42-1-415 is subject to the well-known substantial evidence standard.
The certificate of insurance provided by Hunt to Kajima, dated September 4, 2003, lists the insured as â€œTerry Hunt Construction Company . . . Valdosta, [ Georgia] 31602.â€Â  The certificate holder is listed as â€œKajima Construction Services, Inc. . . . Atlanta, [Georgia] 30305-1503.â€Â  The coverage producer is listed as â€œBB&T Insurance Services, Inc. . . . Macon, [Georgia] 31210.â€Â  The block labeled â€œDescription of Operations/Locationsâ€ is blank.Â  There is no indication on the certificate of insurance in which state, if any, Hunt had workersâ€™ compensation coverage.Â Â  Based on this, there is substantial evidence to support the Commissionâ€™s finding that Kajima did not satisfy section 42-1-415.Â  Thus, the circuit court erred by concluding Kajima satisfied the requirements of section 42-1-415 to transfer liability.Â  
 
C.Â  The House case
The Fund argues the circuit court erred by relying on our decision in South Carolina Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund v. House, 360 S.C. 468, 602 S.E.2d 81 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Conversely, Kajima asserts House is factually similar to this case; therefore, Kajima should be able to pass liability to the Fund.Â  We agree with the Fund.Â  
 
In House, a general contractor employed a subcontractor for framing work.Â  Id. at 469, 602 S.E.2d at 81.Â  During the course of employment, an employee of the subcontractor was injured.Â  Id.Â  Prior to the accident, the subcontractor presented to the general contractor a certificate indicating workersâ€™ compensation coverage.Â  Id.Â  However, by the time of the accident, the subcontractorâ€™s coverage had lapsed.Â  Id. at 469-70, 602 S.E.2d at 81-82.Â  
 
The Commission concluded the subcontractor committed fraud by failing to notify the general contractor of the lapse.Â  Id.Â  The Commission transferred the general contractorâ€™s liability to the Fund pursuant to section 42-1-415.Â  Id.Â  The circuit court reversed and concluded the general contractor had notice of the subcontractorâ€™s lapse in coverage.Â  Id.Â Â  The general contractor appealed to this Court, and we reversed the circuit court.Â  Id.Â  Kajima argues this factual similarity requires us to affirm the circuit court.Â  However, House is distinguishable from this case.Â  
 
The central issue in House was whether a general contractor had a continuous duty to collect proof of insurance coverage.Â  Id.Â  We noted section 42-1-415 does not â€œrequire a [general] contractor to continue to collect proof of insurance coverage from its subcontractor after originally collecting documentation at the time of the hire.â€Â  Id. at 471, 602 S.E.2d at 82 (emphasis added).Â  
 
In House, the subcontractor initially provided the general contractor with proper documentation.Â  Id.Â  We did not address the issue of what happens if the documentation originally submitted to the general contractor did not provide coverage in South Carolina.Â  House does not stand for the proposition that a general contractor may escape liability simply by collecting documentation that shows a lack of workersâ€™ compensation coverage in South Carolina.Â  Thus, the circuit court erred in relying on House.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is  
REVERSED.  [2]Â  

HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Our ruling today does not put an extra duty upon the general contractor to inquire into the validity of the subcontractorâ€™s coverage.Â  However, a general contractor cannot expect to turn a blind eye to the subcontractorâ€™s obvious lack of coverage in South Carolina and have the State shoulder that burden.Â  A determination of what type of conduct constitutes an obvious lack of coverage in South Carolina will have to be settled on a case-by-case basis. 
 
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Dicapua
description: The State appeals the trial court's sua sponte grant of a new trial to the respondent Jeremiah Dicapua following his convictions for distribution of crack cocaine and possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine.  We reverse and reinstate Dicapua's sentence.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Appellant,
				v.
				Jeremiah Dicapua, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  4239
Heard March 6, 2007 â€“ Filed April 23, 2007
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Appellant.
				Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

GOOLSBY, J.: Â The State appeals the trial courtâ€™s sua sponte grant of a new trial to the respondent Jeremiah Dicapua following his convictions for distribution of crack cocaine and possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine.Â  We reverse and reinstate Dicapuaâ€™s sentence.
FACTS
On October 16, 2003, the Horry County Police Department and Myrtle Beach Police Department organized a sting operation in Myrtle Beach.Â  They rented connecting rooms at a Red Roof Inn in Myrtle Beach.Â  One room was to be used as a transaction room and the other as a control room where the officers, using surveillance equipment consisting of a hidden camera and a microphone, would monitor what occurred in the transaction room.
The police issued a female informant $180 in â€œmarked police buy moneyâ€ with which to buy drugs from Dicapua, a person from whom the informant claimed to have purchased drugs on a prior occasion.Â  The police had arrested the informant and another woman whom the record describes as a â€œcooperating witnessâ€ earlier that day, charging them with prostitution.Â  Before Dicapua ever entered the transaction room, the police conducted a search of the room and of the informant and the other woman. Â Once the officers had everything in place for the sting operation, the informant left the room.
Detective Kent Donald of the Narcotics and Vice Division of the Horry County Police Department saw Dicapua and the informant enter the transaction room as he watched from the control room next door using the hidden camera.Â  Once inside the transaction room, the informant gave Dicapua money and Dicapua tossed â€œsomethingâ€ onto the bed.Â  Either the informant picked up whatever Dicapua dropped onto the bed or Dicapua handed the â€œsomethingâ€ to her.Â  Regardless, the informant placed what Dicapua dropped or handed to her inside her pocket.Â  The officers entered the room and arrested Dicapua as he prepared to leave.
The police immediately searched Dicapua and found 0.8 grams of crack cocaine and $160 in marked bills on his person.Â  The informant turned over two bags of crack cocaine.Â  All total, the police recovered 2.4 grams of crack cocaine.
Before the start of trial, Dicapua sought to suppress the videotape because it did not have any audio.Â  The audio surveillance system had failed to record what was said in the transaction room because of a machine malfunction.Â  The trial court, however, refused to suppress the videotape.
Once the trial began, the State introduced the videotape through its first witness, Detective Donald.Â  When the trial court asked what the defenseâ€™s position was regarding the introduction of the videotape, Dicapuaâ€™s counsel specifically stated, â€œWe have no objection, Your Honor.â€Â  (Emphasis added.)Â  Whereupon, the trial court entered the videotape into evidence â€œ[w]ithout objection.â€
After the jury found Dicapua guilty on both charges, he â€œrenew[ed] all of [his] prior Motions . . . made during the course of the trial, as well, as at the end of the Stateâ€™s case.â€Â  Dicapua also moved for a new trial â€œon the basis of what else was set out before the Court, the objections and request going back to the CI, the chain, and all those things.â€Â  The trial court denied Dicapuaâ€™s motions, ruling that the juryâ€™s verdict was supported by the evidence.Â  The trial court sentenced Dicapua to two concurrent sentences of thirty months in prison and fined him $25,000 on each offense.
The trial court vacated Dicapuaâ€™s convictions and sentences the next day, acting sua sponte.Â  The trial court focused upon the videotape, finding its introduction â€œinappropriate for multiple reasons.â€[1]
LAW/ANALYSIS
The State argues the trial court abused its discretion when it granted Dicapua a new trial.Â  We agree.
It is well settled that the grant or refusal of a new trial is within the discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed on appeal absent a clear abuse of that discretion.[2]Â  Where there is no evidence to support a conviction, an order granting a new trial should be upheld.[3]Â  â€œThe State may appeal the grant of a new trial when it appears it is based â€˜wholly upon an error of law.â€™â€[4]
As the record reflects, Dicapuaâ€™s sole objection to the videotape came in the form of a motion in limine to suppress the videotape because of its lack of audio.Â  Once the State moved to enter the videotape into evidence and publish it to the jury, however, Dicapuaâ€™s counsel specifically stated he had â€œno objection.â€Â  We find this amounted to a waiver of any issue Dicapua had with the videotape.
In Martelly v. State, a case similar to the one here, the defendantâ€™s counsel not only failed to object to the introduction of evidence that he had previously moved to suppress through a pretrial motion, but affirmatively stated that he had no objection to its introduction.[5] Â The Court of Appeals of Maryland, in finding the defendant waived his objection, held:

	[A]ppellantâ€™s express waiver of objection to the admission of the evidence now in question was tantamount to a withdrawal of his previous motion to suppress, and . . . consequently the issue of admissibility is not now before us. Â To hold otherwise would be to say that a defendant could not change his mind and affirmatively consent to the admission of the evidence at trial. Â It is settled law that when an accused is present in court and represented by competent counsel, he is bound by the actions and concessions of counsel, and that even constitutional rights may be waived in the course of a trial.[6]

REVERSED.
CURETON, A.J., concurs.
STILWELL, J., concurring in result only in a separate opinion.
STILWELL, J., (concurring in result):Â  I concur with the majority in its decision to reverse the grant of a new trial, but write separately to explain why I would reverse on a different ground.
Dicapua raises the issue of the ability of the State to appeal the grant of a new trial.Â  This is a threshold issue not addressed in the majority opinion.Â  The Stateâ€™s ability to appeal the grant of a new trial is closely circumscribed by precedent.Â  If the grant of a new trial by the trial court is based on the insufficiency of the evidence, the State has no right to appeal.Â  State v. Lynn, 120 S.C. 258, 261, 113 S.E. 74, 75 (1922).Â  On the other hand, the State may appeal the grant of a new trial when it appears it is based wholly upon an error of law.Â  State v. DesChamps, 126 S.C. 416, 418, 120 S.E. 491, 492 (1923).Â  
 
Although the grant or refusal of a new trial motion lies within the discretion of the trial court, â€œ[a]n abuse of discretion occurs when a trial courtâ€™s decision is unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.â€Â  State v. Walker, 366 S.C. 643, 656, 623 S.E.2d 122, 129 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
 
In this instance, I agree the State may appeal because the ruling of the trial court that the videotape is not admissible is, in my view, an error of law.Â  The flaws in the videotape go to the weight of the evidence and not to its admissibility.Â  The trial courtâ€™s grant of a new trial was premised solely on the finding that the videotape was inadmissible.Â  I believe that ruling to be an error of law that allows the appeal, and its prejudicial nature compels the reversal.

[1]Â  The trial court also suppressed the introduction of the videotape in any subsequent trial of Dicapua on the charges, an issue we need not address in view of our decision to reverse the grant of the new trial.
[2]Â  State v. Prince, 316 S.C. 57, 63, 447 S.E.2d 177, 181 (1993).
[3]Â  State v. Smith, 316 S.C. 53, 55, 447 S.E.2d 175, 176 (1993).
[4] Â State v. Johnson, 363 S.C. 184, 189, 610 S.E.2d 305, 307 (Ct. App. 2005) (emphasis in original) (quoting State v. Dasher, 278 S.C. 395, 400, 297 S.E.2d 414, 417 (1982)).
[5]Â  Martelly v. State, 187 A.2d 105, 107 (Md. 1963).
[6]Â  Id. at 108.Â  See Southern Ry. Co. v. Coltex, Inc., 285 S.C. 213, 215-16, 329 S.E.2d 736, 737-38 (1985) (reversing a trial courtâ€™s grant of a new trial ex mero motu on the ground that the partyâ€™s waiver of the issue upon which the trial court granted a new trial meant the issue â€œwas not properly before the trial court, the Court of Appeals, or this Courtâ€ and holding that the grant of a new trial on a waived issue constitutes an error of law requiring reversal); see also State v. Patino, 12 S.W.3d 733, 740 (Mo. Ct. App. 1999) (ruling that the defendant, by announcing he had no objection to the introduction of evidence he previously attempted to suppress in a pretrial motion, affirmatively waived his objection); State v. Scott, 858 S.W.2d 282, 285 (Mo. Ct. App. 1993) (holding that counsel, by affirmatively stating he had no objection to the admission of evidence, as compared to merely failing to object, waived his prior objection); Dean v. State, 749 S.W.2d 80, 83 (Tex. Crim. App. 1988) (ruling an issue was not preserved for appellate review where defense counsel, after losing at the suppression hearing, expressly stated that defense had no objection to the admission of fingerprint evidence when the evidence was later offered at trial); cf. State v. Adkisson, 899 S.W.2d 626, 635 (Tenn. Crim. App. 1994) (â€œWhen . . . a party abandons the ground asserted when the objection was made and asserts completely different grounds in the motion for a new trial . . . the party waives the issue.â€)
