title: Bage v. Southeastern Roofing Co.
description: Southeastern Roofing appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order finding the company was properly served by service of process on its employee, Debbie Green, and determining that it failed to show good cause to allow relief from an entry of default under Rule 55(c), SCRCP. We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Bage, LLC 
Respondent,
				v.
				Southeastern Roofing Co. of Spartanburg, Inc., a/k/a
				Southeastern Roofing Company n/k/a Orvis, Inc. Appellant
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Casey Manning, Circuit Court Judge
Joseph M. Strickland, Master-In-Equity 
Opinion No. 4240
Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed April 23, 2007

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Robert T. King, of Florence, for Appellant.
				Thomas B. Jackson, III, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


ANDERSON, J.:Â Â Â  Southeastern Roofing appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order finding the company was properly served by service of process on its employee, Debbie Green, and determining that it failed to show good cause
to allow relief from an entry of default under Rule 55(c), SCRCP. We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In August 2003, BAGE, L.L.C. (â€œBAGEâ€) entered into a written contract with Southeastern Roofing Company of Spartanburg, Inc. (â€œSoutheastern Roofingâ€).Â  Under the agreement, Southeastern Roofing was to perform re-roofing work on a commercial office building BAGE owned.Â  More specifically, the company was to remove the outer layers of the existing roof system and install of a new, modified bitumen roof on the structure.Â  Southeastern Roofing was to immediately commence the project after the contract was signed and to complete the job within approximately six weeks.Â  Work on the roof, however, did not begin until the end of October 2003 and continued only sporadically through the winter and into the spring of 2004. 
 
From almost the moment Southeastern Roofing started operations on BAGEâ€™s building, significant leaks in the roof began to occur.Â  These leaks resulted in interior water infiltration, manifested by falling ceiling tiles, water gushing down interior walls, light fixtures filling with water, and the growth of mold and mildew.Â  BAGE repeatedly contacted Southeastern Roofing, demanding the leaks be stopped.Â  Despite BAGEâ€™s requests, the necessary repairs were never made and water continued to infiltrate and further damage the building.Â  BAGE ultimately filed suit, claiming breach of contract, breach of express and implied warranties, and negligence.Â  
 
At the fledgling stages of the litigation, BAGEâ€™s counsel spoke with Southeastern Roofingâ€™s general manager, Jamie Cubitt, who initially agreed to accept service of process by mail.Â  When Cubitt failed to return the summons and complaint, BAGE sought to serve the company through its registered agent.Â  After discovering that the agent listed with the Secretary of State was no longer affiliated with Southeastern Roofing, BAGE pursued service via a private process server. Â 
On July 9, 2004, the process server arrived at Southeastern Roofingâ€™s office with the intendment of serving Cubitt with BAGEâ€™s summons and complaint.Â  Cubitt was not in the office at that time, and the server was instead met by Debbie Green, another Southeastern Roofing employee.Â  Green was able to reach Cubitt by telephone.Â  After being informed someone was in the office with papers to serve, Cubitt instructed Green to accept the documents.Â  This communication with Cubitt was relayed to the process server.Â  Green signed for the service of process.Â  An affidavit of service was filed on July 13, 2004.Â  
 
Upon returning to the office, Cubitt instructed another employee, Cheri Barnette, to send a copy of the summons and complaint to Southeastern Roofingâ€™s insurance agency.Â  These documents were faxed to the insurance company on July 13, 2004.Â  No cover letter was included in this facsimile nor was any follow-up with its insurance carrier ever taken by Southeastern Roofing.
Southeastern Roofing never responded to the complaint.Â  BAGE filed an affidavit of default and motion for an entry of default on September 7, 2004.Â  That same day, an entry of default was dated and filed with the court. Â By a motion filed on September 20, 2004, Southeastern Roofing moved to set aside the order granting the entry of default.
A hearing on the motion to set aside the entry of default was held before the circuit court on December 8, 2004.Â  Southeastern Roofing argued (1) the service of process had been improper and thus deprived the court of personal jurisdiction and (2) â€œgood causeâ€ existed to set aside the entry of default under SCRCP Rule 55(c).
By an order dated April 28, 2005, the judge denied Southeastern Roofingâ€™s motion to set aside the entry of default.Â  In regard to service of process, the order specifically found (1) Green was an office manager at Southeastern Roofing for the purposes relevant to service of process and (2) Green had Cubittâ€™s specific authorization to accept service of process.Â  With respect to the Rule 55(c) motion, the judge found Southeastern Roofing had failed to show good cause as to allow relief from the entry of default. Â Southeastern Roofing timely moved for reconsideration of the order denying its motion to set aside default.Â  This motion was denied.Â  
 
On April 27, 2006, following a damages hearing before the Richland County master-in-equity, BAGE obtained a default judgment against Southeastern Roofing in the amount of $1,151,888.84.Â  This judgment was properly filed with the court on May 3, 2006.Â  
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œQuestions of fact arising on a motion to quash service of process for lack of jurisdiction over the defendant are to be determined by the court.â€ Â Brown v. Carolina Emergency Physicians, P.A., 348 S.C. 569, 583, 560 S.E.2d 624, 631 (Ct. App. 2001); accord Lawson v. Jeter, 243 S.C. 103, 106, 132 S.E.2d 276, 277 (1963); Moore v. Simpson, 322 S.C. 518, 524, 473 S.E.2d 64, 67 (Ct. App. 1996). The findings of the circuit court on such issues are binding on this court, unless wholly unsupported by the evidence or manifestly influenced or controlled by error of law. Â Id.
â€œThe decision of whether to grant relief from an entry of default is solely within the sound discretion of the trial court.â€ Wham v. Shearson Lehman Bros., Inc., 298 S.C. 462, 465, 381 S.E.2d 499, 501 (Ct. App. 1989) (citing Ricks v. Weinrauch, 293 S.C. 372, 360 S.E.2d 535 (Ct. App. 1987)); accord In re Estate of Weeks, 329 S.C. 251, 259, 495 S.E.2d 454, 459 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œThis court cannot substitute its judgment for that of the trial judge and will not disturb the trial courtâ€™s decision absent a clear showing of abuse of discretion.â€ Â Ricks, 293 S.C. at 374, 360 S.E.2d at 536; Ammons v. Hood, 288 S.C. 278, 279, 341 S.E.2d 816, 818 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  In reviewing a trial judgeâ€™s exercise of discretion, the issue before an appellate court is not whether it believes good cause existed to set aside the entry of default, but whether the trial judgeâ€™s determination is supported by the evidence and not controlled by an error of law.Â  Pilgrim v. Miller, 350 S.C. 637, 640-41, 567 S.E.2d 527, 528 (Ct. App. 2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Service of Process
Southeastern Roofing argues the delivery of process to Green was insufficient as a matter of law.Â  We disagree.

	Rule 4(d), SCRCP addresses service of process and states:
	
		Summons: Personal Service. The summons and complaint must be served together. Â The plaintiff shall furnish the person making service with such copies as are necessary. Â Voluntary appearance by defendant is equivalent to personal service; and written notice of appearance by a party or his attorney shall be effective upon mailing, or may be served as provided in this rule. Â Service shall be made as follows:
		. . . 
		(3) Corporations and Partnerships. . . .
	

The rule provides service of the summons and complaint may be made upon a corporation by â€œdelivering a copy of the summons and complaint to an officer, a managing or general agent, or to any other agent authorized by appointment or by law to receive service of process . . . .â€Â  Rule 4(d)(3), SCRCP.Â  Service on a managing or general agent is sufficient even though the corporation has a registered agent.Â  Renney v. Dobbs House, Inc., 275 S.C. 562, 274 S.E.2d 290 (1981).

	
		The rule permits service on two types of agents: an agent authorized by appointment and an agent authorized by law.Â  Evidence of an actual appointment by the defendant for the specific purpose of receiving service is normally required to show the authority of the agent.Â  The courts look at the circumstances to find express or implied authority to accept the service.Â  Agency for accepting process is not necessarily established by the act of accepting the process, statements by the person served, or the existence of another agency relationship.
	

James F. Flanagan, South Carolina Civil Procedure 20 (2nd ed. 1996).

	Our supreme court has enunciated:
	
		Service on a corporation may be made by hand delivering a copy of the summons and complaint to an officer of the corporation or to an authorized agent of the corporation.Â  Rule 4(d)(3), SCRCP. Â The rule â€œpresupposes that an officer of the corporation will know what to do with the papers served and will see that the corporation takes steps to defend the action.â€ 62B Am. Jur. 2d,
		Process Â§ 268 (1990). Â Once papers have been served on an officer of the corporation, the corporation then has actual notice of the action. Â Pioneer Util. Corp. v. Scott-Newcomb, Inc., 26 F. Supp. 616 (E.D.N.Y.1939). 
		
	

Roche v. Young Bros., Inc. of Florence, 318 S.C. 207, 210, 456 S.E.2d 897, 899-900 (1995).Â  â€œRule 4, SCRCP serves at least two purposes. Â It confers personal jurisdiction on the court and assures the defendant of reasonable notice of the action.â€Â  Roche, 318 S.C. at 209, 456 S.E.2d at 899; Moore, 322 S.C. at 523, 473 S.E.2d at 66. 
 
â€œThe plaintiff has the burden to establish that the court has personal jurisdiction over the defendant.â€ Â Moore, 322 S.C. at 523, 473 S.E.2d at 66 (citing Jensen v. Doe, 292 S.C. 592, 358 S.E.2d 148 (Ct. App. 1987)). Â However, exacting compliance with the rules is not required to effect service of process. Â Roche, 318 S.C. 209-10, 456 S.E.2d at 899 (citing Foster v. Crawford, 57 S.C. 551, 36 S.E. 5 (1900) (when officerâ€™s return defective as to time and place of service, it can be amended to state facts); Saunders v. Bobo, 2 Bailey 492 (1831) (sheriffâ€™s incomplete return that was not sworn to may be amended); Miller v. Hall, 28 S.C.L. 1, 1 Speers 1 (1842)); Moore, 322 S.C. at 66, 473 S.E.2d at 523. Â Rather, inquiry must only be made as to whether the plaintiff has sufficiently complied with the rules such that the court has personal jurisdiction over the defendant and the defendant has notice of the proceedings.Â  Moore, 322 S.C. at 523, 473 S.E.2d at 66; Roche, 318 S.C. at 210, 456 S.E.2d at 899. Â â€œWhen the civil rules on service are followed, there is a presumption of proper service.â€Â  Roche, 318 S.C. at 211, 456 S.E.2d at 900 (citing 62B Am. Jur. 2d Process Â§ 111 (1990)).Â  The defendant, not the plaintiff, bears the burden of proving that the service of process was signed by an unauthorized person.Â  See Roche, 318 S.C. at 211, 456 S.E.2d at 900 (stating that when service of process is accomplished by certified mail under Rule 4(d)(8), â€œthe defendant, not the plaintiff, must prove the receipt was signed by an unauthorized person.â€).
Not every employee of a corporation is an â€œagentâ€ of the corporation for the purposes of service of process.Â  Brown v. Carolina Emergency Physicians, P.A., 348 S.C. 569, 583-84, 560 S.E.2d 624, 631-32 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  If the employee in question is not a managing or general agent, the question is whether the individual possessed â€œspecific authorization to receive process.â€Â  Id.Â  This court has inculcated:

	
		Actual appointment for the specific purpose of receiving process normally is expected and the mere fact a person may be considered to act as defendantâ€™s agent for some purpose does not necessarily mean that the person has authority to receive process. Â The courts must look to the circumstances surrounding the relationship and find authority which is either express or implied from the type of relationship between the defendant and the alleged agent.Â  Claims by one to possess authority to receive process or actual acceptance of process by an alleged agent will not necessarily bind the defendant. Â Rather, there must be evidence the defendant intended to confer such authority.
	

Moore, 322 S.C. at 523, 473 S.E.2d at 67 (internal citations omitted); accord Hamilton v. Davis, 300 S.C. 411, 414, 389 S.E.2d 297, 299 (Ct. App. 1990).
This court addressed a factually similar issue in Schenk v. National Health Care, Inc., 322 S.C. 316, 471 S.E.2d 736 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  In Schenk, the plaintiff attempted to serve process on the defendantâ€™s registered agent by means of a private process server.Â  When the server took the summons and complaint to the address recorded with the secretary of state, an individual different from the one on file, Carol Grant, informed him the listed agent was no longer there and had retired from the company.Â  Grant signed for the papers, assuring the server that she was duly authorized to accept service as the office manager.Â  She assured him that she would pass the documents along to the companyâ€™s corporate headquarters.Â  The defendant never answered the complaint and an entry of default ensued.Â  A motion to set aside default for improper service was denied by the circuit court.Â  On appeal, this court found service of process had been effective and affirmed the circuit court.Â  Noting Grant was the defendantâ€™s office manager and that she assured the process server of her authorization to accept service of process, we concluded she was a managing agent for the defendant under Rule 4(d)(3), SCRCP.Â  Id. 322 S.C. at 319-20, 471 S.E.2d 738. Â 
Although, â€œ[w]ithout specific authorization to receive process, service is not effective when made upon an employee of the defendant, such as a secretary,â€ Brown, 348 S.C. at 584, 560 S.E.2d at 632 (citing Moore, 322 S.C. at 523-24, 473 S.E.2d at 67), Green indubitably served in a much greater capacity at Southeastern Roofing than simply that of a secretary.Â  The testimony given by Green during her deposition clearly refutes the contents of her prior affidavit submitted by Southeastern Roofing and its assertion that she was only a â€œsecretary/receptionist.â€Â  During Greenâ€™s deposition, the following colloquy took place:

	
		
			Q.
			If Joanie Burnett is not there and youâ€™re there, then accordingly wouldnâ€™t you then be in charge of the office?
			
 
		
		
			A.  
			Yes, Sir.
			
 
		
		
			Q.  
			And on this particular day, you 
			were there and you were in charge of the office?
			
 
		
		
			A.   
			
			Correct.
		
	

Additionally, Green indicates it was common practice for her to sign for the receipt of documents:

	
		
			Q. 
			Was it normal for you to sign 
			for mail for Southeastern?
			
 
		
		
			A.      
			
			Normally it is.Â  I mean as far as, you know, signing for certified mail.Â  Yeah, we usually sign for certified mail.
		
	

The deposition demonstrates Greenâ€™s specific authorization to accept the service of process:

	
		
			Q. 
			. . . Did you tell Mr. Cubitt that the person that was there had a summons and complaint for Mr. Cubitt?
			
 
		
		
			A.  
			
			Yes, Sir.  I 
			just told him that he had some -- the server had some papers from 
			him for some -- for him to sign for.
			
 
		
		
			. . . .
			
			
 
		
		
			Q.    
			
			Did Mr. Cubitt indicate to you it was ok if you --
			
 
		
		
			A.
			Yeah.
			
 
		
		
			Q. 
			--- Accepted the papers?
			
 
		
		
			A.  
			Mm-Hmm (Affirmative Response).
		
	

In his order denying the motion to set aside the entry of default, the circuit judge found:

	
		
			1.  
			As indicated in Ms. Greenâ€™s 
			deposition, the office management responsibilities pertaining to 
			Defendantâ€™s office are shared by the administrative personnel in the 
			office and Ms. Green manages the office and is in charge if no one 
			else is there.  On July 9, 2004, Ms. Green was in charge of 
			managing the office of Defendant when the subject process server 
			arrived for the purpose of serving the Summons and Complaint in this 
			case.
			
 
		
		
			2. 
			According to Ms. Green, and 
			while the process server was at the office, she either called Mr. 
			Jamie Cubitt or Mr. Cubitt called her and, after informing Mr. Cubitt that someone was there with papers to be served, she was authorized by Mr. Cubitt to accept the subject documents, such being told to the process server as acknowledged by Ms. Green in her deposition and also referenced in the process serverâ€™s Affidavit of Service which has been filed in this case.
			
 
		
		
			3.
			After examination by counsel for 
			Plaintiff in her deposition, and on further examination by counsel 
			for Defendant, Ms. Green reconfirmed her conversation with Mr. Jamie Cubitt about being â€œokayedâ€ to â€œreceive whatever it was that the server was there to give you.â€
		
	

Although there is no case in South Carolina specifically defining â€œmanaging agentâ€ or â€œagent authorized by appointmentâ€ under Rule 4(d)(3), SCRCP, Schenk confirms that an office manager of the corporate defendant involved can be deemed a â€œmanaging agentâ€ under the rule.Â  Additionally, the facts of the case prove that Green had Cubittâ€™s authorization to sign for the summons and complaint.Â  Although Southeastern Roofing argues contrarily, the evidence inexplicably supports the circuit judgeâ€™s finding that service on Southeastern Roofing was proper under Rule 4(d)(3), SCRCP.Â  
 
Furthermore, we would note the efficacy and rationale behind the requirement for service of process--that the defendant has notice of the proceedings--has luculently been met in this case.Â  See Roche, 318 S.C. at 210, 456 S.E.2d at 899 (â€œRule 4, SCRCP serves at least two purposes.Â  It confers personal jurisdiction on the court and assures the defendant of reasonable notice of the action.â€); Moore, 322 S.C. at 523, 473 S.E.2d at 66 (â€œRather, inquiry must only be made as to whether the plaintiff has sufficiently complied with the rules such that the court has personal jurisdiction of the defendant and the defendant has notice of the proceedings.â€).Â  The history and dealings between the parties through July 9, 2004 reveal that BAGEâ€™s counsel spoke with Cubitt in regard to this suit and that BAGE attempted to serve process through the postal service.Â  Accordingly, it seems disingenuous for Southeastern Roofing to claim Cubitt, in his conversation with Green, was unaware the papers being served by the process server were the summons and complaint at issue.Â  Moreover, Southeastern Roofingâ€™s manager readily admits to having knowledge of the summons and complaint long before the deadline to answer passed.Â  In his affidavit, Cubitt states: â€œ[O]n or about July 10, 2004, I was notified that a Summons and Complaint concerning this case was left at SE Roofingâ€™s place of business the prior day.â€Â Â  
 
II. Â Entry of Default
Southeastern Roofing argues the court erred in not setting aside the entry of default as provided under Rule 55(c), SCRCP.Â  We disagree.
South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure provide: â€œFor good cause shown the court may set aside an entry of default . . . .â€Â  Rule 55(c), SCRCP.Â  Thus, under the rule, the standard for granting relief from an entry of default is â€œgood cause,â€Â  Wham v. Shearson Lehman Bros., Inc.,Â  298 S.C. 462, 465, 381 S.E.2d 499, 501 (Ct. App. 1989), and is more lenient than the standard for granting relief from a default judgment under Rule 60(b) SCRCP.Â  Ricks v. Weinrauch, 293 S.C. 372, 274, 360 S.E.2d 535, 536 (Ct. App. 1987) (citing H. Lightsey, J. Flanagan, South Carolina Civil Procedure, 82 (2nd Ed. 1985)).
Public policy favors the disposition of cases â€œon their merits rather than on technicalities.â€Â  Mictronics, Inc. v. South Carolina Department of Revenue, 345 S.C. 506, 511, 548 S.E.2d 223, 226 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing Columbia Pools, Inc. v. Galvin, 288 S.C. 59, 339 S.E.2d 524 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  Rule 55(c) should be â€œliberally construed to promote justice and dispose of cases on the merits.â€Â  Dixon v. Besco Engâ€™g, 320 S.C. 174, 178, 463 S.E.2d 636, 638 (Ct. App. 1995); Ricks, 293 S.C. at 374-75, 360 S.E.2d at 536; see also Mann v. Walker, 285 S.C. 194, 328 S.E.2d 659 (Ct. App. 1985) (holding under the earlier statutory provisions for default judgment pursuant to section 15-27-130 of the 1976 Code of Laws of South Carolina, the rules dealing with default are liberally construed to see that justice is promoted and to strive for the disposition of cases on their merits).Â  
 
The decision of whether to grant relief from an entry of default is solely within the sound discretion of the trial court. Â Wham, 298 S.C. at 465, 381 S.E.2d at 501. Â An abuse of discretion in setting aside an entry of default arises when the judge issuing the order was controlled by some error of law or when the order, based upon factual, as distinguished from legal conclusions, is without evidentiary support.Â  In re Estate of Weeks, 329 S.C. 251, 259, 495 S.E.2d 454, 459 (Ct. App. 1997); Boland v. S.C. Public Service Authority, 281 S.C. 293, 315 S.E.2d 143 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  An order based on this discretion will not be set aside absent an error of law or lack of evidentiary support. Â Wham, 298 S.C. at 465, 381 S.E.2d at 501; Stanton v. Town of Pawleyâ€™s Island, 309 S.C. 126, 420 S.E.2d 502 (1992) (stating the appellate court will not disturb a discretionary ruling unless the ruling is without evidentiary support or is controlled by an error of law); Ricks, 293 S.C. 372 S.E.2d 535 (Ct. App. 1987) (holding abuse of discretion in setting aside an entry of default occurs when order was controlled by some error of law or, based upon factual-as distinguished from legal conclusions-was without evidentiary support).Â  Williams v. Vanvolkenburg makes clear the appellate court reviews an evidentiary record under the â€œgood causeâ€ standard by determining whether the trial judgeâ€™s determination is supportable by the evidence and not controlled by an error of law.Â  312 S.C. 373, 440 S.E.2d 408 (Ct. App. 1994). Â 
The seminal case articulating the application of â€œgood causeâ€ under Rule 55(c) to a factual scenario is Wham v. Shearson Lehman Brothers, Inc., 298 S.C. 462, 381 S.E.2d 499 (Ct. App. 1989). Â Wham provides:

	Under S.C.R.Civ.P. 55(c), as under F.R.CIV.P. 55(c), the standard for granting relief from an entry of default is â€œgood cause.â€ Â The decision of whether to grant relief from an entry of default is solely within the sound discretion of the trial court. Â An order based on an exercise of that discretion, however, will be set aside if it is controlled by some error of law or lacks evidentiary support.
	. . .
	In deciding the question of whether to grant the motion by [the defendant] for relief from the entry of default, the master did not employ the â€œgood causeâ€ standard. Â Instead, the master erroneously applied the more rigorous standard of â€œexcusable neglect,â€ a standard used under Rule 60(b). Â He did this even though he recognized the â€œgood causeâ€ standard was applicable.

Id. at 465, 381 S.E.2d at 501 (citations omitted).
A â€œgood causeâ€ analysis under Rule 55(c) ordinarily is made by the trial judge.Â  In deciding whether to set aside an entry of default, the factors the judge should consider are: (1) the timing of the motion for relief; (2) whether the defendant has a meritorious defense; and (3) the degree of prejudice to the plaintiff if relief is granted. Â Wham, 298 S.C. at 465, 381 S.E.2d at 501-02; Weeks, 329 S.C. at 259, 495 S.E.2d at 459.Â  However, it is not necessary for the trial judge to make specific findings in regard to the factors enumerated in Wham. Â This court has held, â€œ[t]he trial judge will not be reversed for failing to make specific findings of fact on the record for each factor if there is sufficient evidentiary support on the record for the finding of the lack of good cause.â€Â  Dixon, 320 S.C. at 179, 463 S.E.2d at 639.
In this case, over two months elapsed between the time Southeastern Roofing was served with the summons and complaint and when it moved for relief.Â  Although the summons and complaint were allegedly sent to Southeastern Roofingâ€™s insurance agent, any negligence by the insurance agent in handling these documents is imputable to Southeastern Roofing.Â  Pilgrim v. Miller, 350 SC. 367, 567 S.E.2d 527 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Pursuant to the findings of the circuit court, Southeastern Roofing mishandled the service of process of this lawsuit:

	It is apparent from the Affidavits filed on behalf of the Defendant that Defendant simply failed to give this matter the proper attention which needed to be given when an entity is served with a Summons and Complaint.Â  There is no indication that there was even a cover letter or other follow up by any representatives of Defendant with its insurance agent after the Summons and Complaint were allegedly faxed to such agent. . . .Â  Defendantâ€™s failure to properly respond to the Summons and Complaint in this case resulted from its failure to take proper action in order to assure that a response was timely filed in regard to Plaintiffâ€™s Summons and Complaint. 
	

Based on the alleged defective workmanship of Southeastern Roofing, the circuit court did not believe Southeastern Roofing had a meritorious defense.Â  The circuit judge stated:

	[T]he Defendant does not otherwise have a meritorious defense to the Complaint based on the alleged poor roofing workmanship of Defendant which has apparently caused Plaintiff to sustain continuing damage to the building involved in this case due to water infiltration . . . Â 

In support of its motion to set aside the order of default, Southeastern Roofing filed several affidavits.Â  The court specifically addressed two of these affidavits in its order:

	As to the Affidavit of Cheri Barnette submitted on behalf of Defendant, Ms. Barnette clearly confirms that Mr. James Cubitt did timely receive the Summons and Complaint which was served in this case and that instructed Ms. Barnette to send the Summons and Complaint to Defendantâ€™s insurance agent, all of which was apparently without any transmittal or follow up by Defendant.
	
	As to the Affidavit of James Cubitt submitted on behalf of Defendant, Mr. Cubitt confirms (1) that he did receive the Summons and Complaint in a timely fashion, and (2) that he did instruct Cheri Barnette to fax a copy of the Summons and Complaint to Defendantâ€™s insurance agent (i.e. all of which was apparently done according to Ms. Barnette in her Affidavit) and that it was Mr. James Cubittâ€™s understanding that the insurance agent would contact Defendant concerning the Summons and Complaint.Â  Apparently, there was no follow up by Defendant.
	

The circuit court found the evidence did not show the existence of good cause as to allow Southeastern Roofing relief from the entry of default.Â  In making this determination, the circuit judge relied upon Stark Truss Co. v. Superior Construction Corp., 360 S.C. 503, 602 S.E.2d 99 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  In Stark, the circuit court refused to relieve the defendants from an entry of default, finding they had failed to present sufficient proof of good cause under Rule 55(c), SCRCP.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed.Â  Noting the defendantâ€™s only explanation for not filing an answer within thirty days was that the companyâ€™s president was â€œstruggling with some depression and had a lot things slip through his fingersâ€ and gave no reason why its attorney failed to file an answer, this court found â€œthere was evidence to support the circuit courtâ€™s refusal to set aside the entry of default.â€Â  Id., 360 S.C. at 510, 602 S.E.2d at 103.
As determined by the circuit judge, Southeastern Roofingâ€™s failure to properly respond to the summons and complaint resulted from its failure to take proper actions in order to assure a response was timely filed.Â  The company offers no good or valid explanation as to why it failed to respond.Â  There is no indication that there was any follow-up by the employees of Southeastern Roofing with its insurance agent after the summons and complaint were allegedly faxed to the agent.Â  It is axiomatic that Southeastern Roofing simply did not give this matter the proper attention it required.Â  
 
CONCLUSION 
We come to the ineluctable conclusion Green qualifies as both a managing and authorized agent of the appellant. Â Concomitantly, the appellant was properly served when the summons and complaint were delivered to Green as an agent of the appellant.Â  There is copious evidence in the record to support the circuit judgeâ€™s finding that appellant did not prove the existence of good cause to allow the court to set aside the entry of default.Â  We hold there was no abuse of discretion by the trial judge in refusing to grant the appellant relief under SCRCP, Rule 55(c).
Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Shaw v. Coleman
description: Appellant appeals a permanent injunction preventing him from discharging firearms on his property or immediate surroundings, firing air rifles or pellet guns toward Respondents' property or person, and yelling or otherwise provoking the Respondents.  We affirm as modified.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Carol C. Shaw, Charles W. Shaw, III, J. Roth Snowden and Delia S. Snowden, Respondents,
				v.
				Christopher M. Coleman, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Marion County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4241
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed April 30, 2007

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


	
		
			
				Laura Catherine Tesh, of Columbia, Lourie A. Salley, III, of Lexington, for Appellant.
				Edgar Lloyd Willcox, II, of Florence, for Respondents.
			
		
	

BEATTY, J.: Â Â Â Â Â  Christopher Coleman appeals a permanent injunction preventing him from discharging firearms on his property or immediate surroundings, firing air rifles or pellet guns toward Carol and Charles Shawâ€™s and Roth and Delia Snowdenâ€™s property or person, and yelling or otherwise provoking the Shaws or the Snowdens.Â  We affirm as modified.[1]
FACTS
Coleman lives between the Shawsâ€™ and the Snowdensâ€™ property on a stretch of land mainly composed of woods and swamp.Â  The properties stretch across Holly Road in Marion, South Carolina.Â  The Snowdens moved to their property in 1959. Â Coleman bought his one-acre property in 1990.Â  The Shaws purchased their land in 1992.
 
After numerous problems with Coleman beginning in August of 2002, including harassing behavior and his firing of weapons on and off his property, the Shaws and the Snowdens brought a nuisance action seeking a permanent injunction[2] of Colemanâ€™s use of firearms, damages for Colemanâ€™s alleged violation of section 31-18-30 of the South Carolina Code (2007),[3] damages for alleged conversion, and damages and a permanent injunction for alleged trespass.[4] Â Ultimately, the courtâ€™s ruling was limited to the question of whether a permanent injunction should be issued.
As a threshold matter, the trial court had to determine whether Coleman had a shooting range on his property because Coleman attempted to use section 31-18-30 of the South Carolina Shooting Range Protection Act (the Act) as a defense.Â  In reaching this decision, the trial court heard two days of testimony and visited the property with the parties.
 
Terry and Violette Thompson purchased ten acres from the Snowdens in August of 2002.Â  Coleman had previously expressed an interest in purchasing this land, but the offer was rejected.Â  Prior to the sale, the Snowdens did not have any problems with Coleman.Â  Ms. Shaw testified that before the sale she heard four or five shots on Colemanâ€™s land over two to three months.Â  According to Patricia Rowell, who also lives near Holly Road, Coleman fired guns occasionally prior to August of 2002, and after August of 2002, Colemanâ€™s shooting was continuous.Â  When the Thompsons bought the property, the frequency of Colemanâ€™s shooting greatly escalated.Â  The Thompsons sold their property back to the Snowdens in October of 2003 due to Colemanâ€™s continued shooting.
 
Ms. Shaw testified that Coleman planned to run the Thompsons off the property because he wanted to purchase it.Â  Mr. Shaw concurred with his wife when he testified that Coleman did not want anyone living on the property the Thompsons purchased, and that he planned to run the Thompsons off of their land.Â  Additionally, Mason Draper, a neighbor, discussed the Thompsons with Coleman.Â  According to Draper, Coleman stated that he would keep shooting until the Thompsons moved.
 
Other nearby property owners experienced similar treatment by Coleman when they sold a portion of their property to a party other than Coleman. Â The Stackhouses testified that Coleman appeared at their residence screaming that they could not sell their property.Â  In addition, following Frank Shawâ€™s purchase of land near Colemanâ€™s property, Coleman followed Shaw and filmed him with a video camera.
There was also testimony that Coleman did not limit his shooting to his property, but instead, targeted specific individuals.Â  Both Mr. Shaw and Mr. Snowden testified that Coleman fired bullets over their heads.Â  Additionally, Mr. Snowden watched Coleman fire his rifle over the Thompsonsâ€™ property.Â  Ms. Thompson also saw Coleman firing over a public road and over her head and her sonâ€™s head.Â  Thomas Nolan witnessed Coleman crouched down near the Shawsâ€™ property while wearing a side-arm holster.Â 
 
In addition to Colemanâ€™s shooting, witnesses also described Colemanâ€™s harassing and threatening behavior.Â  Mr. Shaw stated that Coleman took pictures of him.Â  Mr. Thompson testified that while he was driving on a dirt road, Coleman appeared and drove erratically behind him while waving a gun.Â  Coleman also repeatedly fired an air cannon on his land.
During this contentious time, Travis Rowell delivered thirty tons of dirt to Colemanâ€™s property in December of 2002.Â  Rowell deposited the dirt on a small mound with targets, which was already present prior to the delivery.Â  Additionally, Coleman installed slats on his chain link fence in response to noise complaints.Â 
 
In presenting his case, Coleman testified that he wanted to become a shooting instructor and met Charles Shortsleeve, an instructor, in 2003.Â  Coleman claimed he taught as many as fifty people about guns.Â  He further testified that he first obtained a business license for the Sports Shooting Club on his property in 1992, and the license is still effective.Â  Coleman acknowledged the license was for â€œgun smithing activities.â€
 
On behalf of Coleman, several people testified regarding firearms being shot on Colemanâ€™s property.Â  Ray Williams testified he fired guns on Colemanâ€™s property from 1997 to 2001.Â  Between 1990 and 1993, Vicky Bostic observed Coleman shooting at his backstop a few times.Â  Stacey Jordan fired guns on Colemanâ€™s property as early as 1993.Â  Brian Polston remembered firing guns on Colemanâ€™s property as early as 1997.
 
Robert Butler, who was involved in drafting several amendments to the Act, stated he saw distance markers and a backstop between ten and twelve feet on Colemanâ€™s property the morning of his testimony. Â Butler believed that Colemanâ€™s property met the requirements of the Act.Â Â Â 
 
After the hearing, the trial court issued an order on May 9, 2005. Â The court held under section 31-18-20 that Colemanâ€™s property was not a shooting range because â€œthe primary use of [Colemanâ€™s] property is as a residence for Mr. Coleman, and the use of weaponry is a collateral use incident to his residence at the property.â€ Â Based on this analysis, the court held that Coleman â€œmay not avail himself of the protections of the South Carolina Shooting Range Act,â€ and found that the Act did not apply to Colemanâ€™s property.Â  As a result of these findings, the court permanently enjoined Coleman from discharging firearms on his property or the surrounding property, from discharging air rifles or pellet guns toward the Shawsâ€™ or Snowdensâ€™ property or person, and from screaming obscenities at the Shaws or the Snowdens or otherwise provoking the Shaws or the Snowdens.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œActions for injunctive relief are equitable in nature.â€ Wiedemann v. Town of Hilton Head Island, 344 S.C. 233, 236, 542 S.E.2d 752, 753 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œIn an action in equity tried by the judge without a reference, we have jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€ Â LeFurgy v. Long Cove Club Owners Assâ€™n, 313 S.C. 555, 557, 443 S.E.2d 577, 578 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  However, this scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings of the trial court that saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better position to judge their credibility.Â  Blanks v. Rawson, 296 S.C. 110, 114, 370 S.E.2d 890, 893 (Ct. App. 1988).
DISCUSSION
I.  Shooting Range Protection Act
Coleman argues the trial court erred in granting the permanent injunction because section 31-18-30 of the Act protects his shooting range from this nuisance action.Â  We disagree.
Relying on the provisions of the Act, the trial court found that Colemanâ€™s property, which was his residence, was not a shooting range given that firing firearms was not the â€œusual, regular, and primary activity occurring in the area.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 31-18-20(1)(b) (2007).Â  Coleman asserts the trial court â€œerred as a matter of law in interpreting the statute to per se exclude Colemanâ€™s property because he lives there.â€ 
 
Because the disposition of this case turns on the interpretation of the Act, we must rely upon the rules governing statutory construction. â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory interpretation is to ascertain and effectuate the intention of the Legislature.â€Â  Floyd v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co., 367 S.C. 253, 260, 626 S.E.2d 6, 10 (2005). Â â€œWhere the terms of the statute are clear, the court must apply those terms according to their literal meaning, without resort to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.â€  Cooper v. Moore, 351 S.C. 207, 212, 569 S.E.2d 330, 332 (2002).Â  An issue regarding statutory interpretation is a question of law. S.C. Uninsured Employerâ€™s Fund v. House, 360 S.C. 468, 470, 602 S.E.2d 81, 82 (Ct. App. 2004).

	Section 31-18-20 defines a shooting range as follows:
	(1) â€œshooting rangeâ€ or â€œrangeâ€ means an area that is:
	
		(a) designated, utilized, and operated by a person for the firing of firearms; where
		(b) the firing of firearms is the usual, regular, and primary activity occurring in the area; and where
		(c) the improvements, size, geography, and vegetation of the area are such that a projectile discharged from a firearm at a target would not reasonably be expected to escape its boundaries by virtue of the trajectory of the projectile, or by virtue of a backstop, berm, bullet trap, impact barrier, or similar device designed to prevent the escape of such projectiles.
	
	(2) â€œpersonâ€ means an individual, partnership, limited liability company, corporation, club, association, governmental entity, or other legal entity.
	(3) â€œsubstantial change in useâ€ or â€œsubstantial change in the useâ€ means that the current primary use of the range no longer represents the activity previously engaged in at the range.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 31-18-20 (2007).
On Colemanâ€™s one-acre property there is his residence as well as an area specifically designated for firing weapons, which includes a backstop or berm.Â  Coleman also offered evidence that he has a valid business license and all the appropriate permits to operate firearms on the property. Â Additionally, two witnesses, Butler and William Powell, testified Coleman has established a shooting range which complies with the Act.Â  Based on this evidence, we believe Colemanâ€™s property constituted a shooting range and fell within the ambit of the statute. Â Accordingly, we find the trial court erred in excluding Colemanâ€™s property from the protection of the Act because the property was his residence and shooting was not the sole activity conducted on the property. Â Â 
Although the classification of Colemanâ€™s property as a shooting range implicates section 31-18-30 of the Act, that section does not necessarily preclude the Shaws and the Snowdens from bringing their nuisance claim or provide Coleman with absolute immunity from the claim.Â  Section 31-18-30 states in pertinent part:

	(A) Except as provided in this subsection, a person may not maintain a nuisance action for noise against a shooting range, or the owners, operators, or users of the range, located in the vicinity of that personâ€™s property if the shooting range was established as of the date the person acquired the property. Â If there is a substantial change in the use of the range after the person acquires the property, the person may maintain a nuisance action if the action is brought within three years from the beginning of the substantial change.
	(B) A person who owns property in the vicinity of a shooting range that was established after the person acquired the property may maintain a nuisance action for noise against that shooting range, or the owners, operators, or users of the range, only if the action is brought within five years after establishment of the range or three years after a substantial change in use of the range.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 31-18-30 (2007).Â  As evidenced by the terms of the statute, a nuisance claim may be filed against the owner of a shooting range, but it must be filed within specific time limits. Â We believe the Shaws and the Snowdens filed their claim in compliance with the above-outlined section.
The Shaws purchased their land in 1992, and the Snowdens moved to their property in 1959.Â  Coleman bought his one acre property in 1990.Â  The record indicates people fired guns on Colemanâ€™s property for many years.Â  However, the intensity greatly increased in 2002.Â  In addition, Travis Rowell delivered thirty tons of dirt to Colemanâ€™s property in December of 2002, which served as a backstop for firing guns.Â  Moreover, Coleman at that time began taking certification classes and attempted to put up signs to make the public aware of the existence of a shooting range. Â Therefore, we find that while shooting occurred sporadically on Colemanâ€™s property, the shooting range was not established until 2002.
The Shaws and the Snowdens filed their initial complaint against Coleman on May 13, 2004.Â  This filing was well within the five years after the establishment of a range allowed under section 31-18-30(B).Â  Therefore, although the trial court misapplied section 31-18-20 regarding the existence of a shooting range on Colemanâ€™s property, we find this error is harmless given section 31-18-30(B) does not protect Coleman from the filing of the nuisance action.
Having found the Act is applicable and that the Shaws and the Snowdens properly filed their claim, we must determine whether Colemanâ€™s conduct created a nuisance sufficient to warrant a permanent injunction.
In explaining the theoretical underpinnings for the procedure employed in assessing whether a nuisance has been created, our court has stated:

	In resolving issues relating to a private nuisance, we must deal with the conflicting interests of land owners.Â  To establish the line beyond which oneâ€™s exercise of his property rights becomes a legal infringement upon the property rights of another requires a delicate balancing of the correlative rights of the parties; the right of one generally to make such lawful use of his property as he may desire and the right of the other to be protected in the reasonable enjoyment of his property.Â 
	

Oâ€™Cain v. Oâ€™Cain, 322 S.C. 551, 560, 473 S.E.2d 460, 465 (Ct. App. 1996) (citations omitted).
â€œThe traditional concept of a nuisance requires a landowner to demonstrate that the defendant unreasonably interfered with his ownership or possession of the land.â€Â  Silvester v. Spring Valley Country Club, 344 S.C. 280, 286, 543 S.E.2d 563, 566 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œ[N]uisance is a substantial and unreasonable interference with the plaintiffâ€™s use and enjoyment of his property.â€Â  Id.; see Blanks v. Rawson, 296 S.C. 110, 113, 370 S.E.2d 890, 892 (Ct. App. 1988) (â€œA nuisance has been defined as â€˜anything which works hurt, inconvenience, or damages; anything which essentially interferes with the enjoyment of life or property.â€™â€ (quoting Strong v. Winn-Dixie Stores, Inc., 240 S.C. 244, 253, 125 S.E.2d 628, 632 (1962))).Â  â€œIf a lawful business is operated in an unlawful or unreasonable manner so as to produce material injury or great annoyance to others or unreasonably interferes with the lawful use and enjoyment of the property of others, it will constitute a nuisance.â€ LeFurgy, 313 S.C. at 558, 443 S.E.2d at 579. Â â€œSince the degree of annoyance or inconvenience necessary to constitute an actionable nuisance cannot be generally quantified, each case must depend largely on its own facts.â€Â  Id. at 559, 443 S.E.2d at 579.Â  â€œThe question is not whether the plaintiffs have been annoyed or disturbed by the operation of the business in question, but whether there has been an injury to their legal rights.â€Â  Id.
Beginning in 2002, Coleman fired guns continuously, over roads, over property, and over individuals.Â  Coleman also caused excessive noise by firing an air cannon on his property.Â  Several of Colemanâ€™s neighbors testified they felt threatened by Colemanâ€™s actions. Â Mr. Snowden also stated that Colemanâ€™s actions prevented him from selling any area property. Â Based on this evidence, we hold Colemanâ€™s conduct on his shooting range constituted a nuisance that was not based solely on excessive noise.Â  See Oâ€™Cain, 322 S.C. at 562, 473 S.E.2d at 466 (â€œWhile a business may be a legitimate one and not a nuisance per se, it may become a nuisance per accidens by . . . the manner in which it is conducted.â€). Â Therefore, we find the trial court correctly determined Coleman created a nuisance in that he unreasonably interfered with the Shawsâ€™ and the Snowdensâ€™ ownership and possession of their property. 
 
We believe our decision is consistent with the intent of the Legislature in establishing the Act.Â  As both parties agree, property owners near shooting ranges will undoubtedly be annoyed by the noise created by the firing of weapons.Â  However, if the conduct on the shooting range becomes such as to be a nuisance, a property owner must have some recourse to abate the nuisance.Â  As we understand the Act, the Legislature clearly intended to protect the investments of shooting range owners by establishing a limitation on when a nuisance claim may be filed against them.Â  See Act No. 260, 2000 S.C. Acts 1924 (providing that enactment of South Carolina Shooting Range Protection Act of 2000 was â€œto regulate nuisance actions in connection with the acquisition of property near existing shooting ranges, the establishment of shooting ranges near existing property, and dormant shooting ranges . . . .â€).Â  This limitation assures that property owners may not move to an area where a shooting range has been established and then assert a nuisance claim.Â  Instead, by permitting a property owner to file a nuisance claim, within established statutory time limits, the Legislature effectively balanced the competing interests of the shooting range owners and their neighbors.Â  Here, the Shaws and the Snowdens properly filed their legitimate nuisance claim within the governing statute of limitations.Â  
 
II.Â  Permanent Injunction
Even if his shooting range does not have absolute immunity from a nuisance action under the Act, Coleman argues a permanent injunction is an extreme remedy, which is not appropriate because the Shaws and the Snowdens have alternative legal remedies available. Â We disagree. 
 
â€œThe remedy of injunction is a drastic one and should be cautiously applied only when legal rights are unlawfully invaded or legal duties are willfully or wantonly neglected.â€ LeFurgy, 313 S.C. at 558, 443 S.E.2d at 578.Â  â€œIn cases where an injunction is sought to abate an alleged private nuisance, the court must deal with the conflicting interests of the landowners by balancing the benefits of an injunction to the plaintiff against the inconvenience and damage to the defendant, and grant or deny an injunction as seem most consistent with justice and equity under the circumstances of the case.â€ Id.Â  
 
In its order, the trial court recognized the serious nature of an injunction and acknowledged the need to balance the partiesâ€™ conflicting interests and pointed to evidence of Colemanâ€™s â€œconfrontational and threatening behavior.â€Â  We agree with the trial court and find the preponderance of the evidence shows that Colemanâ€™s conduct on his shooting range constitutes a private nuisance and should be enjoined.Â  
 
The Shaws and the Snowdens testified Coleman willfully fired a rifle towards his neighbors and over their land. Â There was also testimony that Coleman created excessive noise through the use of an air canon.Â  Based on Colemanâ€™s actions, several of the neighbors testified that they felt threatened.Â  Mr. Snowden also testified that Colemanâ€™s actions prevented him from selling any area property. Â Therefore, we agree with the trial court that â€œMr. Coleman unreasonably interfered with their ownership and possession of their land.â€Â  Although we recognize, as did the trial court, the injunction will inconvenience Coleman by preventing him from maintaining his shooting range and being an instructor, the safety benefits to the Shaws and the Snowdens outweigh the inconvenience suffered by Coleman.Â  See Citizens for a Safe Grant v. Lone Oak Sportsmenâ€™s Club, Inc., 624 N.W.2d 796, 804 (Minn. Ct. App. 2001) (affirming trial courtâ€™s decision to issue a permanent injunction and finding that gun clubâ€™s conduct at shooting range created a nuisance where neighbors were apprehensive about going outside on their property during times of shooting, went indoors to avoid the noise, experienced bullets or shotgun pellets passing over their heads, and saw â€œsigns of indiscriminate shooting on the club propertyâ€); see also F.S. Tinio, Annotation, Gun Club, or Shooting Gallery or Range, as Nuisance, 26 A.L.R.3d 661 (1969 & Supp. 2007) (â€œThe remedy generally availed of by persons who have been injured or have suffered damages on account of the maintenance of shooting galleries, gun clubs, or shooting ranges, is injunction.Â  The grant or denial of this remedy depends on the relevant surrounding circumstances and the evidence presented by the plaintiff.â€).
Additionally, Coleman suggests the Shaws and the Snowdens have legal actions available to them, and thus, a permanent injunction as an equitable remedy was not appropriate. Â Coleman is correct that equity is reserved for situations where there is no adequate remedy at law. Â See Santee Cooper Resort, Inc. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 298 S.C. 179, 185, 379 S.E.2d 119, 123 (1989) (â€œEquitable relief is generally available only where there is no adequate remedy at law.â€).Â  The Shaws and the Snowdens, however, are seeking an injunction to prevent Colemanâ€™s dangerous behavior, which cannot be adequately accomplished by an award of damages.Â  Â Â Â 
In their amended complaint, the Shaws and the Snowdens sought an injunction to prevent the â€œcontinuous discharging of firearms and threatening of plaintiffsâ€ in addition to actions for damages for alleged trespass, conversion, and violation of section 31-18-30.Â  Mr. Snowden saw Coleman firing onto peopleâ€™s property and over individualsâ€™ heads.Â  Coleman also fired over Ms. Thompsonâ€™s and her sonâ€™s head.Â  Because the desired action is to prevent Colemanâ€™s dangerous activity, an injunction is appropriate in this case.Â  Therefore, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision to grant a permanent injunction.Â  See Oâ€™Cain, 322 S.C. at 561, 473 S.E.2d at 466 (â€œA lawful business should not be enjoined on account of every trifling or imaginary annoyance, such as may offend the taste or disturb the nerves of a fastidious or overly sensitive person, but on the other hand, no one, whatever his circumstances or condition may be, should be compelled to leave his home or live in mental discomfort, although caused by a lawful and useful business carried on his vicinity.â€). 
 
In reaching our decision, we have considered the cases from other jurisdictions which were submitted by Coleman.Â  Upon review, we find these cases are factually distinguishable, particularly those that discuss excessive noise as the sole basis to bar nuisance actions against shooting ranges.Â  Moreover, we are unable to glean a general rule from these cases for which to resolve the very fact-specific determination of whether to issue a permanent injunction based on a nuisance claim.Â  Balancing the benefits of an injunction to the Shaws and the Snowdens against the inconvenience and damage to Coleman, we hold the trial court correctly granted the injunction.
CONCLUSION
We find the trial court erred in concluding that Coleman did not own a shooting range solely on the basis that he resided on the property at issue.Â  Because we believe Coleman did own a shooting range beginning in 2002, we hold the Act was applicable.Â  We also hold the Shaws and the Snowdens properly filed and established a claim for nuisance against Coleman.Â  Finally, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision to grant a permanent injunction.
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
HEARN, C.J. and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Â This case was originally scheduled for oral argument.Â  Because the parties agreed to submit this case on the record and briefs, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â The trial court granted a temporary injunction by order dated August 17, 2004. 
 
[3]Â  As will be more fully discussed, section 31-18-30 of the South Carolina Code is one of the statutory provisions comprising the â€œSouth Carolina Shooting Range Protection Act of 2000.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 31-18-10 to -60 (2007).
[4]Â  In a pre-trial ruling, the court denied the Shawsâ€™ and the Snowdensâ€™ motion to amend their complaint to include the conversion claim.Â  At the conclusion of the Shawsâ€™ and Snowdensâ€™ case, the court also directed a verdict in favor of Coleman as to the trespass claim.
